  {
    "Course": "AAE20300",
    "Title": "Aeromechanics I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Fundamental concepts and principles of bodies in motion, with applications to aeronautical and\nastronautical problems. Subjects covered include rectilinear motion, curvilinear motion, rotation, and plane motion. The\nstatic equilibrium and quasistatic equilibrium situations are treated as a part of motion in which the acceleration is zero.\nProblems involving impact, separation, work, and energy are considered. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE20400",
    "Title": "Aeromechanics II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Loads on aircraft. Strain, stress, and equations of equilibrium. Description of aircraft structures and\nmaterials. Torsion of shafts. Fuselage and wing structures. Symmetrical bending and stiffness analysis of solid and\nstringer-panel box beams. Structural failures. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE20401",
    "Title": "Aeromechanics II Laboratory",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to strain gauges, dial gauges, and photoelasticity. Tensile test. Torsion of solid and\nhollow propeller shafts. Stress concentration around skin cut-outs. Bending of symmetrical box wing beams. Combined\naxial and flexural test of aircraft stringers. Buckling of slender stringers. Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {

    "Title": "Introduction To Aerospace Design",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The role of design in aerospace engineering. Introduction to aerodynamics, performance,\npropulsion, structures, stability and control, and weights. Layout and general arrangement of aerospace vehicles.\nDesign concept generation and selection. Computational methods for design. Trade studies and graphical optimization.\nConceptual design exercise involving aircraft, spacecraft, or both. Technical presentations and communication for\naerospace engineering. Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Thermal Sciences",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A fundamental course covering a range of topics selected from the disciplines of engineering\nthermodynamics, fluid mechanics, heat transfer and combustion, with an emphasis on their application to propulsion.\nThis is an entry level course to prepare students for advanced analysis of propulsion and energy systems. Upon\ncompletion of this course, students are expected to be able to apply fundamental principles to perform thermodynamic\nanalysis for thermophysical problems involving fluid flow, heat transfer and combustion. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "AAE35200",

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Properties of wing and fuselage sections. Beam-column moments. Torsion of thin-walled and skin-\nstringer multiple-cell sections. Nonsymmetrical bending of skin-stringer wing sections. Flexural shear in open and\nclosed thin-walled and skin-stringer sections. Loads and stresses in the rib system. Cutouts and shear lag. Modified\nbeam theory for wing and fuselage design. Deflection by energy method. Introduction to composite\nstructures. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "AAE41200",
    "Title": "Introduction To Computational Fluid Dynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introductory course in the formulation and application of finite difference methods for solving\nfluid flow problems. Classification of partial differential equations and formulation of well-posed problems. Discrete\napproximation of partial differential equations: stability, consistency, and convergence. Finite-volume formulations.\nSurvey of methods for solving hyperbolic, elliptic, and parabolic problems. Formulation of discrete boundary\nconditions. Application of methods to one- and two-dimensional flow problems. Credits: 3.00"

    "Description": "Theory and application of experimental techniques and instrumentation for aerodynamics and fluid\nmechanics.   {
    "Course": "AAE52100",
    "Title": "Plasma Laboratory",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The laboratory course will include lab prep lectures, practical classes and mini-projects. Lab prep\nlectures will briefly cover topics of the basic plasma physics and diagnostics relevant to the subsequent practical\nclasses. In addition, details of the corresponding lab procedure, instructions and lab report assignment will be\ndiscussed. Practical classes will involve students in practical creation and operation of various plasma sources and\nplasma diagnostics. Specifically, students will operate DC high voltage breakdown facility, electrostatic accelerator\n(ion thruster), cross-field accelerator (Hall thruster), Atmospheric-Pressure Plasma Jet facility, and will conduct\nmeasurements of plasma parameters using Langmuir probes, microwave interferometer and optical\nspectrometer. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE53200",
    "Title": "Orbit Mechanics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Orbit determination of near-earth satellites and various perturbations; libration and attitude control;\norbit transfer and interception; lunar theory and interplanetary orbits; ascending mechanics and re-entry. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE53400",
    "Title": "Spacecraft Electric Propulsion",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Spacecraft electric propulsion systems are intended to provide thrust for propelling spacecrafts in\ninterplanetary missions, orbital maneuvers, and attitude control. The course will start with reviewing material on the\nmechanics and thermodynamics of propulsion, and identifying the niche occupied by the electric propulsion systems.\nThe course will cover elements of plasma physics and electromagnetic theory essential for studying the electric\npropulsion systems. The core of the course will focus on studying various electric propulsion concepts which utilize\nelectric power produced on-board to generate thrust. Mechanisms of the utilization of the electric power to accelerate\ngas or plasma and produce thrust will be considered, including electrothermal, electrostatic, electromagnetic, and\ngasdynamic acceleration mechanisms. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE53500",
    "Title": "Propulsion Design, Build, Test",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,

Standard\nmethods for thermostructural, life, performance, and combustion stability design analysis; combustor design.\nExperimental procedures; fabrication; test. Special topics according to student interest. Credits: 3.00"
  },

Ram accelerator ballistic launch concepts. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {

    "Title": "Air Breathing Propulsion",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(ME 53800) Analysis of operating characteristics of turbojet, turbofan, turboshaft, afterburning,\nand ramjet propulsion systems. Mission\nanalysis. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE53900",
    "Title": "Advanced Rocket Propulsion",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Generalized internal compressible and incompressible flows. Thermochemistry and heat transfer in\nrocket applications. Advanced topics in solid rocket motor performance and internal ballistics. Liquid rocket engine\ncycle analysis and turbopump design. Combustion of liquid and solid propellants. Hybrid rockets and thermal-nuclear\nengines. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE54500",
    "Title": "Dynamic Behavior of Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Materials' responses to high-rate loading are different from their quasi-static behavior.\nApplications of materials in structures subjected to impact loading from events such as bird strike require the\nunderstanding of dynamic material behavior. Such high-rate materials behavior is not available in standard materials\nhandbooks or design manuals. This course introduces stress wave propagation in solids, which is the foundation to\ncharacterization and understanding of high-rate response of materials. Then, the theoretical background and working\nprinciples of high-rate experimental methods are presented to characterize the material response under high-rate\nloading conditions. Finally, rate-dependent material models are introduced to describe the dynamic material behavior\nand deformation mechanisms. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE54600",
    "Title": "Aerospace Structural Dynamics And Stability",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Dynamics of continuous systems: rod, beam, frame, and plate structures. General structural\nprinciples: virtual work, Hamilton's principle, Lagrange's equation, and Ritz method for discrete approximations.\nModal analysis: eigenanalysis, mode shapes, mode superposition, and complex modes. Nonlinear vibrations: phase\nplane, Poincare, bifurcation plots, and chaos. Stability of the motion: classification of problems, follower loads,\naerodynamic loads, divergence, flutter, pulsating compression, and gyroscopic systems. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE54800",
    "Title": "Mechanical Behavior Of Aerospace Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course serves as an overview for materials behavior for students without a materials\nbackground, including seniors and entry-level graduate students. Materials are at the foundation for all of engineering,\nas evident by the latest products that we design, to the airplanes that we fly, to the latest smartphones. In fact,\nbreakthroughs with material research are often accompanied by rapid advancements in technology. Thus, it is\nparamount for all engineers to have an understanding of the structure and behavior of materials. In this class, we focus\non the structure of materials, the microstructure connection to mechanical properties, and, ultimately, failure\nmechanisms. Materials play an important role in both design and manufacturing, which will be addressed in the\ncontext of components and extreme environments. Of specific interest will be defects within materials, defect\nformation/evolution, and their role in strengthening mechanisms. Material anisotropy, micromechanisms, and elasto-\nplastic properties at the atomic, single-crystal/constituent, and polycrystal-material levels and their use in explaining the\ndeformation and failure characteristics in metals, polymers, and ceramics; failure mechanisms and toughening in\ncomposites; structure and behavior of aerospace materials: metal alloys, ceramic-matrix composites, and fiber-\nreinforced polymer composites. Particular topics will also include: elastic deformation, dislocation mechanics, plastic\ndeformation and strengthening mechanisms, creep, and failure mechanisms; design criteria; special topics. We will\nattempt to have minimal overlap with AAE 55400, Fatigue of Structures and Materials. Therefore we will not cover\nfracture, fatigue, or stress concentrators. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE55000",
    "Title": "Multidisciplinary Design Optimization",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Basics of numerical optimization: problem formulation, conditions of optimality, search direction,\nand step length. Calculus-based techniques for univariate and multivariate optimization. Constrained and unconstrained\noptimization methods. Global optimization methods. Multi-objective optimization: Pareto optimality and approaches.\nRecent multidisciplinary design optimization techniques: approximations, response surface methodology, and\ncollaborative optimization. Applications of various methods and techniques to representative engineering problems,\nculminating in a final project. Ability to solve mathematical problems with MATLAB and IMSL and similar software\nhelpful. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE55200",
    "Title": "Nondestructive Evaluation Of Structures And Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Overview of methods employed for nondestructive evaluation of structures and materials taught in\nthe context of damage tolerant structural analysis. Major inspection topics include: radiography, ultrasonics, eddy\ncurrent, penetrant, magnetic, and visual/optical techniques. Other new emerging inspection techniques also are\ndiscussed. Offered in alternate years. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE55300",
    "Title": "Elasticity In Aerospace Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A basic course in the theory of elasticity with emphasis on understanding the fundamental\nprinciples and solution techniques used in the stress analysis of structures. Cartesian tensors. Governing equations for\nlinear elasticity. Rigorous derivation of beam and plate equations from the three-dimensional elasticity equations.\nTorsion. Thermoelasticity. The stress functions and complex functions approaches to two-dimensional problems.\nEnergy methods and approximate solutions. Three-dimensional problems. Knowledge of differential equations\nassumed. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE55400",
    "Title": "Fatigue Of Structures And Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Development and application of methods for predicting the fatigue life of structural components.\nCharacterization and response of materials to cyclic loading. Fatigue resistant design of aerospace structures. Both\nfatigue crack initiation and crack propagation concepts are discussed. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE55500",
    "Title": "Mechanics Of Composite Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Current and potential applications of composite materials. Review of elasticity of anisotropic\nsolids. Methods for determining mechanical properties of heterogeneous materials. Static and dynamic analyses of\nlaminated composites. Fracture and fatigue of laminates. Reliability, testing, and design of composites. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE55600",
    "Title": "Aeroelasticity",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The study of the effect of aerodynamic forces of flexible aircraft. Static aeroelastic problems;\ncontrol effectiveness; lift effectiveness; divergence. Dynamic aeroelasticity; classical flutter; an introduction to stability\naugmentation with controls. A review of standard and modern numerical solution techniques; the k-method, the British\nor p-k method. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE55800",
    "Title": "Finite Element Methods In Aerospace Structures",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to the use of advanced finite element methods in the calculation of deformation,\nstrain, and stress in aerospace structures. Topics include: 1-D, 2-D, 3-D, and axisymmetric elements, isoperimetric\nelement formulation, convergence, treatment of boundary conditions and constraints. Special topics include stability,\ndynamic analysis, and nonlinear material behavior. Emphasis is on the theoretical knowledge of the finite element\nmethod. Applied experience is gained by solution of aerospace structural analysis problems through use of professional\nsoftware. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE56100",
    "Title": "Introduction To Convex Optimization",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(IE 56100) Introduction to convex analysis, convex optimization problems, algorithms of convex\noptimization and measures of their complexity, and application of convex optimization in aerospace engineering.\nRecognition of convex optimization problems that arise in scientific and engineering applications. Introduction to\nsoftware tools to solve convex optimization problems. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE56400",
    "Title": "Systems Analysis And Synthesis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "State space methods of analysis and design of continuous and discrete-time linear systems.\nCoordinate transformations, Jordan canonical forms, digital control, controllability and observability of continuous and\ndiscrete systems. Liapunov stability analysis. The linear regulator problem of optimal control via Hamilton Jacobi\ntheory. Pole assignment, stabilizability, detectability. State estimation for deterministic models. Minimal order\nobservers. MA 51100 recommended concurrently. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE56500",
    "Title": "Guidance And Control Of Aerospace Vehicles",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Optimal control theory and application to trajectory optimization; flight control synthesis and\nguidance law development; handling qualities; stability augmentation; auto-pilots. Launch vehicle and ballistic missile\nattitude control. AAE 56400 recommended. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE56700",
    "Title": "Introduction To Applied Stochastic Processes",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introductory course in the concept of a discrete and continuous stochastic process based upon\nphysical phenomena that originally gave rise to the specific stochastic models that are studies. Spectral analysis,\nresponse of time invariant systems to noise inputs. Estimation theory, Kalman and Winer filtering. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE56800",
    "Title": "Applied Optimal Control And Estimation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces students to analysis and synthesis methods of optimal controllers and\nestimators for (stochastic) dynamical systems. The topics in this course include a review of probability and stochastic\nprocesses, classical estimation techniques, Pontryagin's maximum principle, dynamic programming. Linear Quadratic\nRegulator problems (LQR), Kalman filter, duality of LQR with Kalman filter, Linear Quadratic Gaussian (LQG), and a\nrange of engineering applications. Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Viscous Flow Theory",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Compressible, laminar boundary layer theory; Buseman and Crocco integrals; skin friction and\nheat transfer. Introduction to turbulent boundary layers and transition phenomena. Advanced boundary layer theory; the\nmethod of inner and outer expansions. Boundary layers with chemical reaction; applications to hypersonic flow and\ncombustion. Prerequisite: AAE 51100. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE61500",
    "Title": "Aeroacoustics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(ME 61500) Quantitative measures of sound (decibel) scales, spectra, energetics of acoustic\nmotions, and measurement techniques. The wave theory of sound (basic equations and properties, sound propagation in\nhomogeneous and inhomogeneous media, one-, two-, and three-dimensional sound fields, and distributed sources).\nEffects of source movement. Aerodynamic noise generation-acoustic analogy (Lighthill's equation and Ffowcs\nWilliams-Hawkins equation). Introduction to Computational Aeroacoustics (CAA). Noise from turbulent shear flows\n(jet noise, cavity noise, and noise from flow over objects). Noise from turbomachinery, propellers, and rotors.\nPrerequisite: AAE 51100 or ME 50900 or ME 51300. Credits: 3.00"
  },

  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE62600",
    "Title": "Turbulence And Turbulence Modeling",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Physical description of turbulence. Reynolds averaged equations. Scaling of basic turbulent flows.\nHomogeneous turbulence, spectra and two-point correlations. Hierarchy of turbulence models, including zero-, one-,\nand two-equation models, Reynolds stress models, large eddy simulations, and direct numerical simulations. Additional\ntopics, such as compressibility effects on turbulence and probability density function methods, as time allows.\nPrerequisite: AAE 51100. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "AAE63200",
    "Title": "Advanced Orbital Dynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Discussion of more advanced concepts in astrodynamics. Includes fundamental theories from\ncelestial mechanics, as well as trajectory determination and perturbation analysis with application to the motion of\nEarth-orbiting and interplanetary spacecraft. Assumes experience with the two-body problem. Offered in alternate\nyears. Prerequisite: AAE 50700, AAE 53200. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "AAE64600",
    "Title": "Elastic Wave Propagation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Elastic wave propagation in rods, beams, and plates. Wave motion in semi-infinite bodies;\nRayleigh, Lamb and Love waves. Pochhammer-Chree theory for rods. General properties of dispersive waves and\napproximation techniques. Impact. Wave front and ray methods. Introduction to wave propagation in anelastic and\nnonhomogenous media, and to large amplitude and shock waves. Prerequisite: AAE 55300 or ME 56300. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE64800",
    "Title": "Modeling Damage And Strengthening Mechanisms In Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The usage of materials is the backbone of engineering practice. Yet, advances in materials have\nstagnated due to overly conservative approaches, trial-and-error testing, and long qualification times. Material\nmodeling offers tremendous opportunities to address these issues. This class offers advanced modeling strategies at the\nintersection of mechanics and materials science for both polycrystalline and composite materials. The course topics are\ndefined as follows: First, advanced micromechanics analysis of modern engineering materials with emphasis on\nrelating elastic microstructural phenomena to the mechanics of material behavior, via the Eshelby inclusion problem\nand its application to fiber reinforced composites. Second, classical plasticity is summarized via phenomenological and\nmathematical formulation of the constitutive laws, including yielding, yield surface; von Mises, Tresca yield criteria;\nDrucker's stability postulate; strain or work hardening, normality rule, perfect plasticity, and stress-strain law. Third,\ncrystal plasticity is discussed, specifically physical and mathematical foundation for plasticity in crystalline materials,\nwith a detailed description of the Bishop and Hill implementation of the Taylor model for deformation of polycrystals.\nLastly, concepts of dislocations leading to strengthening mechanisms in metals are discussed: (i) by studying the\nanisotropy of material and elastoplastic properties at crystal level, microstructural basis for deformation in metals,\npolymers, and ceramics and (ii) failure mechanisms and toughening in metals, with primary emphasis on work/strain\nhardening, solid solution hardening, precipitate hardening, and grain boundaries. The course will be comprised of three\nprojects, where the student chooses the topic of the third and final project. Prerequisite: AAE 55300 or\nequivalent. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE65400",
    "Title": "Fracture Mechanics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Methods of stress analysis in elastic media containing cracks. Fracture criteria. The strain energy\nrelease rate and J-integral. Crack tip plasticity. Interface cracks. Cracks in anisotropic solids. Bending of cracked plates.\nDynamic crack propagation. Prerequisite: AAE 55300. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE66600",
    "Title": "Nonlinear Dynamics, Systems, And Control",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Fundamental concepts and tools that are useful in the analysis of nonlinear systems and in the\ndesign of controllers and estimators for such systems. Results are illustrated by, and applied to, aerospace/mechanical\nsystems. Prerequisite: AAE 56400. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE66800",
    "Title": "Hybrid Systems: Theory And Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Hybrid systems are dynamical systems with both continuous and discrete dynamics and they are\nfinding increasing applications in a variety of engineering fields, even in scientific fields such as biological systems.\nThis course will present the recent advances in modeling, analysis, control, and verification of hybrid systems. Topics\ncovered in this course include the following aspects of hybrid systems: continuous-time and discrete-event models;\nreachability analysis; safety specifications and model checking; optimal control and estimation of hybrid systems;\nstability analysis and verification tools; stochastic hybrid systems; numerical simulations; and a range of engineering\napplications. Prerequisites: AAE 56400. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AAE67500",
    "Title": "Advanced Signals And Systems For Satellite Navigation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Fundamental theory of ranging signal design. Generation of pseudorandom noise. Methods for\ndetecting, tracking, and estimating delay using ranging signals. Probability of detection, probability of false alarm, and\ntracking threshold derived from a stochastic signal model. Models for multiple access, quantization, clock and\nmultipath errors. Examples drawn from present-day Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS). Prerequisites: ECE\n60000, AAE 56700, or equivalent (Random Variables and Stochastic Processes). Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ABE20100",
    "Title": "Thermodynamics In Biological Systems I",
    "CreditHours": 4.0,
    "Description": "Thermodynamic principles associated with biological systems and processing of biological\nmaterials. Emphasis on the first law of thermodynamics. Fundamentals of steady-state mass and energy balances for\nreacting and non-reacting processes including multiple unit operations emphasizing living systems and bioprocessing.\nApplications of the first law conservation of energy to biological systems, energy conversion systems, and the\nenvironmental impacts of energy production. Development of engineering problem solving skills via MathCad and\nMatLab software. Laboratory emphasizes combining technical engineering skills with professional skill development\nthrough computer and laboratory exercises including two extensive projects that result in a biological product\ndesign. Credits: 4.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ABE20200",
    "Title": "Thermodynamics In Biological Systems II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Thermodynamic principles and their applications to biochemical and biological systems with\nemphasis on the second law of thermodynamics and use of molecular interpretations of energies and entropies. Concept\nof entropy balances and process efficiency. Free energy and chemical equilibrium. Equilibrium between phases,\ncolligative properties, binding of ligands and formation of biological membrances. Molecular motion and transport\nproperties and their application in biochemical analytical methods. Development of physical chemical problem solving\nskills using MathCad and MatLab software.     "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Fluid statics, Newton's law of viscosity, shell momentum balances, equations of continuity and\nmotion, one dimensional flow problems, flow through porous media, velocity distributions with more than one\nindependent variable, two dimensional flow through a channel, stream function, velocity potential, dimensional\nanalysis, boundary layer, turbulent flow, Reynolds stress, form and skin friction, application of macroscopic\nmomentum and mechanical energy balances to engineering problems.   {
    "Course": "ABE30800",
    "Title": "Heat And Mass Transfer In Food And Biological Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Principles of transport of energy and mass. Mechanisms of heat transfer, heat conduction, heat\nconvection and heat radiation. Development of applications using macroscopic and microscopic balances of energy.\nApplication of thermal energy balances and Fourier's Law to describe steady state and transient conduction applications\nincluding heat generation. Effect of the geometry on these processes. Basic principles of design of heat transfer\nequipment and its operation. Application of species mass balances and Fick's Law to steady state and transient\ndiffusion problems. Effect of geometry on these processes. Analogies between transport of momentum, heat and mass\napplications to the solution of practical problems in the Food Process and Biological Engineering fields. Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Drug Development",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,

The course concludes with a brief review of international regulatory\nissues and patents. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "ABE51500",
    "Title": "Molecular Basis Of Manufacturing",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This advanced course addresses important Chemistry Manufacturing and Control (CMC) issues\nrelated to manufacturing and quality by design. The course provides important information on strategies for quality by\ndesign, manufacturing strategies for early development, the best approaches to analyzing data, and strategies for\nreporting the information to the FDA. This course will also focus on product design and processing. Using product and\nprocess design helps achieve quality by design (QbD), strong development reports, excellent regulatory submissions\nand allows continuous improvement.   {
    "Course": "ABE52200",
    "Title": "Ecohydrology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Ecohydrology links hydrological and ecological processes at various spatiotemporal scales and is\nconsidered to be one of the most exciting frontiers of the future. Hydrological processes in individual ecosystems and\nthe role of water in linking the myriad components of the landscape will be explored in this three-credit course.\nInteractions between hydrological and biological processes and factors that regulate and shape these interactions will be\ncovered. The ecohydrology principles covered will include integration of water and biota at the catchment scale,\nnutrient transport and cycling, modeling ecohydrologic processes, and quantification of ecosystem services.\nRecommended: a prior course in hydrology. Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Offers students in environmental and natural resources engineering programs an understanding of\nthe hydrological processes and related design skills.     "Title": "Life Of A Faculty Entrepreneur: Discovery, Delivery, Translation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(TLI 62600) The course is designed to introduce graduate students and faculty mentors to the\nintellectual, financial, and management processes associated with translating research into tangible products through\nuniversity initiated, early-stage commercialization (start-up) activities. Lectures will present case studies of\ntechnologies and pathways to commercialization. Guest speakers will illustrate the start-up process through real-world\nexperience, and will also address approaches for managing entrepreneurial activities, intellectual property and conflicts\nof interest in a university environment. Permission of Instructor required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ABE62700",
    "Title": "Colloidal Phenomena In Bioprocessing",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The structure, stability, and rheology of biological dispersions, emulsions, and foams are explained\nin terms of the principles of electrostatics, hydrodynamics, thermodynamics, and statistical mechanics. Additional\ntopics include colloidal phenomena in downstream bioprocessing, as well as colloidal aspects of some food systems.\nPrerequisite: Thermodynamics and physical chemistry. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ABE65100",
    "Title": "Environmental Informatics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will educate students in the use, manipulation and analysis of environmental data by\nintroducing them to scripting languages (e.g. c-shell, python), data types (e.g. ASCII, binary, NetCDF), databases (e.g.\nXML, DBF) and data visualization software (e.g. GMT, ArcMap) as well as techniques for checking data quality,\nworking with missing data, and handling large diverse sources of time series and spatial data. Students will manipulate,\ncheck and insert data from a variety of sources, use that data as input to distributed hydrologic model, analyze model\noutput and learn methods for properly documenting their data use (creation of metadata) and long-term archival storage\nof those data. Skills learned should be applicable to most computer operating systems, but the majority of work for this\nclass will be done within the Unix/Linux environment. Students taking this course should have experience with one or"

    "Course": "AGEC20300",
    "Title": "Introductory Microeconomics For Food And Agribusiness",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the application of microeconomics as used by farms and agribusiness firms.\nThe behavior of individual firms is evaluated as price and output are determined in various market structures (pure\ncompetition, pure monopoly, monopolistic competition, and oligopoly).     "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to introduce students to issues and problems related to international\neconomic development.     "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course investigates the major drivers of global agricultural and environmental change\nassociated with the global farm and food system.   {
    "Course": "AGEC60500",
    "Title": "Agricultural Markets And Price Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Agricultural markets are multi-faceted, having been studied using a wide range of analytical tools.\nThis graduate-level course emphasizes charactering demand and supply of agricultural markets and understanding\nforces that determine commodity and food prices. It also aims to cover a set of economic studies of prices and assist\nstudents in applying theoretical frameworks and time-series econometrics to empirical analysis of agricultural prices. In\naddition to studying prices in perfectly competitive markets, the first half of the course highlights several classic\nmodels of consumer demand and agricultural supply, prices under imperfect competition, price spreads (marketing\nmargins), and the economics of information. The second half of the course focuses on empirical price analysis. Popular\ntime-series econometric tools are introduced to study price relationships over space and time, price discovery\nmechanisms, and functions of futures markets. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AGEC60800",
    "Title": "Benefit-Cost Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Principles and practice for analysis of the benefits and costs of public investments. Topics include\nmeasures of project worth, choice of the discount rate, analysis of projects with multiple objectives and purposes,\nidentifying and quantifying benefits and costs, applications of consumer and producer surplus in project analysis,\ntreatment of risk and uncertainty, and shadow pricing techniques for project evaluation in developing counties.\nConcurrent Prerequisite: AGEC 60400; a graduate course in microeconomic theory. Credits: 2.00"

    "Course": "AGEC61900",
    "Title": "Applied Microeconomic Theory",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Provides students with the capability to apply microeconomic theory and econometrics to analyses\nof economic issues and problems. Students will work through applied producer/consumer problems to gain experience\nin the uses of econometric estimation. Topics include: primal-dual approaches, direct and indirect functions, flexible\nfunctional forms, static optimization, separability and aggregation, risk and expectations, dynamics and demographics.\nExamples are drawn from both consumer and producer applications.   {
    "Course": "AGEC63000",
    "Title": "Urban And Regional Economics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The literature discussed in this urban and regional economics course covers theoretical texts,\nconceptual as well as statistical, and empirical applications in order to introduce the student to the economist's view on\nspatial variation in economic outcomes. This ranges from coverage of the theory of industrial location choice, through\ntheoretical and empirical analysis of the spatial distribution of economic activities (agglomeration theory, industrial\nclusters, central place theory), to theoretical and empirical explanations for the spatial structure of cities, the working of\nregional labor markets and migration. The course covers various empirical tools utilized in spatial data analysis (spatial\neconometrics) and modeling of regional economies and their interrelations (interregional input-output analysis).\nPrerequisites: AGEC 20300 or ECON 34000 or ECON 51100. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AGEC63100",
    "Title": "The Theory And Practice Of Spatial Econometrics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course deals with the analysis of spatial data and centers on both exploratory tools developed\nin spatial statistics and GIScience, as well as on econometric models that have been the main focus in spatial\neconometrics. During the course, the theoretical basis for the analysis of spatial data and spatial models will be\ncovered. This theoretical angle will be combined with ample opportunities to acquire hands-on experience in the\nanalysis of spatial data. To the effect, up-to-date software, such as GeoDa, R, Stata, and Matlab will be used. A good\nworking knowledge of basic statistics and regression techniques is needed. Prior experience with GIS is helpful but not\nrequired. Prerequisites: AGEC 45100 or AGEC 65000 or ECON 67100 or STAT 41700 or STAT 51200 or STAT\n51700. Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "AGEC64300",
    "Title": "Theory Of Economic Development",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The economic theories behind the predominant approaches to economic development are\nreviewed. Both the sources of growth and problems in the development process are stressed. Emphasis is on the\nanalysis and evolution of the models supporting the different approaches and the empirical analysis leading to changes\nin the paradigms. The role of agriculture in the economic development process is one of the topics. Other important\nissues are technological change, income distribution, structural adjustment, and the debt problem. Prerequisite: ECON\n51100, ECON 51200. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "AGEC65000",
    "Title": "Application Of Quantitative Analysis: Econometrics I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Brief presentation of probability concepts, mathematical expectation, probability density and\ndistribution functions as background for studying principles of economic model construction. Emphasis is on\neconometric single equation models, principles of estimation, the general linear model, tests of hypothesis, confidence\ninterval estimation, and special topics such as errors in the variables, multicollinearity, dummy variables, hetero-\nscedasticity, autocorrelation and prediction problems. Prerequisite: STAT 51100; ECON 51100 or ECON 60700,\nmatrix algebra. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AGEC65100",
    "Title": "Application Of Quantitative Analysis: Econometrics II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Emphasis is on using advanced econometric techniques. The course covers use of computer\nsoftware and interpretation and reporting of econometric results. The first part of the course includes general\neconometric concepts, such as least squares and maximum likelihood estimation, desirable statistical properties,\nassumptions of the classical linear regression model, Monte Carlo methods, nested and non-nested hypothesis tests.\nLater, more specialized topics are covered, including multiple equation models, simultaneous equation models, limited\ndependent variable models, and other topics that are deemed relevant. Prerequisite: AGEC 65000. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AGEC65200",
    "Title": "Application Of Quantitative Analysis: Mathematical Programming",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Recent literature on the theory and application of mathematical programming and agricultural\nmodeling. Model building and analysis techniques with focus on matching solution methods to problems. Prerequisite:\nAGEC 55200, ECON 61200; a course in matrix algebra. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AGEC65400",
    "Title": "Economic Dynamics",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Focuses on the application of the tools of dynamic optimization to problems in economics. Covers\ncontinuous-time and discrete-time dynamic optimization techniques, including the calculus of variations, optimal\ncontrol theory, and dynamic programming. Applications are drawn from a range of problems in microeconomics and\nmacroeconomics, including current topics in agricultural economics, natural resource economics, and investment\ntheory. Course meets weeks 1 - 10. Prerequisite: AGEC 65200, ECON 60700. Credits: 2.00"

    "Title": "Applied Economic Time Series Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to improve students' abilities to estimate and interpret time series models.\nThe course begins with univariate models and progresses to multivariate analysis. Mastery\nof applied statistics, calculus, and microeconomic theory at the Masters level or higher is desirable. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ASEC43120",
    "Title": "Evaluating International Engagement Methods",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Designed for students who have just returned from the Engagement Methods for Int'l Food\nSecurity course or have previous experience working with our partners. In order to 1) fully comprehend the impact of\nthe experience and 2) foster true long-term relationships with and service to our partners, it is required to work on our\nprojects when we return. Matt McGregor, Former Exec. Dir. of Timmy Global Health, told us that \"It's not really about\nthe trip\". It is essential that we accomplish: 1) Closure of trip experiences with partners and contacts - thank you's and\ncomplete follow-up; 2) Reflection of Purdue student experiences and personal goals/follow-up actions; 3) Promotion of\nfood insecurity realities and opportunities for support; and 4) Planning, recommendations, and promotion of future\nservice learning courses.   {
    "Course": "ASEC58500",
    "Title": "Science Communication",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course utilizes foundational research and commentary from scholars to track the evolution of\nmedia and our ability as scientists to understand and effectively communicate these issues to a non-science audience.\nScience and technology are evolving faster than societies ability to understand, assimilate, and make policies to address\nthese increasingly complex issues. As a result, controversies arise over issues such as climate change, forest\nmanagement, genetically modified foods, energy choices, genetic engineering, nanotechnology, water management,\nand agricultural practices, etc. This course covers the range of issues in the field of science communication including:\nthe nature of science, how to translate evidence for a lay audience, media practices, reporting and qualifying\nuncertainty, human psychology and belief systems, information processing, and the most current research for\nmessaging science. We will work together to examine the foundational scholarly literature in this area and how it is/ or\nis not reflected in construction of popular media. You will use this knowledge to construct both compelling oral science\nnarratives, and a science story for popular consumption. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ASEC63000",
    "Title": "Theories Of Learning And Development",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "&nbsp; The goal of this course is to introduce students to a variety of theoretical perspectives of\nlearning and development and how they may be used in both formal, informal and non-formal educational settings.\nThis goal will be achieved through students' analysis of key concepts, assumptions, propositions and principles of four\ntheoretical areas: (1) Foundational Learning Theory, (2) Student Development Theory, (3) Career & Workforce\nDevelopment Theory and (4) Youth Development & Experiential Learning Theory. This course will also build on\nstudents' prior exposure to behaviorist, cognitive, and constructivist approaches of learning and development. In sum,\nmany of the theories discussed in this course will provide students with a greater understanding of human thought and\nbehavior that will help them become more effective educators, researchers and practitioners. Permission of instructor\nrequired.&nbsp;Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "ASEC68100",
    "Title": "Research Design For Social Scientists",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The goal of the course is to examine social science theories and research designs in the contexts of\nagricultural and natural resources education, communication and engagement. Students will develop understanding of\nthe chain of reasoning and create a research design to study a problem of interest. Students will apply the concepts they\nlearned in a research methods course by critiquing research manuscripts and creating a rationale for a research\nproposal. After taking the course, students should have gained understanding of how research designs are thoughtfully\nand argumentatively justified to study a researchable problem in informal, non-formal, and formal educational contexts\nand other social science contexts.     "Title": "Communicating Across Culture",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will provide students with an opportunity to understand their place in a multicultural,\nmultiethnic, multinational country, the United States. It is designed to provide an academic overview of the field of\nmulticultural education as it evolved to this day. The course will offer an introductory overview of the many\ndifferences that exist within all human beings. Because the diversity among individuals is endless, we cannot study all\ndifferences, but will study a sampling such as race, ethnicity, gender identity, age, social class, disability, learning\nstyles, and religion/spiritual orientation. Issues of poverty, language, and social justice may also be examined in\nrelationship to the above major areas of emphasis. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "AGRY12000",
    "Title": "Water And Food Security",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "General science introduction to global and regional water resources issues, especially with respect\nto food security. It will address the role of water in agriculture throughout the world and agriculture's impact on water\nresources. With\nthis background, they will explore key issues relating to water scarcity and balancing agricultural and urban demands\nfor water, water quality and soil salinization, water footprints of food and the use of virtual water embedded in food to\noffset national water deficits, regulation and roles science and policy in solving water problems.     "Course": "AGRY48500",
    "Title": "Precision Crop Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An experiential lecture, discussion and field laboratory course for graduating seniors majoring in\nAgronomy. Analysis of multi-layer digital georeferenced crop data is used to inform the development and evaluation\nof zone-specific agronomic input prescriptions. Variables include factors affecting soil productivity, soil fertility and N\nmanagement (including emerging sensor and crop modeling technologies). Prescriptions for variable crop genetics and\nseeding rates are also discussed. Sound agronomic use of emerging technologies such as real time soil moisture,\norganic matter, temperature and moisture sensing to affect variable seeding depth, rate and precision are included. May\nbe used in combination with AGRY 49800 to meet the Agronomy undergraduate capstone requirement; will also meet\nthe GIS/GPS requirement in Agronomy plans of study. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(ANSC 51100) Basic concepts of population genetics.   {
    "Course": "ASL36100",
    "Title": "The Structure Of American Sign Language I: Phonology And\nMorphology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Linguistic study of ASL, including the following: phonological features of individual signs (hand\nshape, orientation, location, movement) and how those features shift when placed in a stream of signs; morphological\nfeatures of signs, including compounding and lexicalization of fingerspelled words; grammar, focusing on typical word\norders found in ASL sentences; meaning of signs and how those meanings have shifted over time (as well as how those\nmeanings shift for particular dialects); and typical pragmatic features of conversation in ASL. Knowledge of ASL is\nrequired. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ASL36200",
    "Title": "The Structure Of American Sign Language II: Syntax, Semantics And\nLanguage Use",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces students who already have prior knowledge of linguistics (e.g., phonetics,\nphonology, and morphology) to three areas of study in linguistics: Syntax, Semantics, and language use. Linguistic\nstudy of ASL, including the following: Syntax includes units on basic sentence types, lexical categories, word order,\ntime and aspect, verbs, and the function of the spaces. Semantics includes the meanings of individual signs and\nsentences. Language in Use includes Black ASL, Variation and Historical Change. Bilingualism and language\nacquisition will be also covered. ASL Discourse has the ways that signed conversations among deaf people differ from\nspeaking conversation of hearing people, why these differences exist, and why they are culturally important.\nKnowledge of ASL is required. Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "AMST10100",
    "Title": "America And The World",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course examines the evolution of American culture as the United States transitioned from a\nrelatively isolated country at the end of the 19th century to an active shaper of a global community by the 21st century.\nWe will examine ways in which American Culture shaped and was shaped by international relationships that transcend\nnation states. We will explore reactions to, and the results of, the spread of American culture both inside and outside\nthe United States. By studying traditional cultural forms like art, music, design, literature, film, and technology the\ncourse will build a foundation from which to understand the configuration of American culture. Yet the course will also\nemphasize American culture expression, that in the forms of television, advertising, sport, cartoons, social media, video\ngames, fashion, food, drugs, and automobiles, have transcended the geographical boundaries of the United States to\nengage in global interplays of material cultural exchange. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AMST20100",
    "Title": "Interpreting America",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of American culture, history, and society in its national\nand global contexts. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AMST21000",
    "Title": "Sport In American Culture",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course engages critical questions regarding sport and its role in American culture. It examines\nthe ways sport serves as a key site for the study of larger social issues and social problems, including how race, gender,\nsocial class and other social locations are simultaneously reproduced and challenged in and through sport. The course\nalso explores the relationships between sport and other major social institutions, such as the economy, education,\npolitics, and media. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AMST25000",
    "Title": "An Introduction To American Protest Movements: What Are They?\nWhat Can They Do? How Can We Make One?",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course, we will study the reasons people in the United States have historically decided to\ncreate social movements, tactics and strategies they use to make and sustain those movements, obstacles to their\nsuccess, and ways of judging their victories. The course will draw on scholarship on social movements from various\nfields, especially the field of American Studies. Because social movements are created by ordinary people, we will use\na variety of sources they leave behind: speeches, testimonials, pamphlets, historical accounts, autobiographies,\nmanifestos. We will also explore scholarship on social movements to try to understand how best to record and analyze\nthe work social movements do. The course seeks to provide students an understanding of the role of protest movements\nin American history. Permission of instructor required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AMST31000",
    "Title": "Invention, Innovation, And Design",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course focuses on the various ways that invention, innovation, and design shape the modern\nworld. We will investigate the forms, uses, and meanings of a diverse set of objects, networks, and systems that\ninfluence the ways we live. We will explore these ideas through the concepts of consumption, waste, and \"smart\" to\ngain a deeper understanding of how material infrastructures influence human existence. This project-based course will\nuse readings, discussions, and critical reflections to inform a series of hands-on projects to understand our roles as\ndesigners, creators, and users of science, technology, and material culture. Permission of instructor required. Credits:\n3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AMST32000",
    "Title": "Understanding The National Football League",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course counters the cultural myth that sports are \"simply a form of entertainment\" or \"an\nescape from reality\" and takes seriously the notion that sports matter as a social, cultural, and political force. Students\nwill use academically informed inquiry and investigation to examine broader cultural dynamics through a critical\nexamination of the National Football League. Course topics include how the NFL shapes social identities including\nrace, gender, sexuality, and American identity, the connection between football and militarism, the relationship\nbetween the NFL and commercialism, the role the NFL plays in the triad of men's violence, among other\ntopics. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AMST32500",
    "Title": "Sports, Technology, And Innovation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course examines how science, technology, engineering, and data analysis reshape sports.\nTraditionally, sports have been understood as competitions between humans. However, recent technoscientific\ndevelopments have altered this arrangement and have changed the ways sports are played. We have reached a place\nwhere heated competitions not only take place on the fields of play, but also within scientific and engineering\nlaboratories. The fundamental question this project-based course will address is: how will new and emerging scientific\nknowledge and technological innovations transform sports? We will explore topics ranging from football, baseball,\nbasketball, and soccer, to e-sports, fantasy sports, and sports analytics. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AMST33000",
    "Title": "American Car Culture",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The automobile has become one of the most influential technologies of the 20th century, and\ncontinues to impact American life in the 21st. This course will examine the immense social, political, technological,\nand environmental impacts of the car on American culture; and take an interdisciplinary approach to the understanding\nthe automobile industry, its production systems, its marketing strategies, and the way automobiles reflect the changing\nlandscapes of consumer tastes and values over time. Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "American Studies Interdisciplinary Project",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Students will conduct independent research under faculty supervision towards completion of the\nSpecial Field examination for the Ph.D. degree. The project should be an extended, original research essay, based upon\ninterdisciplinary research. The project should aim to produce original findings on a clearly defined topic or problem. In\naddition to the research and essay, students must produce a statement of methodology in which they explain their\nchoice of sources and how their project contributes to the field of American Studies.     "Course": "AMST60400",
    "Title": "Transnational American Studies",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "What does the term transnational mean? How is the term defined, practiced, and studied in\ndifferent fields? How does one take a transnational perspective, or examine the transnational variable? This course will\ndraw from various fields (sociology, history, anthropology, ethnic studies, etc.) to explore contemporary scholarship on\ntransnationalism in theory and in practice. Specifically, we will examine scholarship that either, 1) utilizes the\ntransnational perspective in understanding history, the globe, and human behavior/interactions, or 2) utilizes\ntransnational behaviors/ties as a variable to measurement adaptation. Materials in this course will examine - through the\nlens of race, ethnicity, class, gender, and sexuality - individual and comparative transnational case studies related to the\nAmericas, Africa, Asia, and Europe. This is a graduate seminar, and your active participation in discussions is\nmandatory. You will be asked to lead four seminar discussions on selected topics from the required readings, write\nthree memos, and submit an extended book review. Permission of instructor required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AMST60500",
    "Title": "Theory And American Culture",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an overview of key foundational texts in social and cultural theory, with a\nfocus on theories of import to scholars in American Studies and related fields. We will explore the various types of\ntheory, examining its internal logic, implications, and critiques. Consider this a brief introduction, meant to give you a\ngeneral feel for the range and sophistication of available theories in American Studies. Moreover, as the \"Cultural\nPolitics\" website observes, \"Recent theory has reminded us that origin stories are powerful determining forces, and thus\nthese tales of the growth and development of the discipline should be read both for what they say and for what they\nmay leave out, read both for their truths and their partialities.\" Similarly, the course syllabus itself creates a particular\nnarrative regarding the development of the discipline. As such, students are encouraged to consider the syllabus\nthrough this perspective. Credits: 3.00"

Includes discussions of current research concerning molecular mechanisms of fertilization, egg\nactivation, early development, and endocrine factors controlling cell growth, differentiation, and tissue formation.\nExperimental approaches utilized for developmental and growth biology research are discussed. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ANTH21500",
    "Title": "Introduction To Forensic Anthropology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to forensic anthropology, the science that utilizes methods from skeletal biology and\narchaeology as tools in human identification in a medico-legal context. This course introduces students to methods used\nto recover and positively identify human remains, and to evaluate trauma and taphonomy in medico-legal situations.\nTopics include an overview of historical and current developments in the field. Students will develop a comprehensive\nunderstanding of the sequential order of applied work from the search for forensic scenes through the recovery of\nremains, and skeletal analysis in the laboratory. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ANTH25400",
    "Title": "Archaeological Hoaxes, Myths And Frauds",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course examines why the ancient past inspires so many theories about aliens, dark\nconspiracies, lost civilizations, and apocalyptic predictions. Topics include the popularity of pseudoscientific theories\nin American culture and the historical contexts in which common pseudoscientific ideas have emerged; why they\npersist in the face of archaeological evidence; and the role of pseudo-archaeology in the growing antagonism toward\nscientific expertise. Through an understanding of datasets and methods archaeologists use to evaluate claims about the\npast, the course goes beyond debunking ancient aliens and Atlantis to develop important critical thinking skills to\nevaluate evidence and recognize pseudo-scientific arguments in the media. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ANTH25600",
    "Title": "Archaeology Of Beer",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Alcoholic beverages are an important aspect of foodways, the cultural practices and values\nsurrounding food and drink. This course provides an overview of the ancient origins of beer and other alcoholic\nbeverages globally, and examines the cultural context and social role of these innovations through a combination of\narchaeology, material culture studies, historical texts, and ethnography. In addition to examining archaeological case\nstudies of the production and consumption of beer and other alcoholic beverages, topics to be covered include:\nevolution of brewing and fermenting technology, biology and chemistry of brewing and fermentation, residue and\nmaterials analysis, origins of agriculture, emergence of social complexity, sexual division of labor, social identity\n(gender, class, ethnicity), and recent trends in production and consumption. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

It is designed for students who intend\nto focus in an anthropological discipline. It would also benefit a variety of students interested in 1) quantitative science\nliteracy and planning for graduate work, 2) joining the workforce and becoming part of the educated citizenry.   {
    "Course": "ANTH32000",
    "Title": "Ancient States And Empires",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Why did some small-scale societies develop into complex chiefdoms, states, and empires while\nothers did not? How did ancient societies adapt in the face of social conflict and environmental challenges? What\nlessons can we learn from resilience or collapse of states in the ancient past? This course compares the political, social,\necological, contexts of the rise and fall of early complex societies, from densely populated hunter-gatherers in North\nAmerica to the world's major ancient civilizations in Mesoamerica, the Andes, Nile Valley, Mesopotamia, Indus\nValley, and China. We will also explore how societies responded to 'grand challenges' in antiquity such as climate\nvariability, food insecurity, global-intercultural interaction, and what modern lessons we might derive from their\nsuccesses and failures. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "ARAB12100",
    "Title": "Qur'anic Arabic Level I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduces students with knowledge of the Arabic alphabet and elementary Arabic word structure\nto the basic elements of Qur'anic Arabic and provides them with foundational knowledge of classical Arabic lexicon\nand grammar. Students will gain insights into the organizational structure of different words and short phrases as they\nexplore the nature of Qur'anic Arabic, its diction, morphology and vocabulary that are crucial for understanding the\ntext. In this course, students will also expand their vocabulary as they work through exercises focusing on identifying\nthe importance of rendering sounds for correct reading, recitation and morphology of different words through sample\nexcerpts from short chapters of the Qur'an. Students can take this course for language credit to meet course\nrequirements in all fields that require a language. Permission of instructor required.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "ARAB33000",
    "Title": "The Middle East On Film",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course offers an introduction to films produced in the Middle East and on Middle Eastern\nCultures. In this class, we will view films from the Arab world, including North Africa, and the large Middle Eastern\nregion. Parallel to film screening, students will read critical and analytical material that provide background as well as\ncommentary and analysis of cultural and historical contexts on content of films and their making. The course will\nexamine a series of topics such as identity politics, religious affiliation, gender, immigration, belonging, homeland and\nexile. We will also situate the films within the aesthetic traditions of production and reception and analyze how they\nprovide critical perspectives and insights in central issues in the cultures of Middle Eastern cultures. The overarching\ngoal of the class is to provide students with a solid understanding of the function of cinema and films in representation\nof the evolution and transformation of the cultures and societies of the region and the issues central to how communal\nand individual identities in the Middle Eastern region are shaped. The class will also equip the students with skills to\nanalyze meaning making and the role of technical aspects such as cinematography, body language, script, setting and\nacting in the creation of characters. All films will be screened with English subtitles. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

    "Course": "ASTR36300",
    "Title": "The Solar System",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is intended for students in science or engineering.   },
  {
    "Course": "ASTR36400",
    "Title": "Stars And Galaxies",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is intended for students in Science or Engineering. This is the second of a two-\nsemester introductory sequence on astronomy and astrophysics, although it is designed to be a standalone course. It is\nintended mainly for Science and Engineering majors who are comfortable with calculus-based contents. The course\nprovides an overview on the formation and evolution of stars, galaxies, and clusters of galaxies. Selected topics that are\ncovered in more detail include stellar structure and atmosphere, properties of black holes, neutron stars, and white\ndwarfs, galactic dynamics, and dark matter in galaxies and clusters of galaxies. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ASTR37000",
    "Title": "Cosmology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Intended for science and engineering majors. Basic physics and math knowledge will be assumed.\nThe picture of how the Universe came to be and how it has evolved has recently come into sharp focus. This progress is\nthe result of improved observational techniques that have resulted in high resolution images of very distant galaxies, a\nmore accurate mapping of the Large Scale Structure of the Universe or the high resolution picture of the young\nuniverse provided by Cosmic Microwave Background observations. We will present a historical perspective of how\nideas and data have shaped Cosmology through the centuries. In addition, we will review the theoretical models that are\nin agreement with the current observations. Our goal will be to provide the students with a broad overview of the\ncurrent research in Cosmology with an eye toward stimulating the students curiosity about the many questions still\nawaiting answers in this field. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ASTR56000",
    "Title": "Stellar Evolution",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(PHYS 56000) Observational basis of astrophysics; formation of galaxies and stars; evolution of\nstars; white dwarfs, supernovae and neutron stars, pulsars, quasars, black holes; cosmic rays, their origin and\nacceleration; radio astronomy, radio galaxies; the H-21 cm line and the 3mK blackbody radiation; gravitational\nradiation; X-ray and g-ray astronomy; cosmology; space physics, magnetosphere, and solar wind. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "AT10300",
    "Title": "Aerospace Vehicle Propulsion And Tracking Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is an introduction to propulsion systems used in aerospace vehicles. The student will\nlearn terminology, component parts, and operational theory of propulsion systems. Course topics covered are\nreciprocating and turbine engine operation theory as well as rocket propulsion systems. including electrical, fuel, fire,\nignition and lubrication. Operational and regulatory fuel requirements are discussed. Emerging technologies and\nenvironmental practices will be explored. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "AT10600",
    "Title": "Basic Aircraft Science",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introduction to federal regulatory systems and associated publications. Includes aircraft\nnomenclature, theory of flight, and fundamentals of the aviation industry. Introduces weight and balance procedures.\nPermission of department required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AT10901",
    "Title": "Introduction To Unmanned Aerial System Operations",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will provide students the aeronautical knowledge required to operate a small UAS in\nthe National Airspace. Students are introduced to various aspects of unmanned aviation operations, which includes\nUAS system types and components, regulations and operational approvals, and indoctrination to the civil and\ncommercial applications of UAS. Through the use of UAS simulation technology, students will develop basic small\nUAS flight skills and successfully complete various UAS operational scenarios. Upon successful completion of the\ncourse students will be prepared to obtain a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Remote Pilot Certificate with a\nSmall UAS Rating. Permission of department required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AT11600",
    "Title": "Aircraft Science For Engineering Technology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Required for AET. This course is an introduction to theory of flight, aircraft nomenclature, aircraft\nconfigurations, high speed flight, and helicopter configurations and rotor dynamics. Covers lift/drag and concepts for"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AT11901",
    "Title": "Unmanned Aerial Systems: Safety And Risk Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course discusses the fundamental concepts of Safety and Risk Management and their\napplication to UAS operations. The course will provide insight into strategies for developing and implementing a\nformal safety management system (SMS) that effectively supports an organization's UAS operations. In addition,\nstudents will gain an understanding of ethical decision making and its relationship to safety. Laboratory exercises\nprovide students practical application of this knowledge to various UAS operational scenarios, which includes utilizing\nSMS principles in assessing risks and developing appropriate mitigations. Permission of department required. Credits:\n3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AT12700",
    "Title": "Publications Records And Regulations",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Required for AET. This course provides students with the concepts, and information to understand\nthe regulations and publications specific to aviation and aerospace vehicle repair and maintenance. The privileges and\nlimitations of the 14 CFR Part 65 airmen certificates are covered, as well as the regulations governing repair facilities\nand repair stations. The specific forms and records, and the proper disposition of those records are covered. In addition,\naircraft technical drawings and prints are examined and the student is to develop the ability to read and comprehend\naircraft drawings, as well as make drawings/sketches for vehicle repair and/or alteration. Precision measuring\nequipment is covered as is the hardware specific to aviation and aerospace. Inspection procedures and conformity\nchecks are covered. Engine run up operations for inspection purpose are covered. This course teaches topics in the\ncurriculum required by 14 CFR Part 147 as outlined in the School of Aviation and Transportation Technology's Part\n147 Operations Manual approved by the FAA, and provides specific knowledge and skills needed for FAA certification\nexaminations. Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

  {
    "Course": "AT54300",
    "Title": "Contemporary Issues In Airport & Airline Finance",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an overview of aviation financial management and is intended for current and\nfuture aviation and aerospace leaders and managers. Taking a global view, the course opens with the tremendous\neconomic impact of the aviation sector that both drives and enables the interdependent global economy. The course\nmaterial covers the unique business models and best practices in financial management for both the airport and airline\nindustries and analyzes the relationship between the two (including the complications implicit in highly divergent\nplanning horizons). The complexity of aircraft financing decisions is covered that lead up to building a fleet to serve the\nairlines' forecast growth. The course uses relevant readings and case studies as well as statistical data in time series to\ndemonstrate the way financial management has evolved to improve performance in both the airport and airline\nindustries. Permission of department required.Credits: 3.00"
  },

The studies include research into\nthe development and use of operational indexes and their possible relation to hedging with commodity and security\ninstruments. Emphasis will be placed on the understanding of current operational measurements and correlations to\ntrading and hedging financial instruments in providing improved risk management in operational\nenvironments.     "Course": "AT54800",
    "Title": "Aircraft Asset Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides the student with a detailed exploration of aircraft asset management programs\nin both airlines and business aviation organizations. Students analyze and study the critical components of an asset\nmanagement program, the financial methods in aircraft asset management, acquisition proposals, and development\nplans of aircraft acquisitions in this course. An airline industry-relevant project is used to improve student reasoning\nand application of industry standard aircraft asset management analysis procedures to include forecating techniques,\npresent value calculations, and benefit-cost analyses. This course serves as the foundational knowledge required for AT\n54900. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AT54900",
    "Title": "Aircraft Leasing",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides students with training and experience managing aircraft leases using financial\nand risk management methodologies specific to the airline and business aviation industries. Students conduct financial\nevaluations of leasing versus ownership programs of airlines, as well as analyze debt, equity and capital markets for\naircraft financing. The course includes an examination oftaxation issues related to aircraft leasing, maintenance\nreserves, and auditing of aircraft financial performance. The prerequisite for this course is AT 54800. Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

  },
  {
    "Course": "AT57200",
    "Title": "Human Error And Safety",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Explores the definition and nature of human error, error chains, and causal factors in error\ngeneration. Error taxonomies are reviewed in order to provide a classification scheme for grouping errors and assessing\nerror criticality. Methods for assessing risk and predicting error generation potentials are learned, as well as strategies\nfor controlling or eliminating errors. Case studies are utilized throughout the course to illustrate course concepts.\nPermission of instructor required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AT57300",
    "Title": "Managing The Risk Of Organizational Accidents",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Examines strategies various industries use to assess the risk of organizational accidents and to\ndevelop safety management programs to prevent, capture, and recover from conditions that lead to disastrous outcomes.\nStrategies such as High Reliability Organizations, Operational Risk Management, Behavioral Based Safety, Tripod\nDelta, and Safety Cultures are explored as successful methods for improving organizational safety in high-risk\nenvironments and endeavors. Permission of instructor required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "AT57400",
    "Title": "Exploratory Studies In Aviation Human Factors",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Exploration of contemporary issues and research related to human factors theory and program\nstrategies as they relate to the aviation industry. The course ventures beyond ergonomic issues into more diverse human\nfactors considerations, while discussing an industry-wide and organizational perspective. The course utilizes a\ncombination of lecture, group discussion, and independent study into issues relevant to student interests and career\ngoals. Permission of instructor required. Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides a critical foundation necessary for understanding Bayesian theory and\nemploying that theory in the analysis of typical data generated in industry. Practical skills in presenting advanced analyses to both professional and\nscientific audiences is a key component of the course.   {
    "Course": "BMS23700",
    "Title": "Applied Physiology With Clinical Correlations I",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces students to the general physiology of mammalian body systems and\nphysiological processes. This course will address the functions of the different systems and homeostasis; the functions\nof the cell and its different compartments; solute transport, blood and immunity; general functions of the nervous\nsystem, reflexes and special senses; the functions of the nerve and muscle, the cardiovascular system; and the digestive\nsystem. The course provides the basic physiological concepts of various organ systems and clinical correlations that\nemphasize how understanding of basic physiological concepts help students solve problems. The clinical correlations\nand the students-centered learning activities are deigned to promote critical thinking, team work, communication skills,\nand problem solving. The targeted undergraduate students are: Pre-vet students, animal science majors, wildlife majors,\nand students in biological sciences and biomedical engineering, and other students interested in use of animals as\nmodels for human diseases. Permission of instructor required. Credits: 2.00"
