    "Course": "BMS52400",
    "Title": "Introduction To Confocal Microscopy And Image Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to the principles of confocal microscopy and rudiments of image analysis. Confocal\nmicroscopy can be used in biological and nonbiological systems and is, therefore, an interdisciplinary tool in the\nmodern research laboratory. The three-dimensional reconstruction of images allows discovery of complex structures.\nDeals with fluorescence excitation and emission, optical design, basic image analysis principles, and application areas\nfor which the technology has been targeted. The student will have a good understanding of the application and use of\nthe technology by the end of the course. Credits: 1.00"

  {
    "Course": "BMS80700",
    "Title": "Veterinary Cell And Tissue Biology Design I\nCredit hours: 2.50. The first of a two-semester sequence of courses, emphasizing developmental and microstructural\nfoundations of structural differentiation of cell, tissue, and organ systems. Emphasis is placed upon principles,\nfundamental concepts, and applicable details as well as comparative aspects of general importance for veterinary\nmedicine and biomedical research. That you have some background in biochemistry and cell biology is\nassumed. Credits: 2.50\nBMS 80800 - Veterinary Cell And Tissue Biology Design II\nCredit hours: 2.00. All lectures will focus on mammalian microanatomy with species differences and aim to include\nalso a brief comparative description for Avian microanatomy when applicable. Structural and molecular basis of\ncellular processes that are the foundation of fertilization, embryogenesis, histogenesis, and basic tissue specialization in\ndomesticated animals. Structure and function of macromolecules and organelles that mediate signal transduction,\ndifferentiation, and integration within a whole animal. Credits: 2.00\nBMS 81000 - Foundations In Basic Medical Sciences",
    "CreditHours": 1.5,
    "Description": "The overall objective of this course is to provide the incoming first year DVM students the basic,\nfoundational science principles upon which they will base study of the DVM curriculum. Emphasis is upon basic\nprinciples and fundamental concepts of: animal body organization and terminology; cellular and whole body\nmetabolism; macromolecules, membranes, transport, biosynthetic processes, cellular communication/signal\ntransduction, cell cycle and growth regulation, gene expression and embryonic development. Credits: 1.50"
  },

    "Description": "Continuation of Physiology of Domestic Animals I (BMS 81100). Survey of the principles,\nconcepts and mechanisms of physiological processes with special emphasis on interactions between large populations\nof cells, tissues, organ systems and integrated functions of domestic animals of importance to veterinary medicine. The\norgan systems covered are respiratory, renal, digestive, endocrine, and reproductive. Credits: 4.00"

  {
    "Course": "BMS81401",
    "Title": "Pharmacology Principles And Applications",
    "CreditHours": 4.0,
    "Description": "This is the first of two pharmacology courses in the DVM curriculum. The first part of this course\nencompasses an introduction to basic concepts necessary to understand and optimally administer and deliver\ntherapeutic drugs, such as pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, dose forms, dosing regimen and prescriptions. In the\nsecond part of the course, drugs are studied not only based on their pharmacological class, but also based on the organs\nand systems on which they act (e.g., heart and vascular system, lungs, autonomous neuronal pathways, respiratory\nsystem, endocrine system, etc.). This course also covers the pharmacology of cancer therapy and drugs used to fight\npathogens (antifungals, antibiotics, antivirals, antiparasitics). Journal club sessions are included to directly relate\npharmacology instruction to topics currently debated in the field. Credits: 4.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "BCHM32200",
    "Title": "Analytical Biochemistry II",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Modern biochemical techniques for the purification and characterization of biological proteins.\nThis is a project-oriented course where students begin by purifying a recombinant enzyme by affinity chromatography\nand then characterize various biochemical properties of the enzyme throughout the semester. Emphasis will be placed\non quantitative analyses, including measurements of enzyme activity and inhibition, molecular interactions, and\noligomeric state. Students will learn basic principles of designing assays to measure biochemical phenomena. Use of\nbioinformatics and computational modeling tools for protein structure analysis will be integrated. The course will\nculminate with preparation of a manuscript-style report describing the enzyme characterization. Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "BCHM42100",
    "Title": "R For Molecular Biosciences",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Students will acquire, assess, clean, visualize and analyze biological data sets with R. Students will\nbe able to describe the link between complex biological phenomena and the data captured through human observation\nor scientific instrumentation. Students will learn how to organize data sets to optimize clarity and analytic possibilities\nwhile minimizing errors with examples drawn from the literature or biological databases. R will be taught starting with\nsmall-scale data such as drug sensitivity assays moving to genome-scale analyses such as gene expression and pathway\nanalysis later in the course. These skills will be taught in the light of increasing data literacy and enabling reproducible\nresearch through clear documentation of data and communication of analyses. Relevant concepts from biology and\nstatistics will be reviewed. Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

  {
    "Course": "BCHM60501",
    "Title": "Macromolecules",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will provide students with an understanding of the basic principles that underlie the\nsecondary and tertiary structure of proteins and nucleic acids which contribute to their function. It will inform students\nof current efforts to engineer macromolecules with novel functions. Students will become familiar with methods used\nto determine the three-dimensional structures of macromolecules, and they will learn to critically evaluate the accuracy\nof structural models. Special topics in the current literature, including membrane proteins, drug design and ribozymes,\nwill be covered. The class will typically include students from a variety of departments, graduate programs, and\nscientific backgrounds. The course will be taught primarily from various textbook and from the primary literature. A\nbiochemistry course designated for majors is a prerequisite of the course. Lack of the prerequisite will require approval\nof the instructor. Permission of Department required. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Title": "Regulation Of Eukaryotic Gene Expression",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will provide students with a basic understanding of gene expression mechanisms with\na s specific focus on newly emerging topics. This course will be taught from current primary literature, using a\ntextbook as a background resource. Students will learn how to read and interpret scientific literature through\nclass presentations, discussions and take home assignments.     "Course": "BCHM62000",
    "Title": "Protein Mass Spectrometry And Proteomics",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The goals of this course are to introduce students to 1) basic principles of mass spectrometry, 2)\nthe most common instruments used for protein mass spectrometry including the advantages and disadvantages of each,\n3) the most common applications of protein mass spectrometry in biological research, 4) current approaches to\nquantitative protein mass spectrometry and their use in proteomic studies 5) the skills necessary to analyze mass spec\ndata from a variety of experiment types including the ability to use and understand common database search programs,\nand 6) contemporary issues associated with large-scale proteomics experiments (including technical challenges and\nlimitations) culminating in the ability to design appropriate experiments to answer a specific proteomic question.\nPrerequisite: Students need to have taken an undergraduate level biochemistry course and be familiar with basic aspects\nof protein structure that are taught in such courses.   {
    "Course": "BIOL14501",
    "Title": "First Year Biology Laboratory With Neuro Research Project",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This laboratory course has been designed under the goals of the Center for Authentic Science\nPractice in Education (CASPiE) which aims to expose students to novel research as a means to teach them laboratory\nscience. This course is designed to engage students in authentic research while acquiring necessary skills and concepts\nto be successful as a biology major. Our topic is Neuroanatomy of Auditory Pathways. We will begin with a series of\nskills and knowledge building weeks and then transition into independent research projects that culminate in a public\npresentation of the data in a poster session. In this course, students will learn the fundamentals in neurobiology as well\nas use sophisticated analysis and instrumentation to answer a research question. Critical thinking in experimental\ndesign as well as interpretation and communication of data will be stressed. The goals for this course are to gain a\nfoundation in basic biological measurements and techniques, hone the analytical skills, appreciate the excitement of\nscientific discovery, and have fun along the way. Permission of department required. Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "BIOL20200",
    "Title": "Human Anatomy And Physiology",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "BIOL 20200 is the second semester of a two-semester course that includes two 50-minute lectures\ndesigned to give the student a basic understanding of the anatomy, organization and function of the human body. To\nassist the student in mastering the subject matter, there will be introductory lectures on the basic concepts of\nbiochemistry and cell biology before the major topics of the course are dealt with. These topics include the organization\nof the human body; muscle and bone; the nervous system (including the special senses); the cardiovascular system,\nrespiration; digestion; metabolism; excretion; fluid, electrolyte, and acid-base balance; the endocrine system;\nreproduction and genetics. The subject matter will be related to relevant questions of clinical or health-related\nimportance. Not available for credit toward graduation for majors in the Department of Biological Sciences. Credits:\n2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BIOL20300",
    "Title": "Human Anatomy And Physiology",
    "CreditHours": 4.0,
    "Description": "A survey of normal structure and function of the human organism. The human is treated as an open\nsystem with the capacity to transport material, transform energy, and maintain a homeostatic state. The capacities and\nlimitations of the human to cope with changes in the environment are emphasized. All major systems of the human\nbody and their functions are examined in relation to the living organism. Integrated into the study of the human\norganism are laboratory exercises that emphasize the essentials of human anatomy and physiology. Not available for\ncredit toward graduation for majors in the Department of Biological Sciences. Credits: 4.00"

  {
    "Course": "BIOL31200",
    "Title": "Great Issues Genomics And Society",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The course will revolve around genomics, the science and technology involved in determining the\nsequence of the entire DNA complement in an organism. Almost everyone has heard of the human genome project, but\nfewer are aware of the spectacular technical progress in this field and the fact that many thousands of genomes have\nbeen sequenced. Until recently, most of these have been microorganisms, but technological and computational progress\nhas made it progressively easier and cheaper to sequence the genomes of higher organisms. This field may have more\nof an impact on your future lives than almost any other field of the life sciences - mostly because it touches on all areas\nof study. The course will focus on the impact that genomes will have in selected areas. It will begin with a basic\nunderstanding of the science and technology that gave rise to our current capabilities in sequencing and the fact that\ntechnology continues to provide greater capacity and cheaper prices. You will soon see that every field in the College\nof Science is well represented in the science and technology. We will then go on to see how genomics influences many\ntopics that affect our daily lives and can possibly provide answers to some critical questions (or at least pose better\nquestions): What is the basis of personalized medicine? What does genomics tell us about the genealogy of mankind?\nWhat impact will genomics have on our future food supply and our ability to feed a population of 9 billion people?\nWhat is the human microbiome and what does that mean to me? Similarly, what is the gut microbiome, the\nmouthmicrobiome, etc? What impact will genomics have on the development of alternative energy sources, especially\nbiofuels? In every area, we will discuss the scientific challenges, but also the ethical and societal implications. In most\ncases, there is no one right answer, but a series of choices that can be guided by ethical considerations. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BIOL32800",
    "Title": "Principles Of Physiology",
    "CreditHours": 4.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to provide students with an introduction to physiology with an emphasis on\ncellular mechanisms that underlie anatomical and physiological adaptations used by animals to survive in their habitat.\nTopics covered will range from cellular respiration to the physical limits of animal performance as we deconstruct and\nthen reconstruct the body to examine how animals can live in extreme environments. Goals for this course are for\nstudents to gain a foundation in basic physiological principles, to learn about the integrative nature of the systems of\nanimals, and to appreciate how and why animals have evolved and strategies to help them survive in their unique\nenvironment. Credits: 4.00"

  {
    "Course": "BIOL43200",
    "Title": "Reproductive Physiology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an integrated approach to examining how tissues interact to regulate\nreproductive processes. Each section begins by describing fundamental commonalities of a reproductive event in a\nvariety of species. This is followed by an emphasis on the difference in the details of that event among species.\nStudents will be strongly encouraged to initiate and participate in discussions related to course topics during class. To\ngain a deeper understanding of physiological processes, students are asked to select a current research article related to\nreproductive physiology. Students are then required to present an analysis of article to the class in a formal\npresentation. Some of the topics to be covered in lecture include ovarian and testicular function, the hypothalamic-\npituitary-gonadal axis, fertilization, establishment of the placenta, maternal support of pregnancy, parturition, and\nlactation. Credits: 3.00"
  },

Up-to-date research findings and techniques will be included. A basic knowledge of cell biology and\nprotein structure and function is strongly recommended. Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Introductory Module: Protein Expression",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This is a project-oriented course designed to give the student exposure to laboratory research\nthrough a series of five-week modules. During this five-week introductory module, the students will learn the basics of\nexpression, isolation, and characterization of recombinant proteins in E. coli using SDS-PAGE and Western blotting. In\nthe first half of the course, students work initially with one recombinant DNA construct and then are given a second\nconstruct to use to identify the protein expressed. *Note: additional hours as needed for particular\nexperiments.     "Title": "Exploration Of Protein Structure",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This module is a hands-on exploration of the principles of enzyme structure.   {
    "Course": "BIOL44215",
    "Title": "Multidisciplinary Design Of Systems And Devices For Physiology\nMeasurements",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This physiology laboratory course will provide an opportunity for undergraduates from the College\nof Science (Department of Biology) to collaborate with students in other colleges (Agriculture, Education, Engineering,\nHealth and Human Science & Technology) to experience and learn how to operate effectively as part of an\ninterdisciplinary team to address physiological problems in the cardiovascular system, respiratory system and in\nbiological transport. Specifically it will emphasize how these teams can use information, tools, techniques and theories\nfrom their disciplines to solve problems that are beyond the scope of any single discipline. In this process, the students\nwill develop an appreciation of both engineering design and the classic hypothesis-driven experimental science as tools\nto solve complex real-world problems. This course will promote effective communication, systems thinking, laboratory\nskills, self-management and professional ethics. Students will learn to measure and quantify biological changes,\nanalyze data (including statistical analysis) and interpret its meaning as it applied to the larger physiological question at\nhand. These skills will be necessary for teams to efficiently function in an interdisciplinary setting both in future\ncourses and more importantly when they enter the workforce.&nbsp;Credits: 2.00"

    "Course": "BIOL47800",
    "Title": "Introduction To Bioinformatics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(CS 47800) Bioinformatics is broadly defined as the study of molecular biological information,\ntargeting particularly the enormous volume of DNA sequence and functional complexity embedded in entire genomes.\nTopics will include understanding the evolutionary organization of genes (genomics), the structure and function of gene\nproducts (proteomics), and the dynamics of gene expression in biological processes (transcriptomics). Inherently,\nbioinformatics is interdisciplinary, melding various applications of computational science with biology. This jointly\ntaught course introduces analytical methods from biology, statistics and computer science that are necessary for"

  {
    "Course": "BIOL48100",
    "Title": "Eukaryotic Genetics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course presents the fundamental concepts of classical and modern molecular genetics in\neukaryotic systems, using examples from the model genetic organisms, yeast, Drosophila, Caenorhabditis, Arabidopsis,\nmaize, mice and humans. These concepts are applied to solving problems of genetic analysis. Recent advances in\ndevelopmental, cancer, and behavioral genetics and genomics, and applications of genetic technology, are used to\ndemonstrate the impact that modern genetics makes at the cutting edge of biological research. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BIOL48300",
    "Title": "Great Issues: Environmental And Conservation Biology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Concerned with the application of ecological principles to environmental issues, the course\nintroduces fundamental ecology, emphasizing the interplay of theoretical models, natural history, and experimentation.\nNew research developments are stressed, with the outlook for application to environmental management and\nrestoration. Whole-biosphere issues, such as the loss of biological diversity, frame a focus at the population level to\nunderstand local and global extinction and community stability. In-depth case studies of endangered ecosystems (both\ntemperate and tropical), with computer modeling, field trips, and discussions of policy formulation, demonstrate the\nrange of tools and information necessary to accomplish coexistence of humans with the rest of nature. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "BIOL53601",
    "Title": "Biological And Structural Aspects Of Drug Design And Action",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(BCHM 53600) This course is aimed at expanding students' fundamental interests in biology,\nchemistry and biochemistry to how drugs work. The course will provide an overview of the modern day drug discovery\npipeline and an in-depth look at the basic biology, structure, and mechanisms-of-action behind marketed therapeutics.\nThe course will start with a historical account of the discovery of natural product drugs such as aspirin and penicillin\nand will then venture into the modern day era of drug discovery including structure-based drug design. We will explore\ndifferent classes of antibiotics, antiviral, and anti-cancer drugs and their targets including small molecule drugs and\nmodern biologics-based drugs. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BIOL53700",
    "Title": "Immunobiology",

    "Course": "BIOL56310",
    "Title": "Protein Bioinformatics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Accumulation of biological data, such as genome sequences, protein structures and sequences,\nmetabolic pathways, opened up a new way of research in biology-bioinformatics. Through the survey of the various\nactive research topics in bioinformatics, in this course we will learn bioinformatics databases, tools, and algorithms\nbehind these tools. Special emphasis is placed on protein sequence and structure analyses. Covered topics will include\nmethods for protein sequence comparison, protein structure comparison, protein structure prediction/modeling, protein\ndocking prediction, protein function prediction, and protein network analysis.   {
    "Course": "BIOL58210",
    "Title": "Ecological Statistics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course covers topics that are useful for successfully designing and analyzing statistically\nobservational and experimental studies in ecology, animal behavior, evolutionary biology, forestry, wildlife sciences,\nfisheries, etc. Some topics are: differences between hypotheses and predictions, design of an ecological study, general\nlinear models, assumptions, different types of designs (factorial, nested, repeated measures, blocks, split-plots, etc.),\nfitting models to data, etc. The course will focus on the conceptual understanding of these topics (e.g., interpreting the\nresults of statistical tests) and practice with statistical programs and real datasets. Credits: 3.00"
  },

Mathematical principles are covered (e.g. in the\nevolution of signals), so some background in mathematics (e.g. calculus or algebra and introductory physics) is\nhelpful. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "BIOL65001",
    "Title": "Techniques In Molecular Biology",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Techniques in Molecular Biology will introduce graduate students to the theory and practice of\nmany commonly used methods. Emphasis will be placed on understanding the theoretical basis for these techniques,\ntheir utility in various circumstances, and their limitations. Although taught as a lecture, students should be able to take\nthis knowledge back to the laboratory to help them in their research efforts. The course will be as close as possible to a\nlaboratory experience without being in an actual laboratory setting. This course is designed to prepare students for other\nin-depth 600-level scientific courses, for their rotations, and for future laboratory work. Exams will be \"experimental\"\nin nature (e.g., \"design and experiment to do something...\" or \"in this type of situation, which technique/vector/etc.\nwould best be used, and why...\"). Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "BIOL66300",
    "Title": "Seminar Methods And Professional Development II",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course is a continuation of BIOL 66200 and expands the introduction for incoming graduate\nstudents to methods of seminar presentation and critique and to various guidelines for professional development during\ntheir graduate school experience. Topics include seminar topic selection and 20-minute seminar design, tutorials on\nelectronic services at the PU Library and Citation Management programs, and evaluating classmate presentations.\nUsing the skills learned the previous semester, each student is required to make a 20-minute PowerPoint presentation to\nthe class, based on a pre-approved topic of their choice. The speaker is asked questions and the presentation receives\nwritten evaluations by all members of the class. Each student practices with the course instructor prior to the public\npresentation. The course also continues to socialize the incoming cohort of students among themselves and with more\nsenior students in the broad range of research disciplines available. Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "BME20100",
    "Title": "Biomolecules: Structure, Function, And Engineering Applications",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Classes of molecules (biomolecules) such as sugars, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids that form\nthe cellular components of living organisms. Explores the chemistry behind the structure and function of these\nimportant classes of biological molecules. Hydrogen-bonding, hydrophobic forces, electrostatic interactions along with\nother weak interactions discussed with reference to their importance in biomolecular systems in an engineering\ncontext. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME20400",
    "Title": "Biomechanics Of Hard And Soft Tissues",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Covers the mechanics of biological materials, with applications in the musculo-skeletal system,\nnerves, spinal cord, and vascular tissue, down to the level of the cell. Topics include center of mass, moment of inertia,\nbasic understanding of stresses, strains, and deformations, axial elements, pressure vessels, beams, torsion,\nviscoelasticity, and thermal stress. Case studies and problem solving sessions used to emphasize the unique biological\ncriteria which must be considered when mechanically analyzing both soft and hard tissues. Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "BME20700",
    "Title": "Bioinstrumentation And Circuit Theory",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction of laboratory instruments used to measure physiological events. Stimulation and\nconduction of electric signals within the mammalian nervous system and other excitable tissues are demonstrated.\nFundamental circuit elements and concepts include resistance, capacitance, inductance, op-amps, impedance, voltage,\ncurrent, power, and frequency. Fundamental analog measurement concepts include adequate bandwidth and amplitude\nand phase linearity. An integrative design project emphasizes the practical aspects of quantitative physiological\nmeasurements. Students are introduced to programming (using Python) to deepen the understanding of the basic\nconcepts and learn basic skills in data processing. SPICE software will be used throughout the course to\ndesign/simulate various analog circuits. Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "BME31400",
    "Title": "Experimental Methods In Biomechanics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course focuses on the concepts and applications of mechanics, imaging, and instrumentation\nmethods towards evaluating experimental biomechanics at multiple length scales. Core concepts include mechanics of\nmaterials, dynamics, contact theory, and the simplifying assumptions and standardizations often needed to conduct\nexperiments on biomaterials and living systems. Experimental methods may include atomic force microscopy, digital\nimage correlation, and motion analysis. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME35600",
    "Title": "Mathematical Models And Methods In Physiology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course uses real-world engineering problems to introduce advanced analytical tools and\nconcepts relevant to biomedical engineering design. Each topic is briefly introduced, and students work in small teams\nto investigate physical mechanisms involving human anatomy and physiology using mathematical models and\nmethods. Group work is done during scheduled class periods and other times by arrangement. Topics include brain\nconcussions and protective helmets, origin of the electrocardiogram and bi-ventricular pacing, and deep brain\nstimulation for Parkinson's disease. Mathematical methods include coupled linear and nonlinear differential equations,\nfinite element analysis, and simulated annealing. Creation of custom computer code is required. Students prepare\nextensive and detailed written technical reports. A midterm and a final examination encourage individual accountability\nand understanding. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME36000",
    "Title": "Introduction To Biomedical Imaging",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The main focus of this course is on basic principles and modes of major bioimaging modalities.\nThis course covers image characterization, interactions of electromagnetic radiation with tissue, fundamental principles\nin imaging and detection, and modes of imaging modalities (e.g. reflection, transmission, absorption, and emission).\nConventional bioimaging modalities will be used to teach the topics. This course is particularly aimed at students in\nscience and engineering interested in gaining a conceptual understanding of several critical biological and biomedical\nimaging methods, including optical microscopy, ultrasound, X-ray imaging, computed tomography, nuclear medicine,\nmagnetic resonance imaging, and mobile health. Overall, this course provides a conceptual framework for biomedical\nimaging in a reasonably concise and understandable format (with minimal mathematical approaches). Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME36600",
    "Title": "Foundations Of Biomedical Data Science",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course presents foundational data science methods for analysis of complex biological datasets\nencountered in biomedical engineering research and applications. After a brief (1-2 weeks) introduction and review of\nmathematical concepts necessary for data science, the course will cover representative areas of regression, supervised\nmachine learning, unsupervised machine learning, model evaluation, and uncertainty quantification. Assignments and\nexams will focus on practical examples spanning basic science, engineering, and medical applications. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "BME40100",
    "Title": "Mathematical & Computational Analysis Of Complex System\nDynamics In Biology, Medicine, & Healthcare",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introduction to analysis of complex system dynamics that appear in biology, medicine, and\nhealthcare. Key topics include nonlinear dynamical concepts associated with phase plane, bifurcation, stability\ndiagram, oscillation, and chaotic systems along with concepts from discrete systems and stochastic processes. These\ntopics are taught within the context of mathematical and computational models related to both non-communicable\ndiseases (i.e. cancer) and communicable diseases (i.e. HIV/AIDS). Courses projects are drawn from recent\nliterature. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "BME41000",
    "Title": "Neural Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introduction to \"Neural Engineering\" - an emerging field of developing and applying\nengineering solutions to research or translational problems concerning the brain.   },
  {
    "Course": "BME43000",
    "Title": "Introduction To Bioimaging",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Provides a conceptual framework for understanding the theory and technical principles behind\nmajor Bioimaging modalities. The main focus is on basic principles and modes of imaging involving interactions of\nelectromagnetic radiation with biological tissue. Main concepts include imaging and detection, modes of imaging\nmodalities (e.g. reflection, transmission, absorption, and emission), and basic image characterizations. Applications\ninclude several critical biological and biomedical imaging methods, such as optical microscopy, ultrasound, X-ray\nimaging, computed tomography, positron emission tomography, and magnetic resonance imaging. Demonstrations of\nconventional Bioimaging modalities are used to teach the topics. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME44000",
    "Title": "Computational Mechanics In Biomedical Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Teaches modeling methods for biomedical engineering problems with focus on fluid/solid\nmechanics. Students are introduced to the most common numerical techniques in biomedical engineering and will learn\nthe applications of these techniques to biomechanical problems at various length scales, such as cardiac contraction and\nblood flow. The first half of this course focuses on modeling based on ordinary differential equation (ODE) and partial\ndifferential equation (PDE) as well as on how we integrate these equations analytically or numerically using software\npackages such as MATLAB. The other half focuses on fundamentals of fluid/solid mechanics and also on the\napplication of COMSOL or similar software to solving relevant biomechanical problems. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME45000",
    "Title": "Deep Learning For Medical Imaging",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Teaches the foundation of neural network (aka \"Deep Learning\") approaches and applications to\nmedical imaging: or how to create computable models of biological neural systems, in particular large-scale neural\nnetworks, for processing medical images and data. Drawing inspiration from neuroscience and statistics, Deep\nLearning introduces the basic background on neural networks, presents computable neuron models and extends to large\nnetworks of neurons. Students study deep learning with both real and artificial neural networks, along with methods of\ndeep learning about the environment by applying back propagation, Boltzmann machines, auto-encoders, convolutional\nneural networks and recurrent neural networks. Students will explore how Deep Learning is impacting our\nunderstanding of intelligence and contributing to the practical design of automatic medical imaging tools that are able\nto augment expert medical personnel, enhance diagnosis accuracy and speed, and lower health-care costs. Credits:\n3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME46000",
    "Title": "Cardiovascular Mechanical Support And Devices",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Designed to expose students to state-of-the-art medical technologies being utilized in the treatment\nof patients with cardiovascular diseases, the course emphasizes the role of the biomedical engineer in the design,\ndevelopment and implementation of these technologies for therapeutic impact. Students completing this course will\nhave an understanding of the role of biomedical engineers in clinical engineering and clinical research. The three\ncomponents of the course, didactic presentations and discussions, laboratory dissections, and clinical shadowing are\nintegrated throughout to teach concepts such as cardiovascular physiology, heart failure and vascular disease,\ntreatments and treatment complications, and future directions. Clinical experts in cardiovascular diagnosis and\ntreatment are frequent guest lecturers. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME47000",
    "Title": "Biomolecular Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The course covers key chemical concepts one needs in order to modify existing biomolecules, link\nbiomolecules with other (bio)molecules, link biomolecules with inorganic entities, create composite (bio)structures,\nmodify specific properties of biomolecules, alter/enhance biomolecule functionality. Taken together, the rational\napplication of these biological, chemical, and engineering tools can be used to; engineer new biomolecules, design\nsensors for molecular detection, create diagnostic tests, develop new imaging modalities, and design and test novel\nbiomaterials, to name a few examples. Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introduction to the application of digital signal processing to practical problems involving\nbiomedical signals and systems. Topics include: overview of biomedical signals; filtering to remove artifacts; event\ndetection; analysis of waveshape and waveform complexity; frequency domain characterization; modeling biomedical\nsignal-generating systems; analysis of non-stationary signals; pattern classification and diagnostic decisions, MATLAB\nis used throughout to apply the theory and techniques discussed to biomedical signals.   {
    "Course": "BME55500",
    "Title": "Magnetic Resonance Imaging Theory",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course covers fundamental aspects of magnetic resonance imaging systems with an emphasis\non theory, methodology, and instrumentation. Key principles are derived from the Bloch equations and Maxwell's\nequations. Topics include pulse sequences, signal acquisition, spatial encoding in k-space, image reconstruction, and\ntissue contrast. Major components of an MRI scanner are examined, including the static magnet, gradient and shim\ncoils, transmit and receive chains, and radiofrequency coils and arrays. Learning outcomes are assessed by solving\nproblem sets integrating theory with practical applications. As a final research project, students survey recent literature\nto identify a specialized topic of interest and deliver a peer-evaluated presentation to the class. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME55600",
    "Title": "Introduction To Clinical Medicine For Engineering Solutions",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces students to the physiology and medicine underlying major human diseases\nlikely to become research targets in biomedical engineering and medical device development. It encourages students to\nupgrade research target selection to include projects that promise to improve patient care, with a major emphasis on\npathophysiology and disease mechanisms. The information and intellectual approach offered will help students\nrecognize needs for engineering solutions to current challenges in medicine. The course also previews the intellectual\ncontent of medical school, including rigor and level of detail, for engineering students considering designing medical\nsolutions or translational engineering research as a career, emphasizing the key \"11-points\" necessary for practical\nunderstanding of any disease: definition of the condition, causes, functional abnormalities, structural abnormalities,\nearly signs, history and physical findings, differential diagnosis, special studies (lab, imaging, etc.), treatment strategy,\nspecific steps of treatment, and follow up, as well as current clinical needs for innovation and research opportunities for\nthe future. To avoid possible redundancy with the Weldon School undergraduate curriculum, focal areas of the course\ninclude topics and body systems not covered in BME 25600, including infectious diseases, cardiopulmonary diseases,\nhematology-oncology, and gastrointestinal diseases. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME56100",
    "Title": "Preclinical And Clinical Study Design",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Medical devices are developed, manufactured, and distributed in a highly regulated environment.\nThis course concerns the preclinical and clinical study design processes for obtaining FDA marketing approval for\nbiomedical devices. Prior to marketing a medical device in the US, specific governmental approval is required\ndependent on the type of device and the risk associated. This course is part of a three-course series dealing with various\naspect of regulatory science. Regulatory science considers the scientific and technical foundations that support the\npractical testing and regulations that ensure the safety and effectiveness of medical devices. This course covers the\nresponsible conduct of clinical and preclinical research, including evaluation of device tissue interactions and how they\nmay be studied with preclinical animal models to predict safety and performance in human clinical trials that are\nnecessary to gain regulatory approval for marketing. In the section on ethics we will cover several topics related to\nresponsible conduct of clinical and preclinical research, including informed consent, risk assessment and ethical\ndecisions, IRB oversight and ethical study design. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME56200",
    "Title": "Regulatory Issues Surrounding Approval Of Biomedical Devices",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Medical devices are developed, manufactured, and distributed in a highly-regulated environment.\nThis course primarily concerns the processes for obtaining FDA marketing approval or clearance for biomedical\ndevices. Prior to marketing a medical device in the US, a specific governmental approval or clearance is required\ndepending on the type of device and the risk associated with the device. This course is part of a three-course series\ndealing with various aspects of regulatory science. Regulatory processes for class I, II, and III devices, including\ncombination devices, are covered with specific focus on 510(k) and PMA requirements. Approval requirements in the\nEU, Japan and other countries will also be briefly considered. Throughout the course, emphasis will be placed on\nregulatory science, regulatory strategy and principles of interacting with regulatory agencies. Credits: 3.00"
  },

Focus is on\nunderstanding the critical elements of regulatory science and quality compliance from a design control perspective.\nInstruction and mentoring in regulatory science skills is provided by academics and industry representatives with\nexpertise in their fields. This course is part of a three-course series. Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Plant Disease Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,

  {
    "Course": "BTNY55800",
    "Title": "Pathogens Of Plants",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Plant pathology is the science of plant diseases and of the microorganisms that cause them and of\nour attempts to manage plant diseases. The ultimate goal of plant pathologists is to reduce the losses caused by\ndiseases, thereby, increasing both the quality and quantity of the world food supply. Plant diseases are caused by the\nsame types of microorganisms that cause disease in animals and humans and, as such, many of the principles that apply\nto human and animal medicine apply to plant diseases. It is the objective of this course to introduce students to the\nmajor types of plant pathogens (plant pathogenic bacteria, viruses, nematodes, and fungi), their basic biology and\nexamples of the types of diseases they cause. It will be expected that students have knowledge in plant\npathology. Credits: 3.00"
  },

The intent is to show students that they probably already have a model in their heads,\nand they just don't know it! Few biologists realize that when they can draw a picture of their system, or explain\nimportant pathways in words, that this is a model. From there, it isn't hard to start some basic math. The course will be"

  {
    "Course": "BTNY56200",
    "Title": "Plant Hormone Biology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will provide a broad and integrated overview of the current status of plant hormone\nresearch. All aspects of plant hormones including biosynthesis, metabolism, transport, signal transduction will be\ndiscussed in relation to the role of hormones in plant growth and developmental processes. Cross-talk between\nhormones and how plants use hormones to integrate developmental or environmental signals to regulate plant growth\nwill be included. In addition, practical aspects of hormones in the agriculture, horticulture, and pathogen responses will\nbe covered to demonstrate the impacts of basic plant science to a modern agriculture. The course will consist of lecture\nand discussion of primary research papers. Upon completion of the course, the students will acquire a comprehensive\nknowledge of the action of plant hormones as growth regulators, critical thinking skills, and ethical research. Credits:\n3.00"

    "Course": "CHE52300",
    "Title": "Engineering Applications Of Biological Molecules",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the applications of biological molecules in different engineering fields. The\nfirst part of the course will provide a general overview of fundamental molecular and cell biology, biophysics and\nbiomechanics. The second part of the course will focus on three specific areas, namely 1) biopolymer, 2)\nnanobiotechnology and 3) genetic engineering. For each focus area, a general overview will be provided followed by\nin-class discussions of seminal papers of the field and team-based case studies. The goal of the course is to introduce\nthe recent advances in the interface of biology and engineering to our students and prepare them for research and\ndevelopment work in interdisciplinary environments. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CHE55300",
    "Title": "Pharmaceutical Process, Development And Design",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the engineering methodologies involved in translating a laboratory recipe\nfor a drug compound produced via synthetic organic chemistry methods to an industrial process. The basic features of\ncommon unit operations used in the pharmaceutical industry will be reviewed, including batch reaction, solid-liquid\nseparation, crystallization, drying, mixing, batch distillation and other separation systems. Both dedicated and multi-\nproduct production system design and batch and semi-continuous operating modes will be covered. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHE55400",
    "Title": "Smart Manufacturing In Process Industries",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course surveys the tools and techniques, which are relevant to support the multiple levels of\ntechnical decisions that arise in modern integrated operation of manufacturing facilities in the chemical and related\nprocess industries. The linkage of these decisions levels and sharing of associated data and knowledge via effective IT\nmethodology is currently termed Smart Manufacturing in the US and Industry 4.0 in Europe. The topics covered in the\ncourse include the structure of the operations decision hierarchy, role of online process measurements, elements of\nsensor network design, information systems to support process operations, plant data reconciliation, detection and\ndiagnosis of process faults, plant wide control, real time process optimization, production planning and scheduling, and\nsupply chain management. Each topic will be addressed by first summarizing the basic role and scope of that\ncomponent, then discussing the structure of the decision problem, and then will outline some representative tools\navailable to address that decision problem. Each major topic will include a lecture given by an industrial practitioner\nwho will offer a perspective on the state of industrial practice. Permission of instructor required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHE55500",
    "Title": "Computer Integrated Process Operations",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to computer-aided process operations management. Topics include: process\nmonitoring, regulatory control, data reconciliation, unit and plant-wide optimization, process fault diagnosis,\nsupervisory control, planning, and scheduling. A design project involving a unified application of the presented\nmethodologies is taken from a published industrial benchmark problem. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CHE56000",
    "Title": "Introduction To Energy Storage Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Energy Storage Systems Laboratory course is designed to introduce fundamentals of\nelectrochemistry and electrochemical engineering of rechargeable lithium ion batteries (LIBs) to undergraduate and\ngraduate students. The course will be reviewing working principles of LIBs, hands on experience on their assembly,\ncharge-discharge testing, data analysis and related safety aspects. Strong emphasis will be given on the Li-ion battery\ntechnology, nanotechnology implementation and the materials design. Beyond conventional Li-ion systems and Pb-acid\nbatteries, next generation Na-ion, K-ion and Li-S batteries will be discussed and designed. Students will be fabricating\nand testing high energy density batteries utilizing engineered electrodes, electrolytes and separators. Broader\nperspectives on sustainable, cost effective, longer lasting battery manufacturing will be provided. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHE56200",
    "Title": "Battery Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to introduce fundamentals of electrochemistry and electrochemical\nengineering of primary and rechargeable lithium ion batteries (LIBs) to undergraduate and graduate students. The\ncourse will be reviewing working principles of LIBs. Strong emphasis will be given on the Li-ion battery technology,\nprimary batteries, nanotechnology implementation and the materials design. Beyond conventional Li-ion systems and\nPb-acid batteries, next generation Na-ion, K-ion and Li-S batteries will be discussed. Students will be understanding\nenergy density calculations, fabrication and testing mechanism of batteries utilizing engineered electrodes, electrolytes\nand separators. Broader perspectives on sustainable, cost effective, longer lasting battery manufacturing will be\nprovided. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHE56400",
    "Title": "Organic Electronic Materials And Devices",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the synthesis, optoelectronic properties, transport physics, and device\noperation of organic and hybrid electronic materials and devices. This course will review how the molecular\narchitecture of small molecule and polymer semiconductors can be tuned to alter the optoelectronic properties of the\nmaterials in solution and in the solid state. A number of relevant materials interactions will be covered, including:\nphotoexcitation and recombination, intermolecular charge transport mechanisms, and energy transfer processes.\nAdditionally, we will observe how these processes are relevant to applications such as organic field-effect transistors\n(OFETs), organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), organic photovoltaic (OPV) devices, and organic memory elements.\nFinally, a new type of organic-inorganic hybrid material called hybrid halide perovskite will be introduced. Credits:\n3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CHE61000",
    "Title": "Advanced Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Properties of pure fluids and mixtures are described in the context of classical and statistical\nthermodynamics. Equations of state and solution theories are developed for this description of fluid phase equilibrium\nand chemical equilibrium. Fluids encountered in mass transfer and separation operations are treated. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHE61100",
    "Title": "Molecular Thermodynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course aims at providing a systematic treatment of the microscopic foundation of\nthermodynamics as well as a working knowledge of the statistical formalism needed to predict microscopic properties\nfrom molecular interactions. Topics covered include kinetic theory of gases, statistical-mechanical ensembles and their\ncorrespondence with thermodynamics, ideal and imperfect gases, distribution function theory of liquids, lattice models\nof liquid and polymer solutions, and molecular simulation methods. Offered in alternating years. Prerequisite: CHE\n61000. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "CHE62300",
    "Title": "Separation Processes",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Design of binary and multicomponent separation processes. Analysis and synthesis of adsorption,\nion exchange, and chromatography in packed beds, moving beds, simulated moving beds, and in cyclic operation.\nDesign and operation of membrane separation techniques including dialysis, reverse osmosis, ultrafiltration, and\ndynamic membranes.   },
  {
    "Course": "CHE63000",
    "Title": "Applied Mathematics For Chemical Engineers",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Determinants and matrices: solution of a system of algebraic equations; applications to\ndimensional analysis, stoichiometry, thermodynamics, kinetics of first order reaction systems, and stagewise\noperations. Differential equations: series solutions, Sturm-Liouville systems, boundary value problems, applications to\nheat and mass transfer and chemical reactor problems. Elements of complex variables: LaPlace and infinite Fourier\ntransforms, applications to heat and mass transfer problems. First order partial differential equations: applications to\nseparation processes, chromatography. Prerequisite: MA 26200. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHE63200",
    "Title": "Linear Operator Methods In Chemical Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Application of the spectral theory of linear self-adjoint and non-self-adjoint operators on abstract\nHilbert spaces to problems in chemical engineering. Symmetrizable non-self-adjoint problems in finite and infinite\ndimensional spaces with applications to physical and chemical rate processes in homogeneous and composite media.\nSolution of transport equations governing heat and mass transfer in deforming and chemically reacting media.\nIntroduction to non-self-adjoint problems in chemical engineering. Offered in alternate years. Prerequisite: CHE\n63000. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHE63300",
    "Title": "Probabilistic Methods In Chemical Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to probability, random variables, and stochastic processes. Ito calculus and stochastic\ndifferential equations. Brownian dynamics and Bridge processes. Applications to chemical engineering systems. Master\nequations and system size expansion concepts to nonequilibrium processes. Stochastic point processes and population\nbalance. Theory of fluctuations. Prerequisite: CHE 63000. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHE65600",
    "Title": "Advanced Process Control",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Topics in linear and nonlinear system theory applied to automatic control of processes. Subjects\ninclude stability analyses, phase plane methods, statistical disturbances, sampled systems, theoretical and experimental\ndetermination of process dynamics, optimization, and computer control. Prerequisite: CHE 45600. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CHE66200",
    "Title": "Catalysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Analysis of the kinetics of heterogeneous catalytic reactions, including the application of collision\nand transition state theories to the estimation of rate constants and calculation of rates over energetically nonuniform\nsurfaces. Discussion of the chemical and physical properties of solid surfaces that influence catalytic reactions, and\nillustration of concepts of catalytic behavior with specific examples from catalytic cracking, reforming, oxidation, and\nhydrodesulfurization. Offered in alternate years. Prerequisite: CHE 34800. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHE66600",
    "Title": "Methods In Catalysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Various spectroscopic and other techniques for characterizing catalysts and for probing the\nchemistry of solid surfaces and their interactions with adsorbing and reacting gases are discussed. Topics include\ninfrared, X-ray photoelectron, Mossbauer, and secondary ion mass spectroscopies. Emphasis is on understanding the\nprinciples underlying each method and gaining an awareness of the kind of information each can provide in a broad\nspectrum of research problems. Offered in alternate years. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {

    "Title": "Colloidal And Interfacial Phenomena",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Preparation, characterization, and stability of emulsions, aerosols, and other multiphase\ndispersions. Thermodynamics of\ninterfacial tension and adsorption. Applications to surfactants, polymers, biodispersions, flotation, separations, oil\nrecovery, etc. Offered in alternate years. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "CHM12901",
    "Title": "General Chemistry With A Biological Focus",
    "CreditHours": 5.0,
    "Description": "An accelerated and comprehensive one-semester general chemistry course that emphasizes\nprinciples that are important in biological systems. This course is designed to cover the essential elements of general\nchemistry traditionally covered in a two semester series. Topics to be covered include: Stoichiometry and chemical\nequations; atomic theory and structure; periodic properties; electronegativity; ionic and covalent bonding; non-covalent\nforces; bond energies; Lewis structures; molecular geometry; gases, liquids, and solids; solutions, quantitative\nequilibria in aqueous solution; acid/base chemistry and buffers; introductory thermodynamics; oxidation-reduction;\nelectrochemical and membrane potential; colligative properties; chemical and enzyme kinetics; nuclear chemistry;\ncoordination chemistry. One year of high school chemistry is required. Credits: 5.00"
  },

    "Course": "CHM33900",
    "Title": "Biochemistry: A Molecular Approach",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This is a comprehensive one-semester biochemistry course that emphasizes molecules and\nmolecular reaction mechanisms, building upon the principles conveyed in general chemistry and organic chemistry.\nThis course is designed to cover the essential elements of biochemistry traditionally covered in a two semester series.\nTopics to be covered include: Amino acids, peptides and proteins, molecular models and structure-function\nrelationships, enzymes, enzyme kinetics and enzyme mechanisms, carbohydrates and carbohydrate metabolism, aerobic\nmetabolism, lipids and membranes, lipid metabolism, nitrogen metabolism and integration and regulation of\nmetabolism. Special emphasis will be placed on connections between biochemical principles and the fields of\nmedicine, human health and disease, nutrition and biotechnology. This course should serve as excellent preparation for\nhigher-level biochemistry courses as well as standardized pre-health professional exams. CHM 33900 was designed as\nthe 4th semester of the 1-2-1 competency-based curriculum transformation in chemistry as it applies to pre-health\nprofessional and life science students at Purdue. However, this course is open to other students who meet the\nprerequisites. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CHM33901",
    "Title": "Biochemistry Laboratory",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "CHM 33901 is a laboratory course based on two modules from the Undergraduate Research\nInspired Experimental Chemistry Alternatives (URIECA) developed at MIT that are designed to introduce students to\ncutting-edge research topics in biochemistry. The course provides students with a research-inspired laboratory\nexperience that introduces standard biochemical techniques in the context of investigating a current research topic, for\nexample, acquired resistance to cancer drugs. Techniques include protein expression, purification, and gel analysis,\nPCR, site-directed mutagenesis, kinase activity assays, and protein structure viewing. CHM 33901 was designed as the\n4th semester of the 1-2-1 competency-based curriculum transformation in chemistry as it applies to pre-health\nprofessional and life science students at Purdue. However, the course is open to other students who meet the pre-\nrequisites. Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "CHM62200",
    "Title": "Chemical Aspects Of Mass Spectrometry",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A graduate-level treatment of chemical aspects of mass spectrometry. No prior knowledge in mass\nspectrometry is required. Prerequisite: Bachelor's degree in Chemistry. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHM62400",
    "Title": "Particle Spectroscopy",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to the application of ion and electron beams in the chemical analysis of gases and of\nsurfaces. Emphasis is on the unity of the phenomena that underlie the preparation, manipulation, and analysis of ion\nand electron beams and on the analogies between inelastic reactions of ions and electrons, including those with both\ngaseous and solid targets. Mass spectrometry is covered in some depth, and a number of newer aspects of particle\nspectroscopy are treated, including ion scattering spectrometry, Rutherford scattering, energy loss spectrometry (ion\nand electron), ion kinetic energy spectrometry, ion cyclotron resonance and Auger spectrometry. Applications of these\ntechniques feature structural analysis (compositions of mixtures, molecular structure of organics, electronic state\nassignment in simple ions), chemical preparations (ion implantation), and isotopic analysis. The underlying chemistry\nis explored, particularly in considering the kinetics and dynamics of unimolecular fragmentation and in terms of the\nfactors that affect the cross-sections of inelastic collisions. Offered in alternate years. Prerequisite: CHM\n42400. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHM62900",
    "Title": "Chromatographic Methods Of Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Principles underlying chemical separations are discussed, including mechanisms of selective\ntransport and zone broadening. Relations are shown between chromatography and electrophoresis, as well as other\nseparation methods. Current applications and current research activity in the field of chemical separations are included.\nPrerequisite: CHM 42400. Permission of department required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CHM63200",
    "Title": "Membranes: Structure And Function",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The structure and molecular properties of biological membranes and appropriate model systems.\nOffered in alternate years. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "CHM63400",
    "Title": "Biochemistry: Structural Aspects",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Chemistry of materials of biochemical interest; carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, amino acids,\nnucleic acids, porphyrins; biochemistry of blood. Prerequisite: CHM 26200, CHM 32100, CHM 37400. Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Thermal And Energy Sciences",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course includes applications of thermal science and energy fundamentals to civil engineering\ntopics.     "Course": "CE40800",
    "Title": "Geographic Information Systems In Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an introduction to the application of geographic information systems (GIS) to\ncivil engineering problems. GIS is a tool for analysis, modeling, and evaluation of civil engineering problems. The\ndesign of spatial databases, assembly of requisite data, and the development of analysis tools within GIS are presented.\nThis course will address: definition of spatial data, data types, spatial relationships, computer operation on spatial data,\ntopology in spatial data, representation of features in a GIS, data models, data dictionaries, data capture techniques;\ndatabase types, composition of spatial queries, analysis of engineering data using a GIS, complex analysis of polygon\nand linear features, presentation of results, use of a GIS as an engineering model test bed. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "CE41300",
    "Title": "Building Envelope Design And Thermal Loads",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course discusses the basic thermal processes in buildings and presents comprehensive\nmethods for thermal design of envelope assemblies in commercial and residential buildings. The first part of the course\nincludes steady-state transient conduction through envelope assemblies, convection and radiation heat transfer in\nbuildings, solar radiation and solar gains, thermal performance of windows, internal gains, ventilation and infiltration.\nThe second part of the course considers surface and room energy balance equations and presents analytical and\ncomputational models for calculation of hourly heating and cooling loads throughout the year. Climate-based standards,\npassive solar design, advanced energy guides, and innovative technologies for high performance buildings are"

    "Course": "CE41400",
    "Title": "Building Mechanical And Electrical System Design",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course covers the design of building mechanical and electrical systems. In the first part of the\ncourse students learn principles of designing and integrating heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems into\nbuilding air delivery systems, mechanical cooling and heating technologies, duct design and layout, blower and pump\nselection, and hydronic systems. They also learn to design heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems within the\nconstraint of achieving satisfactory occupant thermal comfort in buildings. The second part of the course covers design\nconcepts related to building electrical systems; including, single and three-phase power systems, motors, transformers,\nswitching, and relays. The course includes a design project related to mechanical and electrical systems for a\ncommercial building. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CE51300",
    "Title": "Lighting In Buildings",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course focuses on the design of illumination systems in buildings (electric and natural\nlighting) in order to achieve energy efficiency and visual comfort. The first part of the course includes analytical\nlighting calculation techniques, visual perception, radiative transfer, lamp characteristics, electric lighting system\ndesign and control for calculation of required indoor illuminance levels. The second part of the course covers\ndaylighting (natural lighting) systems, including state-of-the-art daylighting prediction models as well as design and\ncontrol of such devices and advanced metrics. The course also has a lab section, in which the students learn how to\nwork with lighting and daylighting tools and build their own computational transient lighting models in open\nprogramming languages, in order to design illumination systems and predict electricity consumption and potential\nenergy savings. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "CE54700",
    "Title": "Transport Processes In Surface Waters",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Four main topics are covered: (1) density-stratified two-layer systems in lakes and channels, with\napplications to mixed-layer growth, oil-spill containment, salinity intrusions, (2) advection-diffusion modeling in\nchannels, including analytical solutions to steady and unsteady, one- and two-dimensional problems, (3) mechanisms of\ndiffusional transport, including turbulence in channels and longitudinal shear dispersion, and (4) near-field analysis of\ndischarges, including similarity analyses of jets and plumes.     "Title": "Earthquake Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The objectives of the course are to: (1) expose the fundamentals of structural design in earthquake\nregions; (2) explain the functions of linear, nonlinear, and limit analyses with respect to design; (3) describe the\ncomplex relationships between ground motion models and structural response models in the linear and nonlinear\nresponse ranges; and (4) provide the students perspectives about the behavior of building structures in the earthquake\nenvironment. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Title": "Prestressed Concrete Design",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Behavior and design of prestressed concrete structures, prestress losses, composite construction,\nflexure and shear design, deflections, and special topics. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CE57300",
    "Title": "Structural Dynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Analysis of structural members and systems subject to dynamic loads such as wind and earthquake\nloads; basic theory for single-degree-of-freedom and multi-degree-of-freedom analytical models of civil engineering\nstructures; free vibration, harmonic and transient excitation, foundation motion, resonance spectrum, Lagrange's\nequation, modal analysis, lumped parameter methods, computer methods. Credits: 3.00"

    "Description": "Theory, methods, and techniques for experimental studies of structural members and systems.\nMeasurements fundamentals; transducers for measuring strain, displacements, force and torque, pressure, and\ntemperature.   {
    "Course": "CE59601",
    "Title": "Entrepreneurship And Business Strategy In Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course offers students the opportunity to learn and apply the core skills required to build and\ngrow engineering- and technology-based businesses through lecture, case discussions, and weekly activities tied to a\nsemester-long team project. Course content includes market analysis techniques to link technology attributes to\nopportunity and vice versa, combinatorial business design and planning methods, strategic innovation theories,\ncompetitive analysis, methods of emergent strategy and risk mitigation, as well as examination of team building, firm\ninfluence and navigation, and organizational design principles. Emphasis throughout is placed on the implications of\nresearch and development uncertainty, long-lifecycle economics, and the management of subcontracts and multi-\ndisciplinary teams often encountered when developing and delivering complex engineering outputs. Case studies are\nused to contrast the challenges faced when creating new businesses (entrepreneurial) with those encountered in\nattempts to grow an existing enterprise (intrapreneurial). Coursework and project activities also facilitate development\nof business acumen, and skill building in conceptual thinking, synthesis, and persuasive communication. This course is\nparticularly relevant for engineering students intending to progress into managerial roles in technology or R&D driven\norganizations. This course can be counted toward the College of Engineering Minor in Innovation and\nTransformational Change and the Burton D. Morgan Center for Entrepreneurship (BDMCE) Certificate in\nEntrepreneurship and Innovation. Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Behavior Of Metal Structures",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Study of the behavior of metal structural components and metal structural systems. Primary emphasis is\nplaced on the behavior of steel structures, although other metal systems also are discussed. Specific topics include\nmaterial behavior, manufacturing processes, fatigue and fracture, bolting and welding procedures, and repair and\nretrofit techniques. Course material is augmented with a number of case studies. Prerequisite: CE 59100. Credits:\n3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CE68901",
    "Title": "Plasticity Theory",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The course covers stress analysis, strains analysis, elastic and inelastic constitutive relations, with\nemphasis on plasticity, and the solution of plastic boundary-value problems for a wide range of materials, including\nmetals, soils and alloys of various types. Specific topics covered by the course include: tensors, stress analysis, strain\nanalysis, laws of thermodynamics, basic concepts from elasticity, viscoplasticity as an extension of viscoelastic\nconcepts, classical plasticity, principle of maximum plastic dissipation, Drucker's inequality, yield function and yield\nsurface, flow rule, hardening rule, classical models (Tresca, Von Mises, Mohr-Coulomb, Drucker-Prager), bounding-\nsurface plasticity, thermodynamics and constitutive models, causes of plasticity at the microstructural level, noncoaxial\nplasticity, limit analysis, method of characteristics (slipline method) and cavity expansion analysis. Prerequisite: AAE\n55300 or ME 61200. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "CLPH43500",
    "Title": "Pediatric Pharmacotherapy",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This elective course will focus on the pharmacotherapeutics and pathophysiology of the more\ncommon disorders that apply to the pediatric population. The purpose of the course is to discuss the relevant\ndifferences between the adult and pediatric population in regards to the diagnosis, treatment options, desired\ntherapeutic outcomes and therapeutic drug monitoring parameters. Instruction will be provided through a combination\nof lectures, case discussions, homework assignments, and group presentations. Credits: 2.00"

    "Description": "This course is intended to complement instruction of other courses in the second professional year\nof the Doctor of Pharmacy curriculum and to review many of the topics previously addressed in the Integrated\nPharmacotherapy courses and Professional Program Laboratories. It is hoped that students who elect this course will\nenhance their development of a strong foundation of knowledge, clinical skills and abilities in order to meet the\nschool's professional outcome abilities. Team-based problem-solving methodology will be utilized to discuss patient\ncases related to topics covered in the IP sequence. Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "CLPH44900",
    "Title": "Introduction To Psychiatric Pharmacy Practice",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course that provides an overview of psychiatric pharmacy practice, introduction to stigma and\ndiversity issues in mental illness, and disease state overviews in a lecture format. In one class period, the students are\nable to interact with 4th year pharmacy students and/or pharmacy residents who have worked or are working in the area\nof psychiatric pharmacy. Four of the class periods also provide live presentations and interactions with persons living\nwith severe mental illness and mental health workers who work with them. Mental Health America of Tippecanoe\nCounty works with the instructor to schedule these live presentations. Students are assessed for attendance and\nparticipation and also for a reflection written about each class period. Credits: 1.00"
  },

    "Course": "CLPH45000",
    "Title": "Formulary Dossier Management",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course will focus on preparing students for competing in the annual Academy of Managed\nCare Pharmacy (AMCP) P&T Competition and is intended to give students a variety of experiences that will enhance\ntheir knowledge in analyzing complex therapeutic and pharmacoeconomic data, research and public presentation. The\ncourse offers an opportunity for students to engage in simulated formulary management by utilizing comparative\nstudies andcost-effectiveness analysis to make real-life decisions on whether or not to add a drug to hospital or health\nplan formulary. Students will be paired into teams with each team consisting of 4 students. Each team will work\nindependently to analyze the product dossier and prepare a monograph and presentation for the local and/or national\ncompetition. Course lectures will focus on information needed to accurately and adequately prepare students in\ncompleting the above noted tasks. Class participation is expected, and students will need to be able to engage in"

  {
    "Course": "CLPH45400",
    "Title": "Advanced Practice In Psychiatric Pharmacy",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The purpose of this course is to provide the student with knowledge and insight regarding the use\nof medications in persons with mental illness. Instruction will be provided in the following areas (but not limited to):\n(1) psychiatric disease states; (2) psychiatric medications - usual dosing, adverse effects, drug interactions; (3) clinical\nuse of psychiatric medications in psychiatric pharmacy practice; (4) useful and appropriate monitoring parameters; (5)\nthe interaction of medical illness in the treatment of psychiatric disorders; (6) strategies to improve medication\nadherence and minimize adverse events; (7) utilization of recognized treatment guidelines in clinical care. Case-based\nlearning will be utilized to emphasize important points in clinical use and monitoring of psychiatric medications and\ndisorders. Permission of instructor required. Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CLPH45700",
    "Title": "Pharmaceutical Care In Developing Countries",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This elective will emphasize the major disease states, rational drug selection, especially with a\nlimited medication formulary, desired therapeutic outcomes, and the provision of complete pharmaceutical care to\npatients in developing countries. The impact of drug therapy on health care, economics, and quality of life for diverse\npopulations will be emphasized. Students will prepare to provide care in a cross-cultural environment in which\nresources are limited. Instruction is provided through a combination of lectures, discussions, and presentations.\nEnrollment is limited to Doctor of Pharmacy students (068) DP-C status or by consent of course coordinator. Credits:\n2.00"
