  {
    "Course": "COM26099",
    "Title": "Professional Practice Parallel Co-Op Summer I",
    "CreditHours": 0.0,
    "Description": "Cooperative Education (Co-Op) is an academic program with oversight provided by assigned\nFaculty Coordinators who serve as the Instructor for participating students. Parallel Co-Op program participants are\nundergraduate students, who work part-time (more than 11 hours per week and less than 30 hours per week) in paid\npositions during the academic year terms (fall and spring semesters) for an employer with a local business or\noffice. During the summer term, Parallel Co-Op students work in part-time or full-time positions at any location\noffered by the employer. A minimum of a one-year commitment is required for Parallel Co-Op students and\nemployers. During the academic year, Parallel Co-Op students register for 6 to 11 credit hours of academic course\nload, and also for an appropriate 0-credit hour Parallel Co-Op course that carries half-time student status to recognize\nthe academic impact of the experience. The combination of both academic courses and Parallel Co-Op course\nregistrations provides students with full-time status. During the summer term, Parallel Co-Op students register for a\nzero-credit hour Parallel Co-Op Summer course that carries full-time student status. Permission of Instructor required.\nTypically offered Summer.Credits: 0.00"
  },

    "Course": "COM36000",
    "Title": "Forensics Practicum",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Forensics is the study and practice of evidence-based argumentation. This course cultivates skills\nassociated with researching and constructing arguments - and then applies these skills to contemporary societal, national,\nand global issues with an eye turned toward generating practicable solutions. Students will be required to move beyond\npassively consuming information to critically appraising information related to broadly general as well as highly specific\nand technical topics.     "Title": "Mock Trial Practicum",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course prepares students to represent Purdue University in American Mock Trial Association\ncompetitions by focusing on legal reasoning, argumentation, and advocacy. Students develop and\ndeliver opening statements, introduce and examine testimonial, physical, and demonstrative evidence, examine and\ncross examine witnesses, and develop and deliver closing statements.   {
    "Course": "COM46399",
    "Title": "Professional Practice Parallel Co-Op Semester III",
    "CreditHours": 0.0,
    "Description": "Cooperative Education (Co-Op) is an academic program with oversight provided by assigned\nFaculty Coordinators who serve as the Instructor for participating students. Parallel Co-Op program participants are\nundergraduate students, who work part-time (more than 11 hours per week and less than 30 hours per week) in paid\npositions during the academic year terms (fall and spring semesters) for an employer with a local business or\noffice. During the summer term, Parallel Co-Op students work in part-time or full-time positions at any location\noffered by the employer. A minimum of a one-year commitment is required for Parallel Co-Op students and\nemployers. During the academic year, Parallel Co-Op students register for 6 to 11 credit hours of academic course\nload, and also for an appropriate 0-credit hour Parallel Co-Op course that carries half-time student status to recognize\nthe academic impact of the experience. The combination of both academic courses and Parallel Co-Op course\nregistrations provides students with full-time status. During the summer term, Parallel Co-Op students register for a\nzero-credit hour Parallel Co-Op Summer course that carries full-time student status. Permission of Instructor required.\nTypically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 0.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

    "Course": "COM60000",
    "Title": "Foundations Of Human Communication Inquiry I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduces doctoral students to major and emerging approaches to understanding human\ncommunication and provides them with the theoretical background and analytic skills needed to navigate the tensions\namong these approaches.   },
  {
    "Course": "COM60811",
    "Title": "Leadership And Global Strategic Communication",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Over the last decade, the field of strategic communication has grown rapidly. The work of strategic\ncommunication professionals requires coordinated responses between distinct organizational units that are often\nseparated by time and space. These conditions necessitate effective leadership. Further complicating leadership in these\ncontexts is the fact that the work of strategic communication has increasingly become global in nature. This course\nprovides students with theoretical background in leadership and global strategic communication, as well as the\nopportunity to apply what they learn to strategic communication cases and to their own professional experiences. It also\nencourages them to think proactively about leadership challenges in these contexts and to articulate theoretically-\ninformed analyses and evaluations of leadership in action. Permission of department required. Typically offered Fall\nSpring Summer.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CPB61900",
    "Title": "Design, Conduct, And Analysis Of Clinical Trials",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Reviews the various types of clinical trials that are used in medical research (e.g., therapeutic and\npreventive). The stages and activities in a \"typical\" trial are defined along with factors that influence study design. Key\nelements of data collection, organization, analysis, and interpretation and reporting of results are discussed and\nillustrated using published reports of clinical trials. Differences in the design and conduct of trials in human and\nveterinary medicine are considered, including the ethical concerns and costs. Prerequisite: Graduate level course work\nin Biostatistics. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 2.00"
  },

    "Title": "Advanced Immunology",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Teaches advanced concepts in basic immunology and applications to disease prevention and\ntherapy.   {
    "Course": "CPB62500",
    "Title": "Clinical Biostatistics",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Intended for veterinary medical and biological science graduate students, this course is designed to\nfamiliarize them with the appropriate usage (and reporting) of different statistical tests in biomedical research. Students\nare taught the basic theories underlying the different tests, the data assumptions underlying the application of those\ntests, and review/critique published scientific articles that employed these tests. Students have the opportunity to\ndescribe the appropriate statistical methods to be used in their proposed research and/or report the usage or appropriate\nstatistical tests on their own data. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CPB62600",
    "Title": "Design And Analysis Of Epidemiologic Studies",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Focuses on epidemiologic study design and applications of statistical software to the analysis of\ndata derived from health research. Includes an overview of epidemiologic study designs, frequency and association\nmeasures, generalized linear models and survival analysis. Hands-on computer laboratories are provided using data\nderived from field studies. Prerequisites: One graduate level course in biostatistics. Typically offered Fall alternate\nyears.Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 4.0,

    "Course": "CPB86900",
    "Title": "Veterinary Public Health And Zoonoses",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "A survey of fundamental topics on diseases that are caused by viral, bacterial, rickettsial, and\nparasitic agents and are known to be transmissible from animals to humans, as well as those diseases that are common\nto humans and animals.   {
    "Course": "CPB88300",
    "Title": "Public Health",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed for senior veterinary students to fulfill their interests in public health and\npreventive veterinary medicine. There will be a classroom and field component, focusing on topics including\nepidemiology, food safety, infectious diseases, environmental health and health communications.     "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course examines both the traditional and contemporary forms of cybercrime, including\nhacking, insider threat, Internet child pornography, cyberbullying, hacktivism, and cyberterrorism.     "Description": "This course provides an introduction to high performance, cluster, and grid computing from a\nsystems perspective. The driving outcome for this course is for students to understand and apply high performance\ncomputing concepts, architectures, and software components to develop and operate a high performance computing\nenvironment. Topics include: high performance computer architectures, network architectures for High Performance\nComputing (HPC), commodity and open-source cluster architectures, and software systems. Typically offered Fall\nSpring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CNIT46100",
    "Title": "Parallel Data Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an introduction to the techniques and technologies used in high performance\ncomputing for developing, using and managing high performance data systems. Topics covered in this course will\nfocus on aspects of the design, implementation, and use of high performance storage systems progressively from the\nhardware layer through the operating system up to the application level. Topics will include: commodity hardware and\nnovel architectural storage components; the architecture and use of parallel file systems, including PVFS2 and Lustre;\nreliability and scheduling; virtualization and fault tolerant strategies for Petascale computing; system architectures for\ndata intensive computing and workflows; parallel I/O systems; and grid and cloud computing architectures. The driving\noutcome for this course is for students to understand and apply advanced high performance computing concepts,\narchitectures, and software components to develop and operate a high performance computing environment. Typically\noffered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "CNIT60100",
    "Title": "Applied Statistics In Information Technology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will survey the field of applied statistics in information technology. Students will gain\nhands-on experience running statistical analyses on samples from a variety of populations. Students will learn the\nprocess of data cleaning, data transforming/coding, identifying the appropriate statistical analyses (descriptive and\ninferential), as well as writing and interpreting the results. Specifically, this course will survey the following statistical\napproaches: correlations, t-test, analysis of variance, analysis of co-variance, factorial ANOVA, simple regression,\nmultiple regression, logistic regression, chi-square analysis, factor analysis, and nonparametric tests. In this course,\nstudents will be able to differentiate statistical analyses and identify appropriate statistical analyses depending on the\nresearch question and variables of interest. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "CGT10301",
    "Title": "Geometric Modeling Applications",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an introduction to the process of 3D geometric CAD modeling, and the\nconstruction techniques used in the creation of constraint-based solid and surface models used in engineering\ndisciplines. Part modeling and assembly modeling are included, as well as manipulation of the geometric model to\nderive variant designs. Emphasis is on the use of the engineering design process as a problem-solving method to\ncapture modeling behavior to enable the downstream use of 3D data in the overall product design process, and its re-\nuse in the product lifecycle. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "CGT27500",
    "Title": "Data Visualization II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides a practical introduction to exploratory data analysis and data mining to better\ninform data visualization applications. The course introduces a practical approach for making sense out of data.\nStudents are introduced to issues inherent to the data analysis process or data mining projects. The course covers: (1)\nhow to prepare data prior to analysis, (2) how to generate summaries of the data, (3) how to identify non-trivial facts,\npatterns and relationships in the data and (4) how to create models from the data to better understand the data and make\npredictions. After data is analyzed students will use the data visualization process and techniques to visually represent\nthe data. The course will also introduce the use of high-level programming languages for data analysis and data\nvisualization. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CGT34500",
    "Title": "Game Development III: Environment Modeling For Games",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(CNIT 33100) This course teaches the techniques and principles needed to create realistic three-\ndimensional virtual environments in game engines. The course will examine the principles of physics that determine\nhow light propagates through the world and is eventually perceived by a human eye. Global illumination techniques\nthat approximate these principles are described, followed by an in-depth examination of how game engines then\napproximate these solutions in order to create virtual environments that can run at real-time frame rates. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "CGT52000",
    "Title": "Computer Graphics Programming",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides a working knowledge of computer graphics programming using OpenGL and\nC++. OpenGL is the platform independent industrial standard APL and the leading edge technology for computer\ngraphics application design. It has been used in the gaming industry, as well as in research and for scientific\nvisualizations. The course focuses on creating real-time and interactive applications and is structured into several\nblocks; OpenGL introduction, modeling, texturing, transformations, lighting, and interactive application design.\nStudents will develop various applications through the course focusing different aspects of computer graphics\nprogramming. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CGT52100",
    "Title": "Advanced Real-Time Computer Graphics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course focuses on a working knowledge of real-time rendering and shaders using GPI.\nStudents will learn how to program advanced computer graphics techniques and how to benefit from the existing\ngraphics hardware in an efficient way. The main focus is on programming modern graphical processing units (GPUs)\nusing the GLSL, CG and OpenGL. Students will learn what the data-flow programming model is, and how to write\nvertex, geometry, tessellation, and fragment shaders. Another output is using texturing and lighting on the low level of\nthe GPU and the next step is to provide animations using vertex shaders. Advanced texturing techniques such as bump\nmapping or environment mapping will be explained. Permission of instructor required. Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

As"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CGT55500",
    "Title": "Game Development II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces students to the advanced concepts, technologies, skills that enable the\ncreation of sophisticated video games, simulations, and game systems. Students are taught using student-led, active-\nlearning pedagogy in which students co-develop and present lectures, demonstrations, and assignments for their peers,\nwith the facilitation of the course instructor. A thorough understanding of how game engines work is therefore a\nrequisite element of the game development process and lever for research in most domains involving interactive\nsimulations and games. As game engine development, research, and application is a large and complex topic, the\ncourse material is distributed across two semesters. In addition to the continuation of technical topics this course also\nemphasizes the experiential, conceptual, and aesthetic dimensions of game development, prioritizing implementation\ncompleteness with creative, aesthetically-pleasing implementations that are informed by current research. As research\nin this field continues to rapidly iterate, the latest findings are incorporated into each new offering of the course,\nrefreshing its content as the technology evolves in its implementation and theoretical underpinnings. Production of\noriginal research focused upon an aspect of game development or game engine design is required. Permission of\ninstructor required. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CGT56200",
    "Title": "Cognition And Human-Computer Interaction",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an overview of the role of human cognition in the use of interactive digital\ntechnologies. Students will learn fundamental theories and concepts of cognitive science that are relevant to interactive\ntechnology. The course takes a broad chronological approach, examining the history and development of cognitive\ntheories and models in the field of human computer-interaction (HCI). Students will read seminal works from leading\nresearchers in cognitive science and HCI. The course covers older well-established theories and models as well as\nnewer speculative ones. Students will develop a sound understanding of the origins, development, and future directions\nof cognition research in HCI. Topics covered include: classical cognition; the cognitive revolution; mediated cognition;\nactivity theory; situated action; embodied cognition; distributed, external, and extended cognition; enactive cognition;\nthinking and epistemic coping; make-believe and imagination; scaffolding and cognitive offloading; internal and\nexternal representations. Students are encouraged to make appropriate connections to their own research areas. No\nspecific technical or programming experiences is required. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides a working knowledge of general-purpose graphics processing unit computing\n(GPGPU) using CUDA, OpenCL, and C++.     "Course": "CGT64500",
    "Title": "Games Research",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course instructs students in current methods of conducting research on digital games,\nludology, and the game development process. The most current or impactful research in the field is presented,\nanalyzed, and extrapolated upon. The course surveys a wide variety of specific topics that shift as new research\nfindings are published. Previous topics have included: biofeedback, user experience evaluation in games, gameplay\nmeasurement and analysis, development pipelines, mathematical modeling of game design, publication strategies and\nmethodologies, scientific document preparation, and simulation. Quantitative and qualitative approaches to conducting\nresearch in the field of digital and traditional games.   },
  {
    "Course": "CGT67000",
    "Title": "Applications In Visual Analytics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Visual Analytics (VA) provides a fast way for people to make sense of large number of data, and\nhas applications in many sectors. This course will introduce Visual Analytics through foundational theories and a broad\nrange of techniques and tools, focusing on using visualization methods to reason and solve complex problems in a wide\nvariety of applications. Visual analytics is the science of analytical reasoning facilitated by interactive visual interfaces\nthat synthesize human and computational ability to attack large complex problems. It is concerned with analytical\nreasoning, interaction, data transformations, data visualization, analytic reporting, and technology transition. While the\ndifferent visual analytics applications share common theories and strategies, each of them has its unique data\ncomposition, visual representations, and analytical needs and strategies. Through survey and study a broad range of\nvisual analytics applications, students will be able to apply visual analytics on their own applications, analyze and\nbreak down a complex analytical problem into proper components and steps, evaluate different visual analytic\ntechniques and strategies, and finally design and develop an effective visual analytics solution toward the\nproblem. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 0.0,

  {
    "Course": "CGT69000",
    "Title": "Research Projects In Computer Graphics Technology",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "to 6.00. This course provides a means of independent study of a special problem under the guidance\nof a graduate faculty member who holds a terminal degree. It is assumed that projects in this course are research\nprojects independent of one's doctoral research. Although not required, it is likely that a major result of the course will\nbe a conference or journal publication.     "Description": "Undergraduate-level introduction to computer networks and data communication.     "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an integrated view of the key concepts of modern algorithmic data\nanalytics. It focuses on teaching principles and methods needed to analyze large datasets in\norder to extract novel, transformative insights for the underlying application. The course\nemphasizes the duality between formulating questions that can be answered by statistical\ndata analysis tools (the statistical perspective) and the algorithmic challenge of actually extracting such answers using\navailable parallel and distributed computational resources from massive datasets.     "Course": "CS47500",
    "Title": "Human-Computer Interaction",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The goal of this course is to teach students how to design useful and usable interactive systems that\naddress important needs of people. Students will experience the entire user-centered design life cycle, from need\nfinding to usability evaluation. Topics covered in the course include user-centered design principles, usability\nheuristics, need-finding methods such as semi-structured interviews and contextual inquiry, quick prototyping\ntechniques, usability evaluation methods such as hallway testing and human-subjects user study, and theories about\nuser interaction and decision making. As we are entering a new era of AI, the course will also include a brief\nintroduction on how to apply the HCI\nprinciples and techniques to AI-powered systems.This course is project-based. Students will form project teams among\nthemselves to work on a semester-long project and apply the user-centered design principles, theories, and\ntechniques that they have learned in class to build a useful and usable interactive system such as a mobile application.\nThis course is also highly interactive, including a series of design studios and in-class activities that require active\nparticipation, communication, and discussion with other students.Credits: 3.00"

This jointly\ntaught course introduces analytical methods from biology, statistics and computer science that are necessary for\nbioinformatics investigations.   {
    "Course": "CS56000",
    "Title": "Reasoning About Programs",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The course focuses on the logical foundations and algorithmic techniques used to ensure program\ncorrectness. With an emphasis on automated program verification and synthesis, the course covers classical concepts\nand techniques such as Hoare logic, abstract interpretation, abstraction-refinement and bounded model checking. The\ncourse also exposes students to approaches for program synthesis, a new frontier for program reasoning, such as\ninductive synthesis, synthesis using version space algebras, constraint-based synthesis and synthesis based on machine-\nlearning techniques. The courses emphasizes both theoretical foundations as well as hands-on experience with\nverification/synthesis tools and SAT/SMT solvers. Students are expected to have completed undergraduate\ncoursework in Foundations of Computer Science (CS 18200) or equivalent, Systems Programming (CS 25200) or\nequivalent, and Introduction to the Analysis of Algorithms (CS 38100) or equivalent. Mathematical maturity is\nexpected. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "CS57900",
    "Title": "Bioinformatics Algorithms",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Review of Genomes, DNA, RNA, proteins, proteomes. Biological Sequences: dynamic\nprogramming; pairwise global, local, and semi-global alignments of genes and proteins; constant, affine, and general\ngap penalties; RNA alignments; BLOSUM and PAM scoring matrices. Multiple alignment of proteins: approximation\nalgorithms; iterative and progressive alignment methods. Database search for sequences: BLAST and variants.\nPhylogenetic Trees: distance-based methods, ultrametric and additive distance functions; parsimony, and maximum\nlikelihood methods. Whole Genome Alignment: suffix trees and suffix arrays. Systems Biology: Module discovery in\nbiological networks, spectral algorithms for graph clustering. Network alignment: quadratic programming formulations\nand graph matching. Genetic Variation: haplotype inference, the perfect phylogeny problem and chordal graphs.\nAdditional topics such as next-generation sequencing, analysis of multidimensional data from flow cytometry, and gene\nexpression data, if time permits. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CS58400",
    "Title": "Theory Of Computation And Computational Complexity",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The theory of general purpose programming systems. Recursive and partial-recursive functions;\nrecursive and recursively enumerable sets. The Church-Turing thesis. The recursion theorem, Rogers' translation\ntheorem, Rice's undecidability theorem. The general theory of computational complexity: there are no general solutions\nto natural optimization problems. Complexity for specific models of computation: the polynomial complexity classes P,\nNP, and PSPACE; NP-hard and PSPACE-hard problems, inherently exponential problems. Typically offered\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CS58800",
    "Title": "Randomized Algorithms",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The area of randomized algorithms has grown from being a tool in computational number theory to\nfinding widespread application in algorithms in all areas of computer science. Two practical benefits of randomization\nare its simplicity and speed. Deep and important computational complexity connections have been developed, from\nbridging the gap between discrete and continuous optimization, bypassing deterministic barriers in online settings,\nsummarizing massive data in polylogarithmic space, probabilistically checkable proofs, privacy enhancing techniques,\nmodeling the web and other large networks, and sparsifying and compressing complicated combinatorial structures\nsuch as graphs. Randomization is an essential key ingredient in the algorithmic breakthroughs today and in the\nfuture. This course presents the basic concepts in the design and analysis of randomized algorithms and shows how to\napply them to algorithms for a wide range of problems. The course covers a broad range of problems benefitting from\nrandomized computation including data structures, graph algorithms, online algorithms, geometric algorithms,\nstreaming algorithms, derandomization techniques, and tools for probabilistic analysis of algorithms. Typically offered\nFall.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  },
  {
    "Course": "CEM45600",
    "Title": "Design-Build Project Delivery Method For Engineers",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course presents traditional project delivery methods and contrasts them with design-build\nproject delivery. The course focuses on the principles, tools, and procedures used in the design-build project delivery\nmethod. It provides students with sufficient education to become certified (following additional examination) by the\nDesign Build Institute of America as an Associate Member and dependent on employment experience, a full Member.\nTraditional project delivery methods, Design-Bid-Build, Construction Manager as Agent, 'Fast Track', and other 'rip\nand read' methods are losing popularity to project delivery methods that take a more collaborative approach.\nCollaboration requires a different way of thinking about a capital construction project and working with others in\nproject delivery. Constructors must move from a transactional, arms-length relationship where the project is viewed as\na low-price commodity to a full-suite delivery of services resulting in a high-value product. This requires collaboration\nwith the Owner and other members of the project delivery process, something that has been missing from traditional\nproject delivery methods. Active student participation is required. Student participation will be facilitated through\nassigned presentations, in-class projects, field trips to local projects, and guest lectures. Students who complete the\ncourse and achieve DBIA's minimum requirements (Fundamentals of Project Delivery, Principles of Design-Building\nProject Delivery, Post Award, and Contracts & Risk Management) will be eligible for recognition by DBIA. Credits:\n3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "CEM53100",
    "Title": "Facilities Engineering And Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides the student with an understanding of the issues related to facilities\nmanagement for owner organizations. The course is oriented toward upper class and graduate students familiar with the\ndelivery of capital construction projects and provides an owner's perspective of capital construction and ongoing\noperation. The course will focus on the total life-cycle cost of a capital construction project beginning with planning,\nbusiness rationale, economic analysis, and programmatic specifications. The owner's perspective on annual operating\ncosts will be examined including calculation of daily, weekly, monthly, and annual operating costs. The implications of\nstewardship and customer service will be reviewed and analyzed including the implications on total life-cycle costs.\nThe human resources implications of operating a facility will be reviewed including determination of staffing\nrequirements to meet various levels of service as well as tools and techniques to determine and manage contracted\nservices. Numerous case studies will be described and discussed which will demonstrate the importance of careful\nplanning and budgeting of annual and periodic maintenance. Issues of sustainability, regulations, and other legal factors\nwill be discussed and examined. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CEM53200",
    "Title": "Infrastructure Planning",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides the student with an in depth understanding of the issues related to\ninfrastructure planning, engineering, and economics. The focus will be on the prioritization, stewardship, management\nand decision-making roles within the engineering division of a large public works agency. Various infrastructure\nplanning concepts will be reviewed and discussed. Numerous case studies will be described and discussed, which will\ndemonstrate that in order to plan and implement a successful public works project, many controversial issues must be\nfaced and difficult problems must be solved. Decision-making at agency and other levels of government will be\ndiscussed with respect to reports prepared by planners covering engineering feasibility, environmental and social\nimpact assessments, and financial and economic analyses. Evolving modern planning issues will be introduced and\ndiscussed, including sustainability; environmental economics; environmental justice; uncertainty and risk-benefit\nanalysis; partnerships with private entities versus total privatization; and the optimum staff-mix utilization in-house\nversus outsourcing. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "CSR10300",
    "Title": "Introduction To Personal Finance",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will provide knowledge and skills for young adults to be active, informed, and rational\nmanagers of their financial life. The course will particularly address the following 4 areas of personal finance.\nManaging money: Why it's useful to plan ones financial affairs, budgeting, being an informed manager of ones money\nand consumer of financial products. Financing large items using savings and credit: Know how credit works, how to\nuse it wisely, and how to avoid over indebtedness. Learn savings strategies to maximize the growth of your money.\nUsing financial markets: What are the different ways to invest, and how to make them work for you and your\nobjectives (such as retirement). Managing risk: How to use financial tools (such as insurance) to protect yourself\nagainst risk. The course will emphasize age-relevant knowledge and practical advice, with the objective to help\nstudents make better financial decisions and adopt better financial behaviors for the long term. Typically offered Fall\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "CSR31500",
    "Title": "Relationship Selling",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course focuses on long term relationship selling. The course is organized around a seven step\nselling process which has proven to be effective. The course adds to this process some principles of marketing and\nbusiness strategy. The elements are necessary for the success of professional salesperson both in successful prospecting\nand making strategic choices as to how to allocate their time within the territory. Important to the learning process is\nactually practice of principles. Students will do various exercises of principles such as prospecting and negotiation. At\nthe end of the semester, students will hone the skills learned through the semester with a series of roll plays designed to\nput them in position of both seller and buyer. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CSR34400",
    "Title": "Fundamentals Of Negotiations",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to be relevant to the broad spectrum of bargaining \"problems\" that are\ntraditionally faced by the manager, sales personnel and financial advisors. The course explores the processes of\nbargaining and negotiation as social and managerial activities. Special emphasis will be given to the areas of\ninterpersonal and interpersonal and intergroup conflict, in addition to the interpersonal influence techniques and the\ntactics and strategies involved with improved bargaining and negotiation. The major purpose of the course is for each\nstudent to gain insight into his or her own negotiating style and to become a more effective negotiator, as well as a\nmore astute observer of social process. The course will involve extensive use of cases, role-plays, and related\nparticipative activities, enhanced by rigorous self-review and introspection. Typically offered Fall Spring\nSummer.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "CSR41600",
    "Title": "Retail Supply Chain Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Supply chain management is a set of approaches utilized to efficiently integrate all parties of the\nsupply chain to fulfill a request from a customer. Companies like Amazon, Zara, Walmart, Toyota, Dell, and Procter &\nGamble are proof that excellence in supply chain management is a must to achieve industry leadership. With increasing\ncompetition around the globe, supply chain management is both a challenge and an opportunity for companies. The\nmain goal of this course is to introduce you to the key concepts and techniques that will allow you to analyze, manage\nand improve supply chain processes for different industries. The course is a combination of lectures, case studies, in-\nclass exercises, and games with the goal of defining key tradeoffs that managers need to understand and evaluate to\nsuccessfully manage complex supply chains. Quantitative tools designed to evaluate these tradeoffs will be studied and\nused extensively throughout the course. Topics that will be covered in this course include: Managing inventory,\nforecasting in supply chains, the optimal design of the supply chain, transportation and distribution, bullwhip effects\nand dealing with uncertainty, sourcing and supply contracts.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "CSR69700",
    "Title": "Final Non-Thesis Paper",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "to 3.00. The curriculum of consumer behavior and family and consumer economics has evolved in\nthe past decades with the changing market trend to currently encompassing specializations for meeting the diverse and\nintegrated needs of individual consumers, their families, and communities. The non-thesis option is called to respond to\nthe increasing market demand for professionals who are able to solve practical issues in the field in addition to mere\nepistemological pursuits. This proposed new course is designed for the students from this option to organize their\nlearnings in the option in a way that provides propositions and strategies for addressing their topics of interest. Hence,\nthis course should be taken during the last semester of the student's Master's program. The students will work with their\nmajor advisors for the topic and design of the study.     "Course": "EAPS35200",
    "Title": "Structural Geology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course deals with the nature and evolution of structures in rock deformed naturally by flow\nand fracture, as deduced from experimental, theoretical and field studies. Specific topics include: structures in three\ndimensions using descriptive geometry and stereonets, field measurements of rock geometry, tensors, strain and stress,\nthe theory of brittle and plastic rock behavior, theory and field observation of folds and faults, structural analysis of an\noutcrop, the structure and mechanics of mountain belts.     "Course": "EAPS35300",
    "Title": "Earth And Planetary Surface Processes",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to a variety of topics in sediment transport and deposition, emphasizing linkages\nbetween active processes, landscape evolution, and the rock record.   {
    "Course": "EAPS35400",
    "Title": "Earth And Planetary Geophysics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will explore geophysical processes from the scales of individual stresses that deform\nrocks, to plate motions, to planetary-scale interiors and phenomena. Emphasis will be focused on sources of stress and\nhow this stress is manifested, heat transfer, and fluid processes. Seismic waves, gravity data, planetary shape, and what\ninformation they provide about the interior of solid planets will be discussed. The course material will be applied to\nEarth, other rocky worlds like the Moon and Mars, and icy moons like Europa and Enceladus. This course is an\nintroduction to geophysical processes and serves as a stepping-stone to upper level geophysics courses such as EAPS\n35200, EAPS 45000, and EAPS 55700.Credits: 3.00"

Prior course\nwork in introductory atmospheric science, second semester physics or thermodynamics is required. Typically offered\nFall.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "EAPS42501",
    "Title": "Physics Of Climate",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "To understand climate we describe and synthesize physical processes in the atmosphere and their\ncoupling to the ocean, ice, and land. We quantitatively explore climatology with an equal balance of physical principles\nand scrutiny of available modern data. Topics include: visualization of atmospheric/land surface/oceanographic\nclimatological data sets; theories of climate dynamics; and climate change. Beginning with radiative balance and\nsimple energy balance models, the course progresses toward understanding the effects of radiative-convective forcing\nand rotation on the fluid envelopes. Analysis of data in an interactive computer-enabled environment is an important\npart of the course. By the end of this course, the student should know how the Earth System behaves at large scales and\ngrasp the physical understandings of why.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "EAPS52900",
    "Title": "Modeling Ecosystems And Biogeochemical Cycles",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Process-based models are powerful tools for studying ecosystem dynamics and geochemical cycles\nin Earth System Sciences. In this course, we will explore how various components of ecosystems can be modeled\nfollowing principles of biology, physics, and chemistry. We will also examine techniques for using modeling to study:\n1) responses of the structure and functioning of ecosystems to changing climate, atmospheric composition,\nenvironmental conditions, and human activities; and 2) exchanges of major greenhouse gases (e.g., CO2, CH4, and\nN2O) between the atmosphere and the biosphere. During the course, we will go through the whole cycle of system\nmodeling approach including model conceptualization, formulation, parameterization, sensitivity and uncertainty\nanalysis, verification, and application. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "EAPS65200",
    "Title": "Folding Of Rocks",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Theory and application of finite strain to the study of folded rocks, with numerous illustrations\nfrom literature. Presentation of modern theories of folding and density instability of single- and multi-layered rocks,\nwith special emphasis on basic folding mechanisms. Treatment of linear viscous and power-law fluids. Second- and\nthird-order analysis of causes of basic fold forms, such as concentric, chevron and kink folds, and mullion structure.\nCauses of drag folds and reverse drag folds. Offered in alternate years. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

  {

    "Title": "Fracturing Of Rocks",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Description and analysis of joints and faults from the point of view of field geology and fracture\nmechanics. Three basic modes of fracture and their analogs in the Earth's crust. Also examined are structures, such as\nfolds, pressure solution surfaces, basins, and mountain ranges associated with faults. Offered in alternate years.\nPrerequisite: differential equations. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "EAPS65700",
    "Title": "Geophysical Inverse Theory",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Investigates problems of determining physical parameters of the earth from remote observations of\nwave and potential fields. The theoretical topics include spectral and singular value decompositions, maximum\nlikelihood and stochastic inversion, Backus and Gilbert theory, Green's function and linear operators, and the physics of\nlayered media. Geophysical applications include seismic tomography, deconvolution, gravity and magnetics,\nearthquake sources, geodetics, and remote sensing. Offered in alternate years. Prior course work in advanced\ndifferential equations, physics, and chemistry of the earth is required. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

  },
  {
    "Course": "ECON16500",
    "Title": "The Marketplace Of Economic Ideas Honors",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Every day, every one of us makes choices and engages in social interactions, including exchange.\nWe do this within a context of institutions - formal rules and informal norms that shape our incentives. The outcomes\nthat emerge, and the value we create in the process, depends on those institutions and incentives. Economics is a broad\nand diverse body of ideas that helps us understand those everyday choices and the kinds of outcomes they generate. We\nwill explore these economic ideas and the ways that institutions affect outcomes, from informal social norms all the\nway to big questions of social organization such as the contrast between capitalism and socialism. Our main method of\nexploring economic ideas will be communicating those ideas - through writing, video, and other multimedia\napproaches; we will build and deepen our understanding of economic ideas in society by explaining them, applying\nthem, and sharing them with others. Course readings will include work by some of the most eloquent and effective\neconomics communicators over the past 250 years up to today. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "ECON26000",
    "Title": "Data Visualization And Inference",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Economics 260 is a self-contained introduction to statistics with economic applications. The goals\nof this course are to help students develop a working knowledge of data production and interpretation in an economics\ncontext, recognize the fundamental interconnectedness of economics and data, and introduce the basic concepts in\nstatistics needed for further study of econometrics and provide basic preparation for ECON 36000. Topics include the\norganization, analysis, and interpretation of data; descriptive statistics; probability theory; sampling distributions;\ninference and hypothesis testing; and simple linear regression analysis. The approach of the class includes both learning\nthe concepts behind basic statistics and also how to apply these concepts to make data-informed, real-world economic\ndecisions. Students will become familiar with the common statistical techniques and databases for analyzing data by\nusing both hand-calculations and STATA to analyze data. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

We will analyze economic regulation in both fuels and electricity,\ndeveloping the economic theory of regulation and exploring how regulation affects the decisions and behavior of\nregulated firms differently in the two different types of energy industries.     "Course": "ECON32500",
    "Title": "Economics Of Sports",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This class applies economic principles to the professional sports entertainment industry and its\nderivative input markets. The class begins by examining the microeconomics of demand for (by fans) and supply of (by\nteams) sports entertainment. The labor markets for the primary input, athletic talent, receive significant attention.\nCoordination among economic agents, taking the forms of leagues, players' unions, and government, is considered at\nthe end of the class, with an emphasis on how they affect the efficiency of the markets related to sports entertainment."

    "Course": "ECON36000",
    "Title": "Econometrics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course examines the statistical techniques economists use to analyze data, estimate causal\neffects, make predictions, and test economic theory. It emphasizes estimating multiple regression models including\nmodels of firm output, product prices, and wages. Students learn to make statistical and practical inferences about the\ntrue causal relationships. The course covers the data analysis skills required for careers as a consultant, financial\nanalyst, researcher, or economist in the private and public sectors. The skills practiced in the course include using\nstatistical software to analyze data. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ECON36100",
    "Title": "Antitrust And Regulation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course studies the influence of laws and regulations on market performance and on the\nfunctioning of a free-enterprise system. The focus is on two types of government policies: antitrust law and economic\nregulation. Antitrust laws define the rules by which firms are supposed to compete. Regulations may require that firms\nobtain approval to set prices, change prices, or enter new markets. They may require firms to adhere to environmental\nor safety standards. The focus is on current topics in both areas, including comparison of U.S. practice with that of\nEuropean Union and elsewhere. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECON36200",
    "Title": "Health Economics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to introduce upper level undergraduate students in economics to the field of\nhealth economics. We will analyze health and health care theories, institutions, and key policy issues using tools from\nintermediate microeconomic theory. The course begins with an analysis of health care as a commodity and why health\nis different from other consumer goods. The course then examines the demand for and the production of health and\nhealth care, and the behavior and organization of health care providers. The discussion then switches to information\nasymmetries and the functioning of health insurance markets. Afterwards, the course turns to the analysis of\ngovernment involvement in the health care system. The class concludes with an examination of medical care systems\naround the world, paying particular attention to the U.S. health care system.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECON36700",
    "Title": "Law And Economics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "It has become increasingly clear to economists, legal scholars and political scientists that it is\nimpossible to understand economic institutions without first having an understanding of the legal framework within\nwhich they operate. Similarly, it is impossible to understand the impact of law on society without first having an\nunderstanding of economic principles. This problem is further complicated by the fact that there are often ambiguities\nin the written law that lead to significant differences between what the law appears to say and how the law is\ninterpreted in the courts. This course is designed to give the student an understanding of both legal and economic\nprinciples and the relationship between them. Finally, through the use of economic analysis, the student will acquire the\ntools to predict the likely outcomes of particular laws and how they will affect their family and business decisions.\nTypically offered Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "ECON51000",
    "Title": "Game Theory",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Game theory is a powerful tool that facilitates a decision making process of individuals. Games are\ncharacterized usually by two or more players where any player's action has an impact on other players' payoff. Players\nare decision making units, e.g. individuals, firms, workers, managers, countries etc. Game theory analyzes situations in\nwhich people (or other animals) interact by breaking these situations down into basic descriptions of the set of players,\nthe strategies available to these players, and the payoffs that the players receive for different combinations of strategy\nchoices. Permission of department required. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 2.00"

    "Description": "Personnel Economics applies micro- and macroeconomic theory to the workings of the labor\nmarket while maintaining a focus on incentives in the workplace.     "Course": "ECON56200",
    "Title": "Econometrics I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This masters-level course in econometrics covers the tools that will enable students to conduct\nempirical analysis using economics data. The course examines the statistical techniques used in testing economic\ntheories, estimating casual effects, and making predictions. Emphasis is placed on estimating a single equation (e.g., a\ndemand function) and the problems associated with such estimation. As part of the course, students will estimate\nequations using STATA, a statistical software package. Permission of department required. Typically offered\nFall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECON56500",
    "Title": "Law And Economics",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to give the student an understanding of both legal and economic principles\nand the relationship between them. It will also show the student how to access various data bases, Lexis/Nexis, to get a\nformal statement of the law and how the laws have actually been interpreted and enforced. Finally, through the use of\neconomic analysis, the student will acquire the tools to predict the likely outcomes of particular laws and how they will\naffect their family and business decisions. Permission of department required. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECON57200",
    "Title": "Econometrics II",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course reviews basic concepts in probability, mathematical statistics and linear algebra in\norder to obtain a more rigorous understanding of the linear regression model, its representation and assumptions,\nprocedures for estimation and properties associated with the OLS estimator. We move on and apply what we have\nlearned to the linear regression model. We discuss estimation and prediction, establish properties such as efficiency,\nunbiasedness, consistency and convergence in mean square. We conclude by considering a few nonlinear models\nappropriate for modeling binary outcomes. Permission of department required. Typically offered Fall Spring\nSummer.Credits: 2.00"
  },

    "Course": "ECON57400",
    "Title": "Microeconometrics",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This is a graduate-level course in microeconometrics. This course is primarily related to the\nspecification and estimation of various models commonly encountered in microeconomic applications. The course will\nfirst briefly cover the theory of maximum likelihood estimation (MLE), and apply MLE in some introductory settings.\nThese methods will then be applied to various latent-variable economic models including binary choice models (the\nlogit, probit, and other alternatives), censored regression models (e.g., the tobit) and models for count data. Permission\nof department required. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 2.00"

    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. This course explores human economic behavior, with a strong emphasis on laboratory and\nfield experiment methodology used in behavioral economics research. The object of this course is to provide the computational\nframework necessary to appreciate and understand how to make decisions based on sound financial reasoning.\nECON 60000 - Teaching Economics",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "to 3.00. This course traces the development of economic theory from the Mercantilist writers\nthrough the contributions of J. S. Mill and Karl Marx. Topics covered include the development of value theory\n(especially labor theories of value), theories of economic growth and business cycles, the classical debate over the\nmeaning and validity of Say's Law, and changing views regarding the appropriate role of government in the\nmarketplace. In each case, the contributions of the authors considered are evaluated in light of our modern\nunderstanding of economic theory. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 1.00 to 3.00"

  },
  {
    "Course": "ECON62400",
    "Title": "Estimating Game Theoretic Models",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. This course examines topics in empirical industrial organization (I.O.), which aims to use\ndata to draw conclusions about how market and firm structure, firm conduct, and market performance interact in\nimperfectly competitive markets. We will take a \"structural\" approach, focusing on estimating the parameters of game\ntheoretic models using real industry data, and then simulating those same models to generate predictions under\nalternative (\"counterfactual\") scenarios. We will cover theory only to the extent that it provides intuition or testable\nconclusions. The course is divided into two unequal parts. In the first part, we will learn about static games in the\ncontext of mergers, market power, and entry. In the second part, we will focus on the estimation of dynamic games,\nafter first understanding how to solve and estimate dynamic single-agent problems."
  },

  {
    "Course": "ECON65300",
    "Title": "Topics In Early Childhood Development",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. This course is the second in the Ph.D. Labor Economics sequence. We will focus on the\neconomics of skill formation and its consequences on later outcomes like schooling choices, health, social behaviors\nand labor market variables. We will do this, by analyzing both static and dynamic settings, in which we recognize that\nskill formation is a process where early inputs affect the productivity of later ones. This course will be econometrically\nintense, covering from reduced form techniques to structural ones. We will pay special attention to econometric\nidentification of effects and the analysis of skills as unobserved heterogeneity, its consequences on empirical estimation\nand models to address it. This course will emphasize the connection between theory and practice."

  },
  {
    "Course": "EDCI36501",
    "Title": "Teaching Science Through Design In Grades K-2",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "One of the primary goals of this course is to provide you with opportunities to enhance your\npedagogical knowledge and skills so that you can become a culturally inclusive and effective science teacher. Hence,\nlearning to teach science in this class will involve conceptualizing science as a verb and not as a noun. To make the\ndistinction more precise, we prefer to use the term critical crosscultural science education instead of science education\nwhen referring to the teaching and learning of science in the increasingly culturally diverse context of schools in the\nUS. Critical cross-cultural science education is defined as the process of actively engaging students in collaborative\ninquiry about what science is; whose interests are served by science; who decides what science is and what gets funded\nas science; and what kinds of individual and collective roles individuals could play as informed and responsible citizens\nin supporting the advancement of science to benefit society. Admission to teacher education required. At least 9 credits\nof science content courses required. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "EDCI36502",
    "Title": "Teaching Science Through Design In Grades 3-6",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,

Students\nwill engage in science and engineering learning experiences; identify and analyze children's ideas and background\nexperiences; and examine instructional strategies for leveraging students' sense making. Using this knowledge, students\nwill plan for and implement standards-based lessons, reflecting on the strengths and areas of improvement of their\ninstruction for grade 3 through 6 learners. At least 9 credits of science content courses are required. Typically offered\nFall Spring Summer.Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "EDCI53300",
    "Title": "Teaching And Learning Number And Operations.",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to provide opportunities for mathematics educators to develop\nunderstanding of teaching and learning in the domain of number and operation. Central to this work is the construction\nof models of learners' understanding of number and operation and the use of those models to build and select\ncurriculum. While curricular efforts have historically taken as central a formal view of mathematics and its\nconstruction, more recently curriculum has been written to engage learners and to build from knowledge of learners'\nunderstanding. In this course we will develop models of learner's understandings of different facets of number and\noperation and then use those models and our emerging understanding of curriculum to explore challenges in teaching\nand learning. Typically offered Fall Spring SummerCredits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "EDCI53400",
    "Title": "Teaching And Learning Geometry And Measurement",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to provide opportunities for mathematics educators to develop\nunderstanding of teaching and learning in the related domains of geometry and measurement. Central to this work is the\nconstruction of models of learners' understandings of geometry and measurement and the use of models to design\ninstruction. Geometry, as a discipline in school mathematics, has historically and more currently been debated. In this\ncourse we will explore research in the teaching and learning of geometry and measurement. A synthesis of select\nliterature will inform our efforts to develop models of learners' geometric reasoning and understanding of measurement.\nWe will move past the development of models to the design of instruction meant to support understandings of concepts\nthat utilizes technology. Typically offered Fall Spring SummerCredits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "EDCI54800",
    "Title": "Teaching Mathematics To Diverse Learners",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to provide opportunities for in-service teachers to engage around issues of\nequity in mathematics education. Equity here is used as a broad construct intended to help us think about how to\nprovide meaningful opportunities to learn for all the students in our mathematics classrooms. The notion of \"diverse\"\nhere is also taken broadly. All students have special needs, but it is sometimes helpful to think about the needs of\nparticular groups of students while at the same time avoiding reducing differences among students to stereotypes.\nIssues of diversity here include, but are not limited to race, culture, gender, disabilities, language, SES, and sexual\norientation.     "Title": "Engineering And Technology Design Practicum",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "EPICS is a service-learning design course in which teams of students from across campus work\ntogether on long- term projects that benefit the community. Project work centers around the engineering,\ntechnology, and computing needs of a community partner, but interdisciplinary team interaction is an integral\nelement for project success. Students may participate in EPICS multiple semesters and participation for multiple\nconsecutive semesters on a project team is encouraged. Teams are composed of first year students through seniors.\nMost EPICS projects last at least one-year, though partnership with the community organization continues for several\nyears. Projects are intended to solve real problems, are defined in partnership with their community partners, and span\nthe complete design process cycle [problem identification - specification development - conceptual design - detailed\ndesign - delivery - service/maintenance - retirement].\nYou receive academic credit for participating in EPICS. How academic credits are applied to your major depends on\nyour degree program and is determined by your department and/or advisor.\nSee https://engineering.purdue.edu/EPICS/purdue/epics-purdue/credit.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "EDPS24800",
    "Title": "Differentiating Curriculum And Instruction",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course provides a solid foundation and set of principles for differentiating curriculum and\ninstruction in any classroom at any grade level. Students will explore a variety of evidence-based strategies, tools, and\ncurriculum models that effectively meet the diverse needs of all learners. Through readings, online class meetings and\ndiscussions, case studies, differentiated instruction examples, direct application, and reflection, students will deepen\ntheir understanding and need to differentiate. With an overarching goal of increasing achievement and developing\nstudent talents, this course includes the following major components:\n\u2022 creating positive learning environments that support a) high-quality curriculum; b) diagnostic, formative, and\nsummative assessments to inform instructional decision-making; and c) flexible grouping\n\u2022 addressing student differences in readiness, interest, and learning profile (including learning preference,\nintelligence preference, gender, culture, language preference, locale, and opportunities to learn) and\nappreciating how these differences influence the ways in which students learn\n\u2022 understanding that the process of differentiation involves modifying content, process, product, learning\nenvironment, and/or affect\n\u2022 incorporating higher-order thinking skills, creative problem solving, project-based learning,\nauthentic/respectful tasks, collaborative learning, and other evidence-based strategies to promote student\nachievement and talent development\n\u2022 understanding how differentiation of curriculum and instruction fits within specific educational interventions\nand models, such as scaffolding, flexible grouping, Response to Intervention (RtI), and Multi-Tiered System\nof Support (MTSS)\nEffective teachers do more than teach content; they teach unique individuals who enter classrooms with various levels\nof expertise, skills, abilities, social-emotional needs, and learning expectations. Effective teachers differentiate\ncurriculum by personalizing content based on the particular needs and interests of their students. Effective teachers\ndifferentiate instruction by applying various grouping strategies, technology applications, and thinking skills. The goal\nof every effective teacher is that every child learns something new every day. Cannot be taken concurrently with EDPS\n24000. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "EDPS30102",
    "Title": "Social-Emotional Aspects Of Learning In Diverse Environments",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The course examines the role of social emotional competence in learning and builds\nunderstandings of the inter-relationships between theory, empirical evidence, and instructional practice. It takes the\nperspective that experiences across different learning contexts are interrelated and may influence each other in\nreciprocal ways. The course views social-emotional dimensions of learning as: embedded in person-environment\ntransactions; tied to specific instructional (formal and/or informal) contexts over time; co-evolving with cognition and\nlanguage; critical to psychological, behavioral, and learning outcomes. The focus is on intersection of social-emotional\ncompetence, learning, and instruction. The course is intended to provide the foundations (theoretical and empirical) that\ncan help those interested in formal and informal instructional environments make informed educational decisions by\nconsidering the social-emotional dimensions of learning.     "Description": "Happiness and Well-Being: An Introduction to Positive Psychology is an undergraduate course\ndesigned to provide students with an introduction to the field of positive psychology while also learning valuable,\nimpactful life skills that can improve individual well-being, resilience, flow, happiness, and mindfulness for those\nenrolled.     "CreditHours": 1.0,

    "Course": "EDPS34100",
    "Title": "Introduction To Philosophical Underpinnings And Concepts Of\nApplied Behavior Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is the first of four courses in the Applied Behavior Analysis pathway for\nundergraduates in teacher licensure programs and is also part of the course content required to become a Board\nCertified Assistant Behavior Analyst (BCaBA). The course will provide an introduction into the primary concepts and\nprinciples of applied behavior analysis. Students will be introduce to the fundamental knowledge and experiences for\nunderstanding Applied Behavior Analysis principles, concepts, and techniques, including operant behavior,\nreinforcement, punishment, choice, antecedent stimulus control, and verbal behavior. Students learn concepts and\nprinciples to increase or decrease target behavior, to facilitate behavior maintenance and generalization, and to evaluate\neffectiveness of instruction. This course includes a field placement.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "EDPS34200",
    "Title": "Applied Behavior Analysis - Assessment And Intervention",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is one of four courses in the Applied Behavior Analysis pathway for undergraduates in\nteacher licensure programs and is also part of the course content required to become a Board Certified Assistant\nBehavior Analyst (BCaBA). This course offers the interventionist with the techniques for designing, implementing, and\nevaluating instructional and behavioral interventions grounded in the theories of applied behavior analysis.\nSpecifically, the learner will be exposed to techniques for measuring target academic, behavior, social and adaptive\nskills, as well as methods for displaying and interpreting data. Additionally, learners will design interventions, and\nmonitor progress and will be exposed to the foundational concepts and methods of ABA including defining behaviors,\ncollecting data, and understanding the three-term contingency of behavior. This course includes a field\nplacement.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "EDPS40099",
    "Title": "Topics In Design Based Research, Assessment And Evaluation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Design-Based Research (DBR) is inquiry that is driven by educational practice- the desire to\nunderstand and improve the practice of teaching and learning. Learning scientist employ DBR in order to implement\ninnovative designs for teaching and learning in a variety of formal and informal educational settings (e.g., schools,\nmuseums, and extramural clubs) and to conduct research no teaching and learning that occurs in the context of their\ndesign innovations.   },
  {
    "Course": "EDPS40200",
    "Title": "K-12 Reading Methods For Exceptional Learners",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to meet the expectations of CEC, NCTQ, and REPA 3 and prepare students\nin the science of reading for exceptional learners (including students with dyslexia and those with intensive needs) in\nTiers 2 and 3. This course will provide implementation details on Response to Intervention (RTI) and Multi-tiered\nSystems of Support (MTSS). The course will present strategies and programs used in strategic and intensive\nintervention efforts for those learners needing additional, unique, and/or more focused remediation efforts. Topics will\ninclude understanding reading intervention research, the behavior analytic and learning science's contributions to\nunderstanding the reading process, the sequence of learning to read (systematic instruction), reading to learn, and the\nfive components of reading instruction for both K-3 and 4-12 learners. This course will specifically address the REPA\n3 Standard: Focused work using \"interventions that are direct, explicit, and multi-sensory\" as a component of\nscientifically-based reading. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 2.00"

    "Course": "EDPS44200",
    "Title": "Advanced Intervention In Applied Behavior Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is one of four courses in the Applied Behavior Analysis pathway for undergraduates in\nteacher licensure programs and is also part of the course content required to become a Board Certified Assistant\nBehavior Analyst (BCaBA). This course will provide fundamental knowledge and experiences for understanding\ninstructional and behavior interventions grounded in the principles of Applied Behavior Analysis including pivotal\nresponse training, functional communication training, video modeling, self-management, social skills training, and\naugmentative and alternative communication (AAC). Students learn procedures to increase or decrease target behavior,\nto facilitate behavior maintenance and generalization, and to evaluate effectiveness of instruction. Students will also\nlearn strategies for consultation with other service providers as well as practices for effective supervision of others such\nas paraeducators.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "EDPS50800",
    "Title": "Cultural And Linguistic Diversity In Special Education Programs",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Living in a diverse society provides special education teachers and support personnel the\nopportunity to encounter a wide array of cultures in their educational settings. The course, designed for special\neducation stakeholders (i.e., teachers, staff, support personnel, administrators), considers issues of human diversity,\nbroadly defined to include ability, ethnicity, culture, gender identity, linguistic background, race, religion,\nsocioeconomic status, and sexual orientation. This course challenges biased assumptions that influence the provision of\neducational services, and examines issues related to promoting equal learning opportunities in the classroom and other\neducational settings. It is designed to facilitate student examination of how diversity and diverse experiences shape\nsystems that affect individuals, families, communities, and society. It allows students to explore their own cultures and\nthe biases and internalized messages about those who are different from themselves. Students will be introduced to\nspecific approaches to practice, and frameworks for equity, advocacy, and empowerment to support students who\nreceive special education and/or applied behavior analysis (ABA) service, as well as their families. The course also\nincludes information and discussion topics pertaining to the culturo-behavior science (CBS) specialization of the\nAssociation for Behavior Analysis International (ABAI) and to interpersonal communication skills - to include\nspeaking, listening, reading, and writing - and their effect on students and families. Permission of instructor\nrequired.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Characteristics Of Students With Intense Intervention Needs",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "EDPS 52000 will explore typical and atypical human development, characteristics and etiologies,\nas well as the influence of cultural, linguistic, and socioeconomic factors of students with intense intervention needs.\nCandidates will study medical conditions, physical and health needs, common medications, and the importance of\ntransition plans, health-care plans, and behavioral and academic intervention plans designed to help students\nwith intense intervention needs achieve desired positive learning outcomes.     "Course": "EDPS56010",
    "Title": "Clinical Practice I Experience: Practicum",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "to 6.00. This is a supervised clinical practice experience across two (2) special education settings,\none at the elementary level (K-6) and a second experience at the secondary level (5-12) serving students with Mild\nand/or Intense Intervention Needs. These experiences take place over the course of 8 to 16 weeks depending upon\navailability and individual agreements with our partner district. These experiences are a coordinated effort between\nthe Clinical Practice Coordinator, University Supervisor, and highly qualified, practicing Cooperating Teachers from\nboth the elementary and secondary placements. Candidates assess, design and deliver lessons, manage student needs\nand behaviors, develop IEPs, integrate technology to support learning outcomes, collaborate with families and\ncolleagues, and analyze the experience of facilitating a classroom and caseload of students.\nIn addition, candidates will analyze relationships across theory and practice, multiple perspectives and trends, and the\napplication of these relationships within educational settings.     "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course covers fundamental concepts and applications for electrical and computer engineers as\nwell as for engineers who need to gain a broad understanding of these disciplines.   },
  {
    "Course": "ECE20002",
    "Title": "Electrical Engineering Fundamentals II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Continuation of Electrical and Computer Engineering Fundamentals I. The course addresses\nmathematical and computational foundations of circuit analysis (differential equations, Laplace Transform techniques)\nwith a focus on application to linear circuits having variable behavior as a function of frequency, with emphasis on\nfiltering. Variable frequency behavior is further considered for applications of electronic components through single-\ntransistor and operational amplifiers. The course ends with consideration of how circuits behave and may be modeled\nfor analysis at high frequencies. Permission of Department required. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits:\n3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE20007",
    "Title": "Electrical Engineering Fundamentals I Lab",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This is an introduction course in electronic measurement and circuit modeling, simulation and\ndesign techniques. These skills are developed through a variety of laboratory experiments ranging from voltage,\ncurrent, and frequency, to resistors, inductors, capacitors, and operational amplifiers. When possible, the experiments\ndevelop practical skills through small design and soldering tasks. Finally, the course culminates in a\ntwo week group design project. In many ways this course is the laboratory of the co-requisite lecture course ECE\n20001: Electrical Engineering Fundamentals I; however, we remind students that this is a standalone course that\nexpects students will learn and demonstrate material not taught in ECE 20001. Typically offered Fall Spring\nSummer.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE20008",
    "Title": "Electrical Engineering Fundamentals II Lab",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This is a course in electronic measurement, circuit modeling, simulation and design techniques.\nThese skills are developed through a variety of laboratory experiments including discrete semiconductor measurement,\ntransistor amplifiers, motor control, and operational amplifier internals. The experiments develop practical skills\nthrough small design and soldering tasks. Finally, the course culminates in a two week group design project. In many\nways this course is the laboratory of the co-requisite lecture course ECE 20002 Electrical Engineering Fundamentals II;\nhowever, we remind students that this is a standalone course that expects students will learn and demonstrate material\nnot taught in other courses.
