  {
    "Course": "ECE20100",
    "Title": "Linear Circuit Analysis I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Volt-ampere characteristics for circuit elements; independent and dependent sources; Kirchhoff's\nlaws and circuit equations. Source transformations; Thevenin's and Norton's theorems; superposition, step response of\n1st order (RC, RL) and 2nd order (RLC) circuits. Phasor analysis, impedance calculations, and computation of\nsinusoidal steady state responses. Instantaneous and average power, complex power, power factor correction, and\nmaximum power transfer. Instantaneous and average power.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE20200",
    "Title": "Linear Circuit Analysis II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Continuation of ECE 20100. Use of Laplace Transform techniques to analyze linear circuits with\nand without initial conditions. Characterization of circuits based upon impedance, admittance, and transfer function\nparameters. Determination of frequency response via analysis of poles and zeros in the complex plane. Relationship\nbetween the transfer function and the impulse response of a circuit. Use of continuous time convolution to determine\ntime domain responses. Properties and practical uses of resonant circuits and transformers. Input - output\ncharacterization of a circuit as a two-port. Low and high-pass filter design.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 1.0,

    "Course": "ECE40862",
    "Title": "Software For Embedded Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an introduction to software design for embedded computing systems. Major\ntopics covered include the importance of time and timing in embedded systems, embedded software organization\n(FSM-based program design, polled loop systems, foreground-background systems, event driven architectures, multi-\ntasking, etc.), real-time scheduling and real-time operating systems, wired/wireless networked embedded systems,\ndebugging techniques for embedded software, and advanced topics such as memory-safe programming, implementing\nreentrant functions, and minimizing code space, memory usage, and power consumption. The course features a series\nof integrated assignments using state-of-the-art embedded hardware platforms, embedded software design tools, and\nreal-time operating systems that reinforce the concepts taught in the lectures. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits:\n3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ECE41437",
    "Title": "ASIC Fabrication And Test I",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The first semester of a two-semester sequence to give teams of 3 to 6 students the experience of\ndesigning an ASIC (Application Specific Integrated Circuit), having the chip fabricated and testing it. The team of\nstudents will develop requirements for a design, prepare the design using VHDL ((VHSIC(very high speed integrated\ncircuit) Hardware Description Language)), Verilog, or schematic entry tools, create and use test benches to functionally\nverify the design, use automated tools to prepare a circuit layout, verify the final layout, submit the layout for\nfabrication, prepare a physical test bed, test or demonstrate the chip, and document all aspects of the design and test\nresults. Permission of department required. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 2.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "ECE45300",
    "Title": "Fundamentals Of Nanoelectronics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Nanoelectronic devices are an integral part of our life, including the billion-plus transistors in every\nsmartphone, each of which has an active region that is only a few hundred atoms long. This course is designed to\nconvey the key concepts developed in the last 25 years which constitute the fundamentals of nanoelectronics and\nmesoscopic physics, assuming a minimal set of prerequisites. Topics covered include the new Ohm's law, conductance\nquantization, the nanotransistor, spin valves, thermoelectricity, quantum systems and the non-equilibrium Green's\nfunction (NEGF) method. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "ECE50024",
    "Title": "Machine Learning",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introductory course to machine learning, with a focus on supervised learning using linear\nmodels. The course will have four parts: (1) mathematical background on linear algebra, probability, and optimization.\n(2) classification methods including Bayesian decision, linear regression, logistic, regression,\nand support vector machine. (3) robustness of classifier and adversarial examples. (4) learning theory on the feasibility\nof learning, VC dimension, complexity analysis, bias-variance analysis.     "Course": "ECE50616",
    "Title": "Physics And Manufacturing Of Solar Cells",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the electronic, optical and material properties and the manufacturing of\nphotovoltaic devices. Topics include electronic charge separation, transportation and recombination; optical\nconcentration, trapping and confinement; material preparations in photovoltaic systems; bulk crystal, thin-film and\norganic photovoltaic device configurations; energy storage; as well as emerging concepts in photovoltaics.   },
  {
    "Course": "ECE50631",
    "Title": "Fundamentals Of Current Flow",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Traditional description of electronic motion through a solid is based on diffusive transport which\nmeans that the electron takes a random walk from the source to the drain. However, modern nanoelectronic devices\noften have channel lengths comparable to a mean free path so that electrons travel ballistically, or \"like a bullet.\" This\ncourse provides a unified conceptual framework for ballistic and diffusive transport of both electrons and phonons, that\nis very different from what is taught in standard courses, but indispensable to understanding nanolectronic\ndevices.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE50632",
    "Title": "Introduction To Quantum Transport",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the Schr\u00f6dinger equation, uses the tight-binding method to discuss the\nconcept of bandstructure and E(k) relations, along with simple quantum transport problems. No prior background in\nquantum mechanics or statistical mechanics is assumed.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE50633",
    "Title": "Boltzmann Law: Physics To Computing",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the key concepts of equilibrium statistical mechanics leading to the\ncelebrated Boltzmann law and how it leads to Boltzmann machines and related concepts in modern machine learning.\nNo prior background in statistical mechanics is assumed.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE50653",
    "Title": "Fundamentals Of Nanoelectronics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The modern smartphone is enabled by a billion-plus nano-transistors, each having an active region\nthat is barely a few hundred atoms long. Interestingly the same amazing technology has also led to a deeper\nunderstanding of the nature of current flow on an atomic scale. The aim of this course is to make the fundamentals of\nnanoelectronics accessible to anyone in any branch of science or engineering, assuming very little background beyond\nlinear algebra and differential equations, although we will be discussing advanced concepts in non-equilibrium\nstatistical mechanics that should be of interest even to specialists. We first introduce a new perspective connecting the\nquantized conductance of short ballistic conductors to the familiar Ohm's law of long diffusive conductors, along with\na brief description of the modern nano-transistor. We then address fundamental conceptual issues related to the\nmeaning of resistance on an atomic scale, the interconversion of electricity and heat, the second law of thermodynamics"
  },

    "Course": "ECE51220",
    "Title": "Applied Algorithms",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Solving large-scale problems typically rely on many clever data structures and algorithms. This\ncourse aims to cover many such useful algorithms for solving large-scale problems. These algorithms include greedy\nalgorithms, dynamic programming and more advanced graph algorithms. The course also aims to demonstrate how\nsuch algorithms can be applied to solve optimization problems encountered in engineering applications. In\nparticular, applications in the design of VLSI (very large scale integration) at circuit, layout, or system level will be\nused to demonstrate how an engineering problem can be formulated as a tree/graph problem and solved\nusing established tree/graph algorithms.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Digital Communications",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to digital communication systems and spread spectrum communications. Topics\ninclude analog message digitization, signal space representation of digital signals, binary and M-ary signaling methods,\ndetection of binary and M-ary signals, comparison of digital communication systems in terms of signal energy and\nsignal bandwidth requirements. The principal types of spread spectrum systems are analyzed and compared.\nApplication of spread spectrum to multiple access systems and to secure communication systems is discussed.\nTypically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE54700",
    "Title": "Introduction To Computer Communication Networks",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A qualitative and quantitative study of the issues in design, analysis, and operation of computer\ncommunication and telecommunication networks as they evolve toward the integrated networks of the future,\nemploying both packet and circuit switching technology. The course covers packet and circuit switching, the OSI\nstandards architecture and protocols, elementary queuing theory for performance evaluation, random access techniques,\nlocal area networks, reliability and error recovery, and integrated networks. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Introduction To Data Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Emphasis is on the design of systems that can manipulate and retrieve data from large databases\nusing high level formal languages.   {
    "Course": "ECE56300",
    "Title": "Programming Parallel Machines",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course presents methods and techniques for programming parallel computers, such as\nmulticore and high-end parallel architectures. Various parallel algorithms will be presented to demonstrate different\ntechniques for identifying parallel tasks and mapping them onto parallel machines. Realistic science/engineering\napplications and their characteristics will be discussed. Parallel architectures to be considered are shared-memory and\ndistributed-memory multiprocessor systems. Programming paradigms for these machines will be compared, including\ndirective-based (OpenMP), message passing (MPI) and thread-based (Posix threads) methods. Methodologies for\nanalyzing and improving the performance of parallel programs will be discussed. There will be a class project in which\neach student parallelizes and tunes the performance of a large computation application or develops/improves a tool that\nhelps this process. Each student will prepare one lecture for a selected topic. Offered during odd years. Typically\noffered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE56500",
    "Title": "Computer Architecture",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introduction to the problems involved in designing and analyzing current machine architectures.\nMajor topics include performance and cost analysis, pipeline processing, vector machines and numerical applications,\nhierarchical memory design, and multiprocessor architectures. A quantitative approach allowing a computer system\ndesigner to determine the extent to which a design meets design goals is emphasized. Typically offered Fall.Credits:\n3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ECE57000",
    "Title": "Artificial Intelligence",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to the basic concepts and various approaches of artificial intelligence. The first part of\nthe course deals with heuristic search and shows how problems involving search can be solved more efficiently by the\nuse of heuristics and how, in some cases, it is possible to discover heuristics automatically. The next part of the course\npresents ways to represent knowledge about the world and how to reason logically with that knowledge. The third part\nof the course introduces the student to advanced topics of AI drawn from machine learning, natural language\nunderstanding, computer vision, and reasoning under uncertainty. The emphasis of this part is to illustrate that\nrepresentation and search are fundamental issues in all aspects of artificial intelligence. Typically offered Fall.Credits:\n3.00"

    "Course": "ECE60200",
    "Title": "Lumped System Theory",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An investigation of the basic theory and techniques of modern system theory, emphasizing linear\nstate model formulations of continuous and discrete time systems in the time domain and frequency domain. Coverage\nincludes notions of linearity, time invariance, discrete and continuous time state models, canonical forms, associated\ntransfer functions and impulse response models, the state transition matrix, the Jordan form, controllability,\nobservability, and stability. Prerequisite: Master's student standing or higher and concurrent prerequisite: MA 51100.\nTypically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ECE60419",
    "Title": "Numerical Simulations Of Electro-Optic Energy Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to computational techniques employed in research on energy systems involving\nquantum electronics and electromagnetics. You will learn the strengths and weaknesses of each approach; what types\nof problem call for which one; and how your simulation will perform. Techniques include eigenvalue problems, fast\nFourier transforms, band structure calculations, rigorous-coupled wave analysis, beam-propagation methods, finite-\ndifference time-domain, and finite element methods. Applications include nanophotonics, photovoltaics, thermal\nmanagement, radiative control, and nonlinear optics. Prerequisite by Topic: Elect/Magn Interactions (ECE 60400 or\nequivalent); Programming For Engineers (C, MATLAB, or similar); Linear Algebra; Ordinary Differ. Equatn; and\nSignals and Systems. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Solid State Devices",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A relatively-broad, moderate-depth coverage of semiconductor devices and related topics.   {
    "Course": "ECE60614",
    "Title": "Reliability Physics Of Nanoelectronic Transistors",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will focus on the physics of reliability of small semiconductor devices. In traditional\ncourses on device physics, the students learn how to compute current through a device in response to applied voltage.\nHowever, as transistors are turned on and off trillions of times during the years of operation, gradually defects\naccumulate within the device so that at some point the transistor does not work anymore. The course will explore the\nphysics and mathematics regarding how and when things break a topic of great interest to semiconductor device\nengineers. Prerequisites: ECE 60600 required; ECE 61200 and ECE 55800 are recommended. Typically offered\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Programmable hardware accelerators seek to fulfill the promise of continued performance and\nenergy-efficiency gains in the era of a slowing Moore's\nlaw, larger problem sizes and an increased focused on energy-efficiency. This class will introduce students to the\narchitectures of programmable\naccelerators. We will delve deeply into the architectures of modern massively parallel accelerators like GPUs,\nculminating in a course project.     "Title": "Nonlinear Optics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An in-depth study of nonlinear optics. After a review of linear effects, several nonlinear optical\nprocesses and applications are discussed.   {
    "Course": "ECE63300",
    "Title": "Modeling And Simulation Of Power System Components",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Recommended for those interested in learning to use computer simulation to investigate the\ndynamic and controlled behavior of electrical power components. Beginning with an introduction to\nMATLAB/SIMULINK, the course goes through the key steps of modeling, implementing and verifying the simulation\nof single and three-phase transformers, single and three-phase induction machines, three-phase wound field\nsynchronous machines and permanent magnet machines useful in power applications, each case amply illustrated in\nprojects around some interesting topics. Students are expected to implement and verify about 10 simulation projects\nand also discuss observed behaviors on topics such as inrush current in transformers, motoring, generating and braking\noperation of machines, and pulsating torque from subsynchronous resonance. Prerequisite: ECE 43200. Typically\noffered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ECE63900",
    "Title": "Error Control Coding",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The theory and practice of error control coding is examined. The study includes the arithmetic of\nGalois fields as well as linear block, cyclic, and convolutional codes. Some applications of codes in digital\ncommunication systems and in computer systems are presented. Offered every third semester. Concurrent prerequisite:\nECE 60000. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "ECE65400",
    "Title": "Solid State Devices II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to advanced concepts in semiconductor devices as an extension and continuation of\nECE 60600. Topics include charge storage and transfer in deep depletion MOS devices (CCDs and DRAMs); negative\ndifferential mobility and transit time effects in microwave oscillators (Gunn and IMPATT diodes); spontaneous and\nstimulated emission, quantum efficiency, and charge confinement in photonic devices (LEDs and double heterojunction\nlasers); and quantum efficiency and spectral response in conventional and avalanche photodiodes. Prerequisite: ECE\n60600. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE65600",
    "Title": "Electronic Transport In Semiconductors",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A treatment of the microscopic and phenomenological physics of carrier transport in bulk\nsemiconductors and in semiconductor devices. The Boltzmann transport equation is introduced as are techniques for\nsolving it analytically and numerically. The physics of carrier scattering in common semiconductors is explored.\nTheoretical treatments of low and high field transport are compared with measured results. Balance equations are\nderived as moments of the Boltzmann Transport Equation and are applied to the analysis of sub-micron semiconductor\ndevices. Students are expected to be able to apply elementary concepts of quantum mechanics and solid state physics.\nOffered every third semester. Prerequisite: ECE 60600. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE65800",
    "Title": "Semiconductor Material And Device Characterization",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A comprehensive survey of modern characterization techniques routinely used to determine solid-\nstate material and device parameters. Concepts and theory underlying the techniques are examined, and sample\nexperimental results are presented. The coverage includes electrical, optical, chemical, and physical characterization\nmethods. Offered in alternate years. Prerequisite: ECE 60600. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "ECE66100",
    "Title": "Computer Vision",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course deals with how an autonomous or a semi-autonomous system can be endowed with\nvisual perception. The issues discussed include: sampling from a topological standpoint; grouping processes; data\nstructures, especially hierarchical types such as pyramids, quadtrees, octrees, etc.; graphic theoretic methods for\nstructural description and consistent labeling; issues in 3-D vision such as object representation by Gaussian spheres,\ngeneralized cylinders, etc. Prerequisite: ECE 57000. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ECE66300",
    "Title": "Compiler Code Generation, Optimization, And Parallelization",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course presents the concepts needed to design and implement production quality code\ngenerators for any of the more popular languages and families of computer architecture (including various pipelined,\nsuperscalar, and macro-parallel machines). Flow analysis and concurrency detection, as well as optimizations and loop\nand irregular code parallelizations, are covered in detail. Using C on ECN UNIX, each student will complete a project\nimplementing a simple optimizer/parallelizer. Prerequisite: ECE 56500, CS 50200 or ECE 46800 or ECE 57300.\nTypically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE66400",
    "Title": "Formal Languages, Computability, And Complexity",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Topics in computability theory and formal languages include recursive function theory, the\nequivalence of various generic programming languages for numeric calculations and string manipulations, regular\nlanguages and finite state automata, and context-free and context-sensitive languages. In complexity theory, emphasis\nis on the theory of NP-completeness, including proof methods, the distinctions between strong- and weak-sense NP-\ncompleteness, NP-hardness, and performance-guaranteed approximation algorithms. Offered in alternate years.\nPrerequisite: ECE 60800. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE66600",
    "Title": "Advanced Computer Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The study of theoretical aspects of advanced computer systems where multiprocessing is used.\nTopics include the design, architecture, and performance evaluation of multiprocessor memories, interconnection\nnetworks, and computational pipelines. Also included are the topics of scheduling, synchronization, resource allocation,\nload-balancing, partitioning and deadlock avoidance in multiprocessors. Also covered are the design and analysis of\nparallel algorithms, programming languages and automatic approaches to parallelism detection/exploitation for\nconcurrent computation. Prerequisite: ECE 56500, ECE 60800. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "RLC extraction of VLSI interconnects. Modeling of interconnects as RLC trees or networks.\nElmore delay model. Reduced-order modeling: moment matching, Pade approximation, and Krylov-subspace methods."

  {
    "Course": "ECE67300",
    "Title": "Distributed Computing Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Discussions of the design issues of distributed computing systems (DCS). The general theory of\ndistributed transaction management, reliability, and resource management is discussed. Various algorithms and\nspecification methodologies for DCS are introduced. A general coverage of the three major areas of DCS, namely:\ndistributed operating systems, distributed databases, and distributed AI is provided. The discussion is augmented with\nvarious case studies. Prerequisite: ECE 46900 or introductory course in operating systems. Typically offered\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "ECE67800",
    "Title": "Radar Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introduction to the system aspects of modern radar engineering. The theoretical basis for radar\nperformance analysis is developed and applied to radars designed for a variety of different applications. Consideration\nis given to system parameters such as receiver noise, antenna characteristics, operating frequency, target characteristics,\ntransmitted signal modulation, and methods of detection. Attention is given to radars for special purposes, such as\nautomatic range and angle tracking, moving target indication, and resolution enhancement through synthetic aperture\ntechniques.   },
  {
    "Course": "ECE68000",
    "Title": "Modern Automatic Control",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Theoretical methods in optimal control theory. Topics include the calculus of variations and the\nPontryagin minimum principle with applications to minimum energy problems. Geometric methods will be applied to\nthe solution of minimum time problems. Computational methods, singular problems, observer theory, and sufficient\nconditions for existence of solutions are also discussed. Offered in alternate years. Prerequisite: ECE 60200. Typically\noffered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ECE68800",
    "Title": "VLSI Testing And Verification",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Discusses different aspects of VLSI testing and formal verification of designs. Design and\nmanufacturing defect models are introduced along with test generation and fault simulation algorithms targeting the\ndifferent fault models. Both combinational and sequential logic testing are covered, and different synthesis for\ntestability schemes such as BIST (Built-In-Self-Test), scan path design, etc., are introduced. Other new and emerging\ntest and verification techniques also are discussed. Offered every third semester. Prerequisite: ECE 55900. Typically\noffered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is a survey of key electrical and electronics systems, their basic performance and\napplications. AC\nsystems include transformers and reactive elements, power production and distribution, filtering, motors and relays.\nComputer systems are presented with a microprocessor and provide the ability to write and read both digital and analog\ndata.     "Course": "ECET35901",
    "Title": "Computer Based Data Acquisition Applications",

  },
  {
    "Course": "ECET54400",
    "Title": "Real-Time And Embedded Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Real-time systems are hardware/software systems in which a timely response by a computer to\nexternal stimuli is vital to the performance of the system's objectives. This is the study of temporal determinism.\nEmbedded systems are those with special-purpose microcomputers designed into the system for explicit purposes.\nExamples of such are the computers on your car's engine that control fuel injection, fly-by-wire attitude controls in\nmodern jet aircraft, even the microcontroller inside a cellular phone. In these examples, the computer has a specific,\nlimited task that is part of the functionality of the device and specifying average performance of that computer is\ninsufficient for successful completion of the task at hand. Imagine if the flight controls of a Boeing 787 on final landing\napproach experienced a \"network lag\" similar to that which occurs occasionally while you're reading e-mail. If the\ncontrols stop responding at a critical time, a horrific crash could occur. Even if the system doesn't freeze up 99.999% of\nthe time, it can still result in disaster.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 1.0,

  },
  {
    "Course": "ENGR26099",
    "Title": "Professional Practice Parallel Co-Op Summer I",
    "CreditHours": 0.0,
    "Description": "Co-Op is an academic program with oversight by assigned Faculty Coordinators who serve as the\ninstructor for participating students. Parallel Co-Op program participants are undergraduate students who work part-\ntime (more than 12 hours per week and less than 30 hours per week) in paid computer science, engineering,\npolytechnic, or management positions during the academic year terms (fall and spring semesters) for an employer with\na local operation or office. During the summer term, Parallel Co-Op students work in full-time positions at any location\noffered by the employer. During the academic year, Parallel Co-Op students register for 6 to 9 credit hours of academic\ncourse load, and also for this zero-credit hour Parallel Co-Op course that carries half-time student status to recognize\nthe academic impact of the experience. The combination of both academic course and Parallel Co-Op course\nregistrations provides students with full-time status. During the summer term, Parallel Co-Op students register for a\nzero-credit hour Parallel Co-Op Summer course that carries full-time student status. Prerequisite: Student must be\neligible to participate in the Cooperative Education (Co-Op) program, and have written documentation of valid work\nsession with approved Co-Op employer. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Summer.Credits: 0.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ENGR27199",
    "Title": "Professional Practice Flex Co-Op I",
    "CreditHours": 0.0,
    "Description": "Co-Op is an academic program with oversight provided by assigned Faculty Coordinators who\nserve as the Instructor for participating students. In the Flex Co-Op program, students must work for their first\nemployer for a minimum of two work sessions, and then have the option to continue for one-to-three additional work\nsessions; or, after completing two work sessions with the first employer, the student may elect to start with a second\nemployer. If the student elects to change employers, they must notify their first employer and their Faculty Coordinator\nin writing at the conclusion of the second work session. The student must commit to work for the second Co-Op\nemployer for a minimum of two work sessions. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall Spring\nSummer.Credits: 0.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "ENGR30500",
    "Title": "Fundamentals Of Innovation Theory And Practice",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to provide students with initial exposure to the fundamental patterns,\nmindsets, behaviors, attributes, tools, and methods employed in the innovative activity of individuals and\norganizations. Emphasis is placed on understanding and effectively utilizing techniques to systematically drive\ninnovation that are drawn from the fields of business, design, problem-solving, engineering, and the social\nsciences. Lecture, in-class small group activities, and individual and team assignments are employed across an array of\ncontemporary socio-technical challenges to provide students with the opportunity to apply conveyed theory and\nmethods to rigorously structure problems, understand involved stakeholders, utilize innovation motifs and analogical\nreasoning to develop robust views of potential solutions spaces, tailor solution design to stakeholder context, consider\nthe full suite of functional, social, and emotional dimensions that could influence solution prioritization, and document\nand systematically assess underlying solution assumptions to iterate toward a viable and sustainable forward looking\nplan that could achieve target outcomes. This course counts toward, serves as a required entry course for, the College of\nEngineering Minor in Innovation and Transformational Change. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ENGR31000",
    "Title": "Engineering In Global Context",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides students with opportunities to study how engineering is intertwined with\nlarger economic, social, cultural, and technological dynamics in an era of intensified globalization. Its major goals are\nto help students understand and appreciate what engineering is, how engineers are trained, what engineers do, and how\nengineering and society interact. The course approaches these themes through discussion of: the relation and interaction\nof engineering, science, technology, and society; the historical origins and development of engineering as a profession;\ndiversity issues in engineering and other STEM fields; engineering in cross-national/cultural contexts; and\ncontemporary challenges related to globalization, ethics, and sustainability. In summary, the course is designed to help\nstudents understand what it means to identify as, and/or work with, engineers. Recitation sections and/or independent\nprojects (at the instructor's discretion) provide further opportunities for students to expand their knowledge and\nimprove their skills in relation to course themes. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "ENGR36099",
    "Title": "Professional Practice Parallel Co-Op Summer II",
    "CreditHours": 0.0,
    "Description": "Co-Op is an academic program with oversight by assigned Faculty Coordinators who serve as the\ninstructor for participating students. Parallel Co-Op program participants are undergraduate students who work part-\ntime (more than 12 hours per week and less than 30 hours per week) in paid computer science, engineering,\npolytechnic, or management positions during the academic year terms (fall and spring semesters) for an employer with\na local operation or office. During the summer term, Parallel Co-Op students work in full-time positions at any location\noffered by the employer. During the academic year, Parallel Co-Op students register for 6 to 9 credit hours of academic\ncourse load, and also for this zero-credit hour Parallel Co-Op course that carries half-time student status to recognize\nthe academic impact of the experience. The combination of both academic course and Parallel Co-Op course\nregistrations provides students with full-time status. During the summer term, Parallel Co-Op students register for a\nzero-credit hour Parallel Co-Op Summer course that carries full-time student status. Prerequisite: Student must be\neligible to participate in the Cooperative Education (Co-Op) program, and have written documentation of valid work\nsession with approved Co-Op employer. Permission of instructor required.Credits: 0.00"

  {
    "Course": "ENGR49001",
    "Title": "Breakthrough Thinking For Complex Challenges",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course helps students learn and effectively employ high-impact design principles and\nstructured problem solving methods to address complex multi-stakeholder socio-technical challenges. Case discussions\nof historical and contemporary high impact solutions to complex challenges are used to introduce techniques to frame\nproblems, structure ambiguity, intentionally design non-incremental solutions, and communicate, trial, and iterate\nsolutions to drive adoption and multifaceted sustainability. Techniques are drawn from multiple schools of thought\nsuch as business, design, engineering, and the social sciences. Over the course of the term, multi-disciplinary student\nteams directly apply cumulative learning to address selected parts of a real-world complex societal challenge in close\ncollaboration with a partner organization, in an experiential learning format. This course can be counted toward the\nCollege of Engineering Minor in Innovation and Transformational Change and the Burton D. Morgan Center for\nEntrepreneurship (BDMCE) Certificate in Entrepreneurship and Innovation. Permission of instructor required.\nTypically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course, new doctoral students in engineering education explore their roles within the field of\nengineering education, create a learning plan that maps to program requirements, and develop habits of mind to support\ntheir ongoing professional development.   {
    "Course": "ENE50300",
    "Title": "Engineering Education Inquiry",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is conceived as a bridge between beginning graduate students' knowledge of technical\nresearch and modes of inquiry appropriate to the new field of engineering education. It is designed as the entryway to\nrequired research method courses taken as part of the students' plan of study. By the end of this survey course, students\nwill be able to critique research in terms of the quality of the authors' argument based on their chain of reasoning, and\nwill recognize that the articulation of a research question, the significance of the question, the choice of methods in\nregards to the research goals, and the transparency of the explanation of the methodology are all the parts of the chain\nof reasoning. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ENE50400",
    "Title": "Leadership, Policy, And Change In Science, Technology,\nEngineering, And Mathematics (STEM) Education",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides a foundation for examining historical and current perspectives of STEM\neducation programs and policy at the secondary and postsecondary levels. Focusing on the relationships among\neducation policy, leadership theories, and models of systemic change, this course will enable students to situate and\nenvision their potential role in shaping engineering education within the context of the larger education landscape.\nStudents will synthesize course readings, examine education policy, and reflect on leadership theories and change, as\nwell as explore how they can influence leadership, policy, and /or organizational change in STEM education through a\nsemester project. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ENE50500",
    "Title": "Theories Of Development And Engineering Thinking",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course examines theories of human development, learning and epistemology in the context of\nEngineering Education. A broad survey of readings guides an in-depth study of fundamental theories of development\nand knowledge generation as it relates to pedagogy and research. A rich body of theoretical literature will be studied in\norder to explore its relation to engineering education. Work in the course aims to construct answers to the following\nthree questions: (1) How do theories of human learning, development, and epistemology help us think about\nengineering? (2) How do they relate to engineering education? (3) How do they inform research method and practice in\nengineering education? No restrictions. It is helpful, however, for students to have engaged in prior reading-and\nwriting- intensive courses that required them to synthesize large amounts of information. For this reason, it is\nrecommended that students are enrolled currently in a graduate program at Purdue University. Permission of\ndepartment required. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "ENE55400",
    "Title": "Globalization And Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The focus is on the multifaceted dynamics of globalization, and its impact on engineering practice\nand the lives and education of engineers. The course emphasizes engineering and globalization from the perspectives of\nthe emerging Asian economies and Europe, as well as the United States. This course is designed for practicing\nengineers and engineering educators. It is taught within a learner-centric, highly interactive, collaborative learning\nenvironment in which students are expected to learn from the experiences and thinking of each other, as well as from\nthe instructor, and other course resources. The course places emphasis on reading, writing, web-based research, and\ndiscussion. Students are recommended (but not required) to have a minimum of two years work experience as a\npracticing engineer and strong communication skills (self-assessed). Permission of instructor is required. Typically\noffered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ENE62000",
    "Title": "Design, Cognition And Learning",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Design is central to engineering: it is an integral part of the engineering profession and how we\neducate future professionals. Design cognition and learning is an area of engineering education research that seeks to\nunderstand what designers know and how they learn, and what tools best support design activity (e.g., collaboration,\ninnovation, etc.). This research draws from many perspectives including cognitive psychology and the learning\nsciences, organizational learning, engineering and product design, architecture, human-centered interaction, and\ncreativity and innovation. Themes in the course include (1) design knowledge, (2) what theories help understand design\nknowing and learning, (3) what are ways to study designers and design activity, and (4) how may design research\ninform design education and practice? Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },

Participants in this course will be able to evaluate various\nlearning technologies relative to specific learning goals and outcomes and will design a technological tool to support\nthinking, learning and/or teaching about concepts in science, engineering, mathematics and technology. Participants"

  {
    "Course": "EPCS10200",
    "Title": "First Year Participation In EPICS",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Continuation of EPCS courses (see EPCS 10100). Participants in EPCS 10200 gain insight into the\nspecific project, and more generally, into the design and development process. They attend planning and reporting\nmeetings with the customer and are expected to attend all team meetings. Working with team's sophomores, juniors and\nseniors they perform and report upon tasks consistent with their level of discipline expertise. EPCS 10200 is offered for\ntwo credits and is intended for students who have exhibited significant achievement in EPCS 10100 and desire the level\nof responsibility that is appropriate for two credits. May be repeated for credit. Permission of department required.\nTypically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "EPCS11100",
    "Title": "First Year Participation In EPICS I",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Together, Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) courses create a vertical project\ntrack under which students work in multidisciplinary teams on long-term engineering-based design projects. Projects of\nat least one-year in duration are intended to solve real problems that are defined in consultation with \"customers\" from\nnot-for-profit community and education organizations. EPCS courses are open to students from all disciplines; each\nstudent contributes expertise in his/her academic discipline. Each team consists of a mix of first-year, sophomores,\njuniors, and seniors. Students are encouraged to participate in an EPICS project team for two or more semesters. First-\nyear students participating in EPCS gain insight into the specific project, and more generally, into the design and\ndevelopment process. They attend planning and reporting meetings with the customer and are expected to attend all\nteam meetings. Under mentorship from upper level students and instructors, they perform and report upon design tasks\nconsistent with their level of discipline expertise. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 1.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course prepares manufacturing and information technology leaders to design and analyze\nmanufacturing processes to achieve manufacturing system objectives that meet internal and external customers quality,\ncost and delivery requirements within a safe environment.     "Course": "ENGT56100",
    "Title": "Metrology Concepts And Applications",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Metrology is a fundamental concept required for obtaining scientific data and understanding\ninstrumentation. This course introduces the concepts of metrology associated with measurement systems: sensors,\nsignal conditioning, data acquisition and analysis, as well as the error propagation. System and environmental noise are\ninvestigated along with methods to mitigate influences of noise. Standards and calibration of instrumentation are also\nstudied. Concepts of metrology for the seven basic units of measurements are described from the macro to nano-scale.\nTypically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course explores the interconnections among markets, business and its management, and\nliterature.   },
  {
    "Course": "ENGL22900",
    "Title": "Creole Languages And Cultures",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the concept of pidgin and creole languages across the world, with a focus on\nEnglish-based pidgins and creoles. It addresses their geographical distribution and some of their cultural manifestations\nsuch as music, food and literature on both sides of the Atlantic. The course presents a general view of the historical\nevents that led to the formation of creole languages and to the development of the African diaspora. We will consider\ndifferent varieties of creole languages and (their) cultures including English-based creoles in West Africa such as Kru\n(Liberia and Sierra Leone), Nigerian Pidgin and Cameroonian Pidgin; in the Caribbean such as Jamaican, San Andreas,\nNicaraguan and Limonense, contrasting them with the Spanish-based creole Palenquero; and the three most\npredominant creoles in the U.S. Louisiana Creole, Gullah and Hawaii Creole, to understand their characteristics and\ntheir history. We will explore the ways in which the languages manifest in the music and literature of the contexts\nwhere they are spoken. Finally, we will consider the African diaspora as a fundamental thread that ties (English-based)\ncreole languages and peoples together. In exploring these issues, the course will draw on a variety of theoretical\nconcepts and traditions from sociolinguistics, creole studies and African American studies. Typically offered Fall\nSpring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Description": "This course explores legal conflicts through literature.   {
    "Course": "ENGL34300",
    "Title": "Labor And Literature",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces its students to the transformative synergy between the labor of literature and\nlabor within literature. In contrast to accepting the marketplace as a societal monolith, the readings illustrate the role of\nlabor in creation. This course will examine labor taken in its broadest sense, from the labor of self-fashioning to the\nlabor of industries; the labor of life and the labor of destruction and the implications of the laboring body from market\ncreation to market collapse. Diverse readings range from traditional literary staples to modern representations of the\nlabor market. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ENGL34400",
    "Title": "Environmental Ethics, Policy, And Sustainability",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Environmental Ethics, Policy and Sustainability is an interdisciplinary course designed to open new\npathways into ethical and eco-critical inquiry in the Anthropocene age. The course analyzes disciplinary differences in\napproaching the ethical, the human, and environmental problems such as sustainability, development, biodiversity,\nglobal security, and climate change. Students will explore what it means to be ethical in and through an interrogation of\nour contemporary conceptions of what it means to be human. These interrogations in turn will prompt us to reconsider\nhuman creations such as knowledge, culture, and technology, which will push us to genuinely think how humans as a\nspecies situate their creations within the realm of what they call Nature. Students will be introduced to the history of\nenvironmental studies in the discipline, to the rise of what is now known as \"postcolonial ecocriticism\" to theoretical\ninquiry into modern technology, and to other recent developments in the fields of environmental studies.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "ENGL34500",
    "Title": "Games And World Building",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Every game designer and gamer knows that there is more to narrative than just words on a page\nand more to worldbuilding than images on a screen. This course looks at the ways that narrative worlds get built in\ngames. We will begin by looking at the narrative elements in analog games that have been the foundation of many\ndigital games and move on to look at the elements in digital games that come together to form the worlds.   {
    "Course": "ENGL66900",
    "Title": "Introduction To Visual Theory And Visual Culture",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Visual studies is the multidisciplinary study of images, viewers, and vision. Students will be\nprovided with an overview of the theories, practices, and histories of the visual from a variety of disciplinary\nperspectives and historical periods. The seminar will be organized around a series of basic questions (such as what is an\nimage? how do images produce meaning? What do images do? what is vision?) whose responses have come to\nconstitute the field as well as its transdisciplinarity. Readings will be drawn from seminal works in visual theory,\ncultural semiotics, cultural theory, intermediality, art history, media studies as well as the psychology, philosophy, and\nscience of vision. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ENTM12800",
    "Title": "Investigating Forensic Science",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Designed for both forensic science majors and non-majors, this course will provide an overview of\nthe issues affecting the study and practice of forensic science as defined by the National Academy of Science 2009\nreport: \"Strengthening Forensic Science\". Using a mixture of popular media (film, television, news articles) as well as\nmore conventional academic peer-reviewed articles, students will learn how the scientific method is applied to forensic\ninvestigations including; identifying pseudoscience, crime lab procedures, DNA evidence, errors in thinking and\nproblem solving, types of fraud, and the influence of the \"CSI Effect\". Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ENTM60200",
    "Title": "Insect Biology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A comprehensive course in entomology, for graduate students with little entomological\nbackground, that introduces students broadly to insect structure, function, behavior, ecology, pest management, and\nsystematics. Students apply broad knowledge in each of the topic areas to a specific insect and are expected to be able\nto read and critically evaluate primary literature and summarize it in written and oral presentations. One year of college\nbiology is strongly recommended. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ENTM60900",
    "Title": "Science Writing",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed for graduate students (MS or PhD) at any stage in their professional career\nwho are seeking formal training in manuscript and grant writing for a scientific audience. Students will be required to\nattend class and prepare for in-class group discussions and writing activities by reading assigned sections of the text or\nassociated papers. Students will also be required to prepare a written assignment (manuscript or grant) over the course\nof the semester, which they will use to practice and hone newly acquired skills, as well as participating in peer-\nevaluation of one another's writing. Permission of department required.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ENTM61000",
    "Title": "Current Trends In Insect Pest Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Concepts of pest management and dynamics of pest populations, with emphasis on population\nregulation in theory and practice. The principles of applied ecology that pertain to insects and agricultural crops and\nsystems. Identification, biology, behavior, and relationships of pests of forage, fiber, and vegetable crops. A knowledge\nof introductory entomology is recommended. Offered in even-numbered years. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ENTM61100",
    "Title": "Toxicology Of Insecticides",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The chemistry, mode of action, and metabolism of insecticides and related compounds in both\ninsect and vertebrate systems. Evaluation of toxic action, principles of selective toxicity, insecticide resistance, and\nenvironmental effects are also discussed. A minimal knowledge of entomology is required. Knowledge of biochemistry\nand neurobiology is useful. Offered in even-numbered years. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ENTM64200",
    "Title": "Analysis Of Ecological Data",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Intermediate course in analysis options for biological and ecological data. Topics include:\nunivariate, multivariate, parametric and non-parametric analysis and their basis; advanced graphical techniques; basic\nmapping with and without geographical information systems; simulation modeling; associated coding for open source\nplatforms. A previous graduate-level course in statistics is required. Working knowledge of ANOVA, t-tests, linear\nregression, and assumptions and distributions of test statistics for these is assumed. Typically offered Spring.Credits:\n3.00"

    "Course": "EEE38000",
    "Title": "Environmental Chemodynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to chemical thermodynamics and general equilibrium processes in environmental and\necological engineering systems. Introduction to the first and second laws of thermodynamics; properties of pure\nsubstances; ideal and real gases; thermodynamic cycles and processes; heat transfer and combustion; and chemical\nequilibrium in aquatic solutions, including equilibria between phases and reaction equilibria. Emphasis is on\nunderstanding and conceptualizing important processes, and competency in thermodynamic calculations. Typically\noffered Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "FS48300",
    "Title": "Fermentation Capstone",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The development of value-added fermentation processes requires a complex blend of\ntechnoeconomic and market awareness, resource gathering, strain selection and engineering, reactor optimization and\noperation, product recovery, and project management skills. Keeping these diverse aspects in balance while managing\nproject timelines is essential to a successful fermentation process - that is, one that is both technically and economically\nsuccessful. This course is organized to develop your knowledge of the diverse inputs into design of microbial\nfermentation and your ability to apply concepts learned in prior fermentation classes to the design of a fermentation\nprocess, integrating microbiology, chemistry, and processing with basic marketing and business concepts. Students will\nbe organized into project teams for the semester and challenged to design, market, develop, prototype, and scale up a\nnew fermentation. Classes will include guest lectures from experts in the fermentation industry and academia. Project\nteams will be organized and project leaders selected to manage communication between individual groups and the\ninstructors. Final product concepts will be presented to faculty and peers for evaluation.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "FS56600",
    "Title": "Microbial Techniques For Food Pathogens",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Molecular biology, immunochemistry and tissue culture-based rapid and automated techniques\ncurrently used for detection and identification of foodborne pathogens. The techniques include metabolic fingerprinting\nidentification system, enzyme immunoassay and dot blotting, lateral flow assay, polymerase chain reaction, genomic\nfingerprinting, cytotoxicity assays, and selected biosensor tools. Laboratory experiments are scheduled for four hours,\nwith up to two additional hours of arranged time. Offered in even-numbered years. (Weeks 6-16). Typically offered\nSpring.Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "FS62000",
    "Title": "Scientific Writing In Food Science",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course covers the essential elements of publishing original research at professional meetings\n(oral presentations and papers) and in peer-reviewed journals (original research manuscripts). Topics include: ethics in\nwriting, effective reading of the literature, organizing research data, choosing a journal, writing the manuscript (results,\nmaterials and methods, introduction, discussion, title, abstract, references), publication process, revising and reviewing,\nposter presentation, and short oral presentations. Each student will write a paper, prepare a 12-minute oral presentation,\nand prepare a poster, based on data from his/her graduate research project. Permission of instructor required. Typically\noffered Spring.Credits: 2.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

  {
    "Course": "FNR35950",
    "Title": "Spatial Ecology Laboratory",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "The lab will focus on the use and application of spatial databases that are common in natural\nresource management settings. Introduction to the principles of landscape ecology and biogeography with a\nlaboratory devoted to the analysis of spatial data using geographic information systems and other database\ntools. Landscape ecology focuses on the important relationships of landscape structure (pattern, heterogeneity)\nand ecological processes (movement of animals, hydrologic dynamics) and how this information is used for\nnatural resource management. Biogeography examines ecological patterns and processes at larger scales\n(generally at subcontinental to global) for the purposes of managing plants and animals of global importance. In\nthe last 15 years, tremendous efforts have been made to create spatial databases that help support research and\nmanagement of natural resources at various scales. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "FNR43900",
    "Title": "Silviculture",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course details common silvicultural systems used in North America for establishment and\ntending of forest stands for a variety of objectives. Lab projects\nemphasize critical thinking, data-driven decision-making (using growth-andyield models), technical writing and oral\ncommunication. Permission of department required.   {
    "Course": "FNR53600",
    "Title": "Ecology Of Disturbance",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Advanced lecture-and discussion-based class examining how disturbance shapes the composition\nand structure of communities and landscapes across major terrestrial biomes. Students will examine and discuss the\nrelationships between disturbance intensity, frequency, and spatial extent and how these characteristics affect\necological processes and ecologically-based management of forest and grassland ecosystems. The class will also\nexamine the synergistic effects of multiple disturbances and the restoration of endemic disturbance regimes in\ncontemporary ecosystems. Course is reading intensive; students will read and discuss on average 3-8 journal articles\nper week. Typically offered in even years. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "FNR57400",
    "Title": "Big Data, AI, And Forests",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is focused on introductory big data analysis, artificial intelligence, and\nassociated applications in large-scale forest research. The lecture will cover the challenges we encounter in\nbig data ecological research, and the approaches to overcome these challenges. Real-time forest inventory\nand wildlife survey data at national and continental levels will be utilized in this course, and actual high-\nimpact research projects will be introduced as case studies to inform students of the state-of-the-art in this\nsubject area. High-performance computing clusters will be utilized for big data analysis.\nThis course is also open to non-forestry majors. We will introduce basic machine learning techniques that are\napplicable to other subject areas. Guest lectures may cover big data analyses in different fields, internet-of-\nthings, and/or data management and optimization/decimation for collaborative Virtual Reality experiences.\nThe class will be evaluated through a final project, for which students will work independently or in a group\nsetting to develop a 'mini' research manuscript with a title of their own selection. All the groups are\nencouraged to submit their manuscript for publication at peer-reviewed journals, and those whose\nmanuscripts have passed the initial journal screening will get extra bonus points. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "FNR58000",
    "Title": "Research Methods For Natural Resource Social Science",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This class covers basic elements of research design for social scientists, with an emphasis on issues\npertinent to natural resource management. Topics to be covered include the role of theories and paradigms in designing\nsound research, writing research questions and hypotheses, and the importance of validity and reliability in research\ndesign. Qualitative, quantitative, and mixed methods designs are presented and discussed. Typically offered\nFall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "FNR58600",
    "Title": "Urban Ecology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Urbanization is on the rise, transforming natural ecosystems into coupled human-natural\necosystems that encompass complex, novel functional and structural characteristics shaped by people and the inherent\nenvironment. Through local field trips and readings of the primary scientific literature, we examine the unique\ncharacteristics of coupled human-natural ecosystems. The course is designed to be broadly accessible to students from\na variety of backgrounds, interests, and majors who are interested in environmental science and engineering and\nemphasizes the importance of incorporating an ecological perspective in environmental engineering and natural\nresource management. This course covers fundamental principles of ecology as applied in urban and other coupled\nhuman-natural systems with emphasis on the impacts of modern industrial society on ecosystem structure and function."
  },
  {
    "Course": "FNR58700",
    "Title": "Advanced Spatial Ecology And GIS",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to the principles of landscape ecology and biogeography with a laboratory devoted to\nthe analysis of spatial data using geographic information systems and other database tools. Landscape ecology focuses\non the important relationships of landscape structure (pattern, heterogeneity) and ecological processes (movement of\nanimals, hydrologic dynamics) and how this information is used for natural resource management. Biogeography\nexamines ecological patterns and processes at larger scales (generally at subcontinental to global) for the purposes of\nmanaging plants and animals of global importance. In the last 15 years, tremendous efforts have been made to create\nspatial databases that help support research and management of natural resources at various scales. The lab will focus\non the use and application of these databases that are common in natural resource management settings. Typically\noffered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "GER66400",
    "Title": "Middle High German",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces students to the Middle High German language, the language of medieval\nliterary texts written in German between 1050 and 1350. The language of this period is significantly different in\nspelling, vocabulary, and grammar when compared to Modern Standard German. The course also provides an\nintroduction to various genres of medieval German literary texts from this period. Many of the foundational works in\nthe German tradition come from this period, including those of the so-called \"golden age\" of medieval German\nliterature from 1170 to 1230. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "GER67900",
    "Title": "Seminar In German Linguistics",

  {
    "Course": "HK44300",
    "Title": "Neuroscience Of Movement",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course students will learn about the neuroscience behind the control, sensation and\nperception of human movement. The course is divided into five sections. In the first section, students learn about the\nsensory systems with human movement. In the second section, students learn about the basic CNS building blocks\nunderlying movement control and perception. In the third section, the control of balance and locomotion is the central\ntopic. In the fourth section students learn about the higher brain functions involved in cognition. The final section of the\nclass examines issues regarding learning, development, and brain plasticity. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HK44400",
    "Title": "Balance Rehab In Older Adults",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course, students learn about the decline in motor function that occurs in older adults and\ntechniques to improve motor function in an older population. Topics include decreased balance control, loss of muscle\nstrength, and declines in adaptive locomotion as a function of age. Students enrolled in this class also participate in an\noff-campus lab. In the lab, students are paired with an older adult and use the knowledge gained in lecture to improve\nthe motor function of the older adult. This class provides students with a unique opportunity to gain hands-on\nexperience working with an older population. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits:\n3.00"

    "Course": "HK61100",
    "Title": "Data Analysis In Health And Kinesiology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This student-driven course addresses a variety of data analysis issues in health, kinesiology, and\nrelated fields (e.g., education, psychology).     "Title": "School Of Health Sciences Freshman Honors Project",

    "Description": "This course is for Freshman students in the School of Health Sciences Honors Program. In this\ncourse students will earn credit for work completed on their Honors Project under supervision of their faculty mentor.\nStudents enroll in this course during the spring semester concurrently with HSCI 19501. During the fall semester in\nHSCI 19501, students will be matched to a faculty mentor in the research area of their choice and complete a Project\nDescription Form based upon the work to be completed during this course. Course meeting times and frequency are to\nbe set by the student and faculty mentor with an estimated commitment of 3-4 hours per week. Hours are to be arranged\nbetween the student and the faculty mentor, with at least weekly or biweekly meetings set aside for a one-on-one\nsession between the student and faculty mentor. Some students may also be matched to professional mentors off\ncampus depending on their interests and future goals. The regular meeting times should be set during the first week of\nclass. Working hours must not conflict with other course obligations or consume too much of students' study time.\nPermission of department required. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "HSCI31000",
    "Title": "Imaging In Medicine",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will introduce students to develop essential understandings of all primary medical\nimaging techniques utilized in hospitals such as Computer tomography, X-ray imaging, MRI, Ultrasound and Nuclear\nmedicine imaging modalities. In addition, this course introduces the student to human anatomy as\nseen in the transverse, coronal, and sagittal planes.     "Description": "Course presents an introduction to the principles of radiation detection and measurement, including\nstatistical models, counting statistics, error analysis, detection limits, ionization chambers, proportional counters, GM\ncounters, scintillation counters, gamma-ray spectroscopy, solid-state detectors, TLDs, track-etch and bubble detectors.\nTypically offered Fall.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HSCI33300",
    "Title": "Introduction To Immunology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to Immunology will meet twice weekly and provide an overview of this evolving field\nof science with an emphasis on the clinical implications and application of learned knowledge. The immunologic\nmechanisms associated with the normal and abnormal immune response will be discussed and students will put this\nknowledge into practice by directing their own case study. In addition, a number of common clinical concerns with\nrespect to immunity will be reviewed. Furthermore, we will explore the critical role our knowledge of this branch of\nscience plays in patient diagnosis, treatment and care both now and in the future. Typically offered Spring.Credits:\n3.00"

    "Course": "HSCI33400",
    "Title": "Lung Physiology And Medicine",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course will explore the normal functioning of the respiratory system, along with a variety of\ndiseases and disorders affecting this system. Special emphasis will be placed upon diseases which result from, or are\naggravated by, environmental pollutants. Individual lung disorders will then be discussed with consideration of the sources of air pollution\ncontaminants and the interaction of those contaminants with normal lung tissue.Credits: 2.00"

  },
  {
    "Course": "HSCI35300",
    "Title": "Occupational Safety Management And Culture",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The Occupational Health and Safety Manager assumes a critical role within an organization -\nprotecting the employees from suffering work-related injuries, illnesses, and fatalities. This job requires a number of\napproaches to achieve this aim, including employee training, hazard identification and abatement, safety policy\ndevelopment, and incident investigation. The health and safety manager often forms a bridge between upper\nmanagement and front line employees. As such, the successful health and safety manager needs skill sets which\ntransfer across organizational levels. This course will explore strategies managing an effective health and safety\nprogram within an organization. Management strategies will be viewed from multiple perspectives. In relation to the\nfront line employee, topics will be explored to help engage employees in safe behaviors and dealing with situations in\nwhich failures occur, resulting in accidents. The upper management perspective will focus on the establishment of a\nsafety management system and effective techniques for measuring and reporting safety performance. A final\nperspective will consider both the front line employee and upper management. This perspective will explore strategies\nto establish a positive safety culture within an organization to bring the front line employees and upper management\ntogether in their vision of a safe and healthy workplace. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HSCI36000",
    "Title": "Everyday Toxicology: Poisonings From Clinics To Courtrooms",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Exposure to chemicals happens every day in human life through the living environment and diet;\nyet the health impact and toxicological consequences of these exposures are often unknown to general populations.\nThis 300-level course examines basic concepts of toxicology in human health as they apply to the exposure of\nenvironmental agents, e.g., chemicals, metals, and poisons in daily life and attempted poisoning in criminal cases and\npolitical assassins. With an emphasis on historical accounts of poisonings and cases analyses, the course describes\ncommonly encountered chemicals and poisons, their symptoms, clinical diagnosis, basic toxicological mechanisms, and\nmedical interventions. Students will also learn some of the large scale environmental and occupational incidents that\nhave led to legal actions, and the role of toxicology in forensic investigation of purposed poisoning. The course is ideal\nto students who are inspired to become a future healthcare professional in any of the health-oriented pre-professional\nprograms or students with majors in biomedical health sciences, environmental and occupational health sciences,\nmedical laboratory science, and/or public health.Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "HSCI52000",
    "Title": "Risk Assessment In Environmental Health",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Risk assessment as used in environmental health is the scientific process used to determine the\nextent of human exposure to an environmental hazard, and the type and quantify of health effects that are likely to\nresult from these exposures. Information derived from risk assessments are used as the basis for setting regulatory\nguidelines, determinations of whether a given situation is \"safe\" or \"hazardous\" throughout government and\nindustry. This course will cover the process and steps needed to performing a risk assessment, how risk\ncommunication can be used to discuss results of a risk assessment, and the use of risk management as a tool to translate\nresults of a risk assessment into policy.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "HSCI56200",
    "Title": "Analytical Toxicology And Pathology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Historically, toxicology has been defined as the study of the adverse effects of xenobiotics. Today,\ntoxicology encompasses much broader areas, including the study of endogenous compounds, physical agents, and even\nusing toxicants as research tools. Basic and introductory toxicology courses cover the principles of toxicant metabolism\nand target organ toxicity. This course, Analytical Toxicology and Toxicologic Pathology is focused on the research and\nclinical applications of these principles. Two major areas will be covered: (1) principles of toxicant detection in\nbiological matrices and (2) the assessment of pathological effects caused by toxicant exposure in biological systems.\nLaboratory sessions associated with each major topic allow students to have hands-on experience in these advanced"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HSCI57000",
    "Title": "Introduction To Medical Diagnostic Imaging",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course teaches the fundamentals of medical imaging, including the basic physics and\nengineering associated with each imaging modality (CT, MRI, PET, and ultrasound), as well as mathematics and\ncomputational tools associated with image reconstruction and image processing. The course is intended for students in\nhealth sciences, biomedical engineering, physics, and life sciences. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HSCI57200",
    "Title": "Radiation Oncology Physics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introductory course to the physical principles, equipment, processes, imaging guidance, and\nclinical techniques involved in the treatment of cancer patients with external radiation beams and radioactive sources.\nVarious external radiation beam types and their energy deposition characteristics are described. Treatment planning\ndose calculation algorithms and point dose calculations are discussed. The use of international dosimetry protocols for\nradiation beam calibration are covered in detail. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "HSCI58000",
    "Title": "Occupational Biomechanics And Ergonomics",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Occupational safety is a cross-disciplinary area concerned with protecting the safety, health and\nwelfare of people engaged in work. Occupational ergonomics is a branch of science that focuses on optimizing the\nrelationships between workers and their work environment. This course focuses on the principles and applications of\nsafety and ergonomics as it applies to workers. The first part of the course will consist of lectures on the fundamentals\nof safety standards and liability and the development of work-related musculoskeletal disorders, ergonomic risk factors\nincluding work practices, tools and workstation design. The last part will consist of identification and use of safety and\nergonomic controls to reduce and prevent work-related fatalities, injuries, and musculoskeletal disorders. Credits: 2.00"
