  {
    "Course": "HSCI67100",
    "Title": "Biochemical Toxicology",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Toxicologists in all fields are concerned with mechanism of action or how a specific toxicant or\nclass of toxicants produces toxicity. Introductory toxicology courses typically focus on the adverse effects exerted by a\nspecific compound, with some examination of mechanisms. The entire focus of this upper level graduate course is on\nthe \"how\" and the \"why\", or a detailed examination of biochemical mechanism of toxicity. There will be some lectures,\nbut the majority of the course will consist of student-led discussions on specific mechanisms of action. Further,\nstudents will write a review-style article on a chosen mechanism of action. Prerequisite: HSCI 56000. Typically offered\nSpring.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HSCI67200",
    "Title": "MRI Quality Assurance Internship I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This internship course provides didactic training and practical experience in clinical diagnostic\nmedical physics. Students will spend 3-4 hours per week learning the responsibilities of a medical physicist in MRI\nquality assurance (QA) such as MRI system performance testing, setting up weekly MRI QA procedures, analysis of\nMRI QA data, and annual clinical system evaluations. In Part I students will observe and review the weekly MRI QA\ntests performed by the MR Technologists on clinical MRI scanners and be involved with data analysis of these tests\n(image quality assessment, reporting). Annual MRI system performance evaluations of different clinical scanners will\nbe observed and discussed. This includes assessing magnetic field homogeneity, slice position accuracy and slice\nthickness accuracy, and performance of radio frequency coil tests on the various coils available at different clinical\nMRI sites in the Indianapolis area. Students will also work as a team with the instructors on a course project to develop\nand evaluate advanced MR QA methods and procedures. Prerequisites: HSCI 57000. Having documented experience in\nrunning an MRI scanner, e.g. having primary operator status on one of the research scanners at Purdue or IU. Level II\nMRI Safety Training: http://www.indiana.edu/~mri/safety_nonIU/safety.html. Permission of instructor required.\nTypically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HSCI67300",
    "Title": "MRI Quality Assurance Internship II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This internship course provides didactic training and practical experience in clinical diagnostic\nmedical physics. Students will spend 3-4 hours per week learning the responsibilities of a medical physicist in MRI\nquality assurance (QA) such as MRI system performance testing, setting up weekly MRI QA procedures, analysis of\nMRI QA data, and annual clinical system evaluations. In Part II of the course, MRI system performance evaluations of\ndifferent clinical scanners will be performed by the students independently following the ACR guidelines. This\nincludes assessing magnetic field homogeneity, slice position accuracy and slice thickness accuracy, and performance\nof radio frequency coil tests on the various coils available at different clinical MRI sites in the Indianapolis area.\nStudents will also work as a team with the instructors on a course project to develop and evaluate advanced MR QA\nmethods and procedures. Prerequisites: HSCI 67200. (This course provides the theoretical basis and opportunity to\nobserve MRI QA on clinical scanners, and forms the basis for this course, Part II). Permission of instructor required.\nTypically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "HHS40000",
    "Title": "Intercultural Learning In Health And Human Sciences - Lived\nExperiences",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "to 6.00. This course focuses on intercultural learning in health and human sciences through direct\nexperiences in a foreign country, whose culture is unique as a whole yet diverse across its different regions. Students\nwill be guided in cognitive and affective learning through observing the destination's culture and society and interacting\nwith its people. By direct exposure to the local customs, health conditions, history, human relations, lifestyle, and\nreligion as they travel across the foreign destination, students are expected to develop a deeper appreciation and\nempathy for cultural values and traditions that are different from their own.     "Course": "HIST30805",
    "Title": "History Of Life Sciences",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will examine the development of life sciences from 1750 to the present, introducing\nstudents to critical problems related to biology and society through the study of primary and secondary sources. The\n\"life sciences\" include all the sciences that deal with life as an organic entity. A prominent theme in this historical\ntreatment is the impact of social and political ideas on the life sciences. Topics will include theories of life, the origin of\nlife, taxonomy and classification, theories of development, natural selection, genetics, eugenics, science and religion,\nthe evolutionary synthesis, biodiversity, ecology and environmentalism, sociobiology, the discovery of DNA, cognition\nand the brain, and gender in science. Students will develop crucial skills in the interpretation of primary and secondary\nsources, research, analysis, and presentation. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "HIST33300",
    "Title": "Science And Society In Western Civilization I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A survey of the main lines in the development of science and society in Western civilization from\nearliest times to Newton's discovery of gravitation. Beginning with prehistory and Egyptian and Mesopotamian\ncivilizations, the course treats in more detail the Greeks and Romans. The course then considers science during the\nMiddle Ages, examining the transmissions of ancient science and its incorporation into the body of Christian doctrines.\nThe course concludes with the new efforts of physicians and astronomers to free their studies from the influence of the\nChurch and antiquity, and the new accommodations between science and society during the Scientific Revolution.\nTypically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HIST33400",
    "Title": "Science And Society In Western Civilization II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course considers Western science and society from the time of Newton to the present.\nBeginning with Copernicus to Newton, topics next include biological classification, modern chemistry, and the onset of\nthe industrial revolution. For the nineteenth century the course stresses the maturation of biology. Darwinian evolution,\nthe dynamic synthesis and electromagnetic studies, and the second industrial revolution. In the twentieth century, the\ncourse covers modern physics, the life sciences, the understanding of the universe, and the interaction between pure and\napplied science. The course concludes with some of the modern social and political problems which science caused by\nits success. Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "HIST61000",
    "Title": "History: Theory And Methods",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This is the first part of an introductory two-course sequence for new graduate students intended to\nacquaint them with some important issues regarding the modern professional practice of history. This semester\nconcentrates on historiography, theoretical questions, and methodological debates that today's working historians\ninevitably encounter. Students read about the practice of historical scholarship and read several important example texts\nrepresenting different approaches to the discipline over the past 200 years. Students write several short book reviews,\nposition papers, and a mock grant proposal during this semester. The course is required of incoming graduate students\nin history. It usually will be followed by HIST 61100, Research Practicum. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "HONR22000",
    "Title": "Community Of Inquiry",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course is for new members of the Honors College community, who entered as continuing\nPurdue students or transferred to Purdue. It, being your first or one of your first courses in the Honors College, is\ndesigned to help you hone some of the fundamental learning outcomes of an honors education: interdisciplinary\nthinking, critical thinking, problem solving, research thinking, collaboration, and global awareness. You will also\nengage with the pillars of the Honors College and develop community within the Honors College. To accomplish these\nobjectives, the course is simultaneously project-based and experiential. You will work in multi-disciplinary teams on\napplied-research that emphasizes critical and multi-dimensional thinking about real-world problems. Through project-\nbased learning, you will move your skills beyond identifying and understanding a problem to identifying and\nformulating solutions to that problem. The problem addressed in the course is local or global in scope and has social,\neconomic, political, and/or environmental implications for our local and/or global community as well as begs a multi-\ndisciplinary, innovative solution. Continuing in the vein of experiential learning and of building your honors ethos, you\nwill attend events (some as a class, others individually) and participate in programs in the Honors College and across\ncampus that embody the Honors College's pillars: Community and Global Engagement, Leadership, Research, and\nInterdisciplinary Academics. You will curate a schedule of events that take place during the semester and reflect on\nthese experiences. Permission of department required.Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "HONR22200",
    "Title": "Solutions Lab Global",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "In this course, students from Purdue University (West Lafayette, Indiana) and at universities\nabroad will collaborate virtually in interdisciplinary teams to identify solutions to a major global challenge. Each\nsemester, the theme of the global challenge changes. At the start of the course, students at both universities will meet\ntogether as a class to learn about the topic from a range of disciplinary perspectives through guest lectures, assigned\nreadings, and class discussions. Students will then be divided into interdisciplinary teams with members from both\nuniversities and provided a prompt related to the semester's theme. Teams will spend several weeks of the course\nfocused on researching, developing, and packaging their solutions, before presenting them publicly at the end of the\nterm. In addition to increasing knowledge of the topic and improving teamwork skills, students in this course will\nadvance in intercultural knowledge, skills, and attitudes through their international collaborative experience.Credits:\n2.00"

    "Course": "HONR31200",
    "Title": "Jazz",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Jazz artists \"speak to each other in the language of music.\" In Jazz, we will explore the nature of\nthis artistic conversation with many of it's cultural influences, geographical variations, and temporal iterations.\nThroughout our time together we will interrogate varying facets of the social impact such a conversation facilitates.\nFurthermore, we will explore the musical language of jazz with it's power to make collective performance stronger.\nAnd we will investigate the ways in which this artists' talk became the \"talk of the town\" and country as a medium\nthrough which people could break from dominant cultures. We will make sense of and process our journey by creating\nour own jazz ensemble, featuring the layered textures of our lives as inspiration for the note and lyric.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "HONR46000",
    "Title": "Technological Justice",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course, students will study interdisciplinary approaches to technology ethics for responding\nto today's pressing technological dilemmas in a range of contexts, from healthcare, mass incarceration, and airport\nsecurity, to social media, smart cities, and space travel. Students will grapple with how historical and present-day\ninequalities, institutional environments, decision-making cultures, and regulatory systems impact the technological\ndesign process and distribution of technology's risks and rewards in society. We will ask ourselves how relations of\npower inform the ways technologies are designed and experienced, as well as how power shapes dominant and\ninsurgent approaches to achieving technological justice. The primary deliverable in this class is for you to conceive of\nand carry out your own \"Technological Justice\" Project, based on your interests, passions, and personal and/or\nprofessional goals.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HONR46100",
    "Title": "Well-Being",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Copenhagen, Zurich, Helsinki, Stockholm, and Tokyo are the five most livable cities in the world\naccording to MONOCLE's 2021 Quality of Life Index. They are the highest ranking cities when using metrics to\nmeasure crime, emergency services' response time, transportation networks, cycling culture, food, drink, retail, and the\nnumber of independent bookshops. MONOCLE's Quality of Life survey is one among the many that exist to rank the\nworld's best cities, but wealth is one theme that emerges from among the varying indices and their respective results.\nThe metrics, indeed the participants responding to the metrics, represent populations of people with high levels of\ndiscretionary income. How might the metrics reflect different values if these indices include a different kind of\nparticipant, such as the urban poor?Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "HONR46200",
    "Title": "Protein Design With FoldIt",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The protein folding problem is a grand challenge in biology. How does a protein's amino acid\nsequence dictate its three-dimensional structure? FoldIt is an online game in which players determine the most stable\nfolded structure of hypothetical proteins that have been predicted by unique computer algorithms to perform specific\nfunctions in the cell. Students in this course will be introduced to the mechanics of the FoldIt software to fold\ncomputer-predicted proteins into their native structures as well as design novel proteins that can bind and deactivate the\nCovid19 spike protein.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "HORT53100",
    "Title": "Applied Plant Genomics",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course aims to provide students an introduction to the theory and practice of functional\ngenomics in plants. The course is centered around the many forms in which DNA sequencing technologies are applied\nto understand plant genomes, their variation and their function. This is a full semester course\nthat meets twice a week for: 1. A lecture that covers the rationale and theory of the topic and 2.   {
    "Course": "HDFS41800",
    "Title": "Understanding Autism",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(PSY 41800, SLHS 41800) This course will explore the etiology, neuroscience, diagnosis, and\ntreatment of autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Approached from a multi-disciplinary perspective this course brings\ntogether gene, brain, and behavioral sciences with the aim of developing a better understanding of autism. The course\nwill begin with an overview of ASD as a complex behavioral phenotype. This will include discussion of the history\nASD and the expansion of the diagnostic criteria associated with the disorder. This introduction will be followed by\nseveral classes in which we will examine some of the key domains of impairment in ASD: reciprocal social interaction,\nlanguage and communication, and restricted and repetitive behaviors. We will also consider the deficits associate with,\nbut not defining of ASD, and examine co-morbid conditions frequently present in individuals with ASD. We will then\naddress the topics of brain architecture, neurochemistry, and genetics and gene expression, all of which we will attempt\nto relate back to the behavioral features of autism. We will end the course with a review of treatment practices and their\nefficacy and an examination of impact of ASD on the family and society. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course gives students a basic grounding in the class of statistical techniques known as\nmultilevel modeling (MLM), also known as hierarchical linear modeling (HLM), mixed models, or random coefficient\nmodels. The\nfocus is on three types of multilevel models: growth-curve models, organizational models, and daily experience\nmodels. Students will also learn how to use SAS Proc Mixed for conducting MLM analyses. Students are assumed to"

  },
  {
    "Course": "IPPH68000",
    "Title": "Pharmacokinetics And Biopharmaceutics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Pharmacokinetics (PK) is the study of the time course of the absorption, distribution, metabolism\nand excretion (ADME) of a drug, compound or new chemical entity (NCE) after its administration to the body.\nBiopharmaceutics examines the relationship between the physical/chemical nature of a drug, the dosage form and the\nroute of administration on the rate and extent of systemic drug absorption. Knowledge of the pharmacokinetic and\nbiopharmaceutics properties of an NCE are critical to its selection as a lead candidate in a drug discovery program, its\nuse as a functional research tool, and its use as a therapeutic agent. This course will be an overview of the development\nof pharmacokinetic principles, including guidelines for conducting clinical studies, and equations required to\ncharacterize the disposition of drugs and their metabolite(s). Students will develop the ability to probe the mechanisms\nand physiological processes responsible for ADME. Pharmacodynamics, the relationship between drug concentration\nand effect, and the issues surrounding stereospecific PK will presented. Prerequisites: Admission to the IPPH graduate\nprogram and at least one course in pharmacology and one course in mammalian or human physiology. Permission of\ninstructor required. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {

    "Course": "ILS20100",
    "Title": "Introduction To Digital Humanities",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This is an interdisciplinary foundational course that combines theory and practice to teach students\nin and about digitally mediated culture. Accordingly, this course fosters a critical understanding of the digital and its\nimplication for the development of a technologically driven society. Students will be introduced to digital inquiry and\ncritical practice and explore the ways that the digital transforms knowledge acquisition and production across the\nhumanities, social sciences and sciences. Students will engage in readings and activities that help them form\nsubstantive perspectives on the digital formulations and practice through digital technologies and tools. Students will\nalso experiment with digital methods and tools by building a digital project. This course places an emphasis on engaged\nlearning through online and in-class discussion, digital activities, and collaborative work. Permission of instructor\nrequired.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "KOR10100",
    "Title": "Korean Level I",
    "CreditHours": 4.0,
    "Description": "This course is the first half of the Elementary Korean language sequence. It is designed for those\nwho have no prior (or very limited) knowledge of Korean. Lecture will introduce new material and explain\nconversational patterns considering grammatical, lexical, and pragmatic aspects of Korean. Some class meetings will\nbe conducted entirely in Korean. Emphasis is placed on the fundamentals of listening, speaking, reading, and writing.\nIn addition, students will be exposed to everyday life contexts (e.g., language use, culture, etc.) likely to be encountered\nin contemporary Korean society.     "Description": "This course aims to help students develop their language skills in four areas-speaking, listening,\nreading, and writing- in Korean at the advanced level.   {
    "Course": "LC32300",
    "Title": "Humanities-Informed Engineering Projects",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "to 3.0. The main goal of this course is to encourage students to think like global engineers by\nfocusing curricular activities on engineering case studies from a humanistic-engineering perspective. The case studies\nexamined in the course may include past, present, and hypothetical engineering successes and failures; analyses will\nrequire engineering skills combined with understanding of cultural perspectives of local communities and cultural\ncontext (i.e., sociological, anthropological, and historical information and analyses that contribute to cultural\nunderstanding). This humanities-infused approach will encourage students to develop a new mindset-a way of seeing\ncurrent and hypothetical engineering plans, projects, and impacts through local communities' pasts and presents, unique\nvalues, perspectives, and daily ways of life."

    "Course": "LC47500",
    "Title": "Theories Of Teaching World Languages",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to assist you in the process of becoming a skilled professional who can\nteach world language(s). You will develop an understanding of the connection between effective language teaching\nand successful language learning, be able to think critically about your own teaching and teaching materials, and gain\nan understanding of various theories, methods, approaches, and techniques in world language teaching. Areas of\nemphasis include the nature of language learning theories, early approaches to language pedagogy, communicative\nlanguage teaching methodology, the relationship between theory and practice, aspects of interaction between speakers\nin the classroom, skills-based theories, sociocultural perspectives, individual differences between learners, and usage-\nbased approaches to second language acquisition. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "LING50100",
    "Title": "Language Acquisition",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course offers an introduction to main linguistic, psycholinguistic and sociocultural approaches\nto language acquisition theory and research. Through extensive reading, students will develop a deep understanding of\ncentral issues affecting language acquisition in typically developing children, including age effects, and input and\noutput conditions in the acquisition of syntax, semantics, phonology, lexicon and morphology. Emphasis will be made\non experimental approaches and research methods in the acquisition of syntax in L1 and child bilingual development.\nTypically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "LING57000",
    "Title": "Field Methods In Linguistics",
    "CreditHours": 4.0,
    "Description": "This course deals with the basic techniques for collecting language data, and is designed to\nreproduce and explore the conditions and methods of linguistic fieldwork in a classroom. The course also addresses\nquestions related to the ethics of retrieving linguistic data, the relations between the linguist and the speaking\ncommunities, and the use of the collected data. A non-Indoeuropean lesser-studied language will be examined with the\nhelp of a native speaker of the language. The main area of its grammar will be covered: phonetic and phonological\nsystem, inflectional and derivational morphology, basic syntactic structures and basic semantic phenomena. The final\ngoal is to obtain a basic grammatical description of the language. Lab sessions will be directed towards the training in\nthe software and audio and video tools used for the trade. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 4.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "MGMT26100",
    "Title": "Introduction To Supply Chain Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course seeks to introduce general concepts in supply chain management, including\nprocurement, supply planning, demand planning, and logistics. This course is designed around a corporate partnership\nto provide students with the opportunity to collaborate on solving a large-scale supply chain challenge. In the first five\nweeks of the semester, students will be introduced to basics of SCM through lectures, cases, and assignments.\nBeginning in the sixth week, students will form teams to work on a real-world case presented by the corporate partner,\na complex problem broken down into six learning areas, each with a corresponding deliverable.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MGMT28500",
    "Title": "Knowledge Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Practical, hands-on introduction to the major techniques of computer-based knowledge\nmanagement including: text management, data base management, ad hoc inquiry, forms management, customized\nreport generation, business graphics, spreadsheet analysis, and programming. These are examined from the standpoint\nof how they can be personally used by managers to solve typical problems. All are presented and illustrated within a\nunified conceptual framework and particular emphasis is given to the integration of techniques. The four major\ninterface approaches are introduced. Students are also acquainted with the topics of business expert systems and remote\ncommunications. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "MGMT42000",
    "Title": "Consumer Analytics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The course focuses on understanding how and why consumers behave the way they do. We explore\nbehavioral and economics theories that help us better understand and predict consumers' behavior, and learn about how\nthese theories can be applied in developing marketing strategies. The key topics covered in the course include: (i)\ndiscussion of a framework for analyzing consumers' decision making; (ii) review of relevant psychological,\nsociological and economics concepts; (iii) discussion of marketing research methods for studying consumer behavior.\nWe apply the concepts covered in these topics to measure consumers' beliefs, attitudes, intentions, and behavior and\npredict how consumers will react to different marketing strategies. Finally, we consider the application of behavior\ntheory to the design of marketing strategies, including product design, pricing, and advertising. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "MGMT47200",
    "Title": "Advanced Spreadsheet Modeling And Simulation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course covers up-to-date and practical spreadsheet modeling tools that can be applied to a\nwide variety of business problems from finance, marketing, and operations. The topical coverage consists of the\nfollowing five modules: (1) Excel functions, skills and financial models; (2) deterministic and stochastic optimization\ntechniques to determine the best managerial actions under internally-and/or externally-imposed constraints; (3)\nprobability distribution fitting techniques to find the most likely description of the uncertainty in future business; (4)\nsimulation modeling techniques to discover and analyze the risk and uncertainties in business environment and\nprocesses; (5) application of spreadsheet modeling and simulation techniques in forecasting asset dynamics( stock\nprice) and pricing options and real investment opportunities. This course provides hands-on experience of computer\napplication using Microsoft Excel and the spreadsheet add-ins @RISK,RISKOptimizer, SimQuick, etc. Typically\noffered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "MGMT49400",
    "Title": "IBE Capstone",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The objective of the IBE Capstone course is to provide students with the opportunity to apply and\nintegrate what they have learned from prior courses in \"Real World\" settings. There are no traditional classes. Rather,\nstudents will work in self-managed teams of 5-6 on projects that have both business and engineering elements with the\nsupport of a mentor; in many cases the mentor will be from a sponsoring company. The role of the company mentor is\nto provide advice and guidance to the student team as well as to expose the students to the approaches and processes\nused in industrial and commercial organizations. The course instructors will also meet with the student teams on a\nweekly basis to assess progress and provide guidance.\nPossible options for the projects include: 'Product Design' and 'Business Solution'. The Product Design projects would\nbe focused on the marketing, technical, and economic feasibility of a new product concept. The Business Solution\nprojects would be focused on technical issues in a business context and developing solutions to a \"real world\" problem\npresented by a sponsoring company. Examples of these projects might include use of 3-D printing for spare and\nreplacement parts or incorporation of autonomous transportation into a company's operations and supply chain.\nTypically Offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "MGMT51100",
    "Title": "Fixed Income Securities",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to fixed income securities. Discusses a variety of contracts-starting with pure discount\nbonds, coupon bonds, and callable bonds. Continues with options on bonds, caps, floors, and interest rate swaps.\nIntroduces the theory of the term structure and present models for pricing fixed income securities. Topics include: spot\nand forward markets for debt instruments, simple models for interest rate risk management, duration, convexity,\norganized exchange-traded interest rate contracts, interest rate swaps, pricing relationships and the theory of the term\nstructure, and single factor models for pricing interest rate claims. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 2.00"

    "Course": "MGMT53600",
    "Title": "Employment & Diversity Law For Managers",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Managers, regardless of your industry, will routinely face HR and employment issues that collide\nwith the law. In this course, we will examine many laws and the practical ways you can stay on the right side of the\nlaw. Don't worry, you aren't in a law school class and I don't expect you to become employment attorneys. However, I\nwill help you gain a working knowledge of employment laws including: The Civil Rights Act, ADA, ADEA, FMLA,\nFLSA, and a host of alphabet soup. We will also apply these laws from posting a job description to recruiting to hiring\nto employee reviews to terminating an employee. While I can't guarantee you will never be sued by a disgruntled\ncurrent or former employee, I can help you put yourself and your company in the best possible position to defend that\nsuit.   },
  {
    "Course": "MGMT55500",
    "Title": "Leading Management Of Diversity And Inclusion In Organizations",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. This course is designed to help students more effectively manage self, peers, teams, clients\nand firms in diverse organizational settings and lead change. People and leaders in organizations are constantly\nworking with members of different backgrounds, social identities, and experiences, fostering increased attention to\ndiversity and inclusion in an employment and organizational context.[1] For example, women represent over half of\nthe labor for 57% (BLS, 2018) [2] but are severely under-represented at senior management levels and in high-paying\ntechnical and professional fields (Kossek & Buzzanell, 2018)[3]. Ethnic and racial minorities are also severely under-\nrepresented . The U. S. population is increasingly diverse as 40% of the population identifies as racial or ethnic\nminorities (U.S. Bureau of Census, 2019) including African-American (13.4%), Hispanic- American (18.3%), Asian-\nAmerican (5.9%), American Indian or Alaska Native (1.3%), and European American (60% ) as well as a growing\nnumber of individuals who identify with more than one race or ethnicity (U. S. Bureau of Census, 2019)[4]. Further,\n26% of the population has some form of disability, and 16% are over the age of 65 (U. S. Bureau of Census,\n2018). Many other minority groups can face workplace marginalization challenges such as veterans, minority religious\ngroup members (Muslims, Jews, Hinduism; Catholic; Latter Day Saints), immigrants, people with mental or intellectual\ndisabilities, immigrants, & LGBTQ persons (Stone, Lukaszewski, & Dulebohn, 2020)[5]. When leveraged effectively,\nthese differences in social identity and values can help attract and retain talent, strengthen societal and community\neconomic equality, support organizational and team effectiveness; but when overlooked, or mismanaged, these\ndifferences can increase turnover, conflict, stress, talent under-utilization, and harm career and work-life wellbeing, and\nproductivity. The class focuses on management of gender and diversity for inclusion and equity from an individual\nemployee, leader and team/organizational perspective in a workplace context. The goal of this class is to take a multi-\nlevel approach to help you learn how to lead the management of diversity and inclusion through a) improving your\nability to work in diverse teams, as well as b) developing your ability to lead, develop, and implement strategies to\nfoster cultural and structural change to support the management of gender and diversity toward enhanced\norganizational effectiveness. Men, as well as women, majority and minority individuals, will be able to leverage the\nskills taught in this course when making their own career decisions, as well as when managing, being managed by, or\ncollaborating with others; or leading and changing organizations to support new ways of working. We integrate\nmultiple levels and lenses to understand diversity and inclusion. From an individual leadership perspective, we tackle\nthe question: \"Why does diversity matter in employing organizations and business, what is the state of the art evidence-\nbased knowledge, and what does it mean to me personally in my career and my leadership beliefs.\" Specifically, we\nfocus on the business and social science processes - including attitudes toward in-groups and out-groups, stereotyping,\nidentity, privilege, and power, intersectionality, discrimination, bias, equity influence opportunity, bystander\nawareness, and perspective taking - this affects how members of different social groups perceive and interact with one\nanother. Since managing social identity increasingly involves managing work-life boundaries and work and non-work\npublic and private selves, we will also learn about authenticity choices and social and public/professional identity\nboundary management. From an organizational and group perspective, we address the questions: \"What are best\npractices for successful diversity management?\" We will focus on organizational and institutional structures and\ncultures and their relations to strategies for creating diversity through management practices; how to create an inclusive\nculture and positive climate for inclusion and talent management, and developing and retaining diverse talent and foster\ninnovation and organizational effectiveness across multiple levels of intervention (individual, group, intergroup,\norganizational, and societal). We discuss how to conduct an organizational diagnosis of the current diversity climate\nand barriers and facilitators for creating a multicultural workplace and a flexible environment supportive of many\nidentities, and how assumptions may vary across industry and cultural contexts.Credits: 2.00 or 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "to 4.00 (West Lafayette) 3.00 (North Central). Oriented to managers, the course examines the firm's\ninternal systems for costing products or services and their interpretation.     "Course": "MGMT60200",
    "Title": "Valuation And Financial Statement Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Establishes how to use accounting information to make business and investment decisions.\nInternally, the information is used to assess performance of units, to evaluate performance of upper-level management,\nto monitor the firm's investment and financing decisions, and for comparison purposes with the firm's rivals.\nExternally, accounting information is used by financial analysts, investors and (potential) acquirers to assess the value\nof the firm, by creditors to assess its credit-worthiness, and by regulators.   {
    "Course": "MGMT60300",
    "Title": "Taxes And Business Strategy",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Provides a framework for analyzing tax planning. The framework offers an approach to tax\nplanning and business strategy that remains useful long after the next revision of the tax code. It offers an approach that\ncan be readily employed in an international setting. After developing the framework, it will be applied to a variety of\nbusiness settings that integrate topics from accounting, finance, and economics in order to provide a more complete\nunderstanding of the role of taxes in business strategy. Two important concepts will be applied: the concept of implicit\ntaxes (tax-induced differences in before tax rates of return) and the concept of tax clienteles (the effect of cross-\nsectional differences in tax rates). Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 2.00"

    "Title": "Communications For Accountants",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Accountants spend much of their time designing and writing reports, memos, etc. and explaining\nthose communications to others. They communicate regularly with external investors and creditors, regulators, clients\nand fellow professionals. This course is designed to help accounting students prepare for their professional careers by\nhelping them develop their written and oral communication skills.     "Course": "MGMT63650",
    "Title": "Accounting Ethics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to introduce students to the foundational elements underlying ethics and\nethical behavior, with an emphasis on ethical issues facing professional accountants. The course will provide students\nwith a framework of ethical reasoning, professional values and attitudes for exercising professional skepticism, and\nother behavior that is in the best interest of the public and accounting profession. The course will also review the core\nvalues of integrity, objectivity, and independence as well as rules of professional conduct. This course uses real-world\ncase studies and practical hands-on applications in order to enhance the student's ability to recognize ethical dilemmas\nand overcome them with sound ethical decision-making. Students successfully completing this course in a face-to-face,\ntraditional classroom setting may be assured that the course meets the Texas State Board of Public Accountancy\n(TSBPA) and Illinois Board of Examiners ethics course required to apply for taking the Uniform CPA\nExamination.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MGMT63750",
    "Title": "Advanced Taxation",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. This course is directed at students who wish to learn more about the taxation of business\nentities beyond the basic principles taught in MGMT 504 Introductory Tax Accounting or an equivalent course. The\ncourse will cover broad topics such as tax law sources and tax research; the tax advantages and disadvantages of\nvarious business entities as well as how entrepreneurs may choose the optimal entity for tax purposes; taxable and\nnontaxable methods of mergers, acquisitions, and divestitures; fundamental concepts of consolidated tax returns for C\nCorporations; and the accounting for income taxes under ASC 740."
  },

  {
    "Course": "MGMT63850",
    "Title": "Public Company Reporting & Regulation",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. This course introduces students to the Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) rules\nand regulations as they apply to U.S. companies and their auditors. Requirements for frequently encountered annual\nreporting responsibilities (e.g., Forms 10-K, 10-Q, 8-K, proxy statements, etc.) and registration statements are explored\nand analyzed. Actual SEC filings provide real-world applications and interpretation of the SEC's rules. Rules imposed\nby the primary U.S.-based stock exchanges are introduced as is the history of the SEC and current trends affecting this\nrule-making body. Additionally, this course encompasses the enforcement power of the SEC and its implications to\ncompanies, their officers, and accountants."

  {
    "Course": "MGMT63902",
    "Title": "Washington DC Accounting For Policy",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. This course offers students an intensive, distinctive, personal and professional development\nexperience, addressing critical public policy institutions, issues, and trends affecting the profession of accounting. Over\n3 days in Washington, D.C., participants meet with and gain a greater understanding of the role of regulatory agencies\nsuch as the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Participants\nalso have meetings and discussions with organizations governing the accounting profession, such as the American\nInstitute of Certified Public Accountants and the Center for Audit Quality, as well as more informal but important\norganizations such as trade associations and think tanks. The course often includes visits with members and staff from\nCongress and officials from the Executive Branch to understand their institutional roles in governing the profession.\nThese meetings include discussions of the relevant tax, securities, commodities, and oversight committees in Congress,\nfor example. Within the Executive Branch, discussions typically include the operations of forensic accounting and\ncompliance within agencies such as the U.S. Treasury and Internal Revenues Service and the Federal Bureau of\nInvestigation. Participants also gain practical insights into the strategic role of government relations, as well as the role\nof public policy lobbying and advocacy by the overall profession and individual firms, regarding issues that affect them\nand their clients. Other topical sessions often include discussions of cybersecurity policy, tax policy, and other topics\nrelevant to the profession and key clients."
  },

    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00.     "Title": "Venture Capital And Investment Banking",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "to 4.00. Examines the process of corporate value creation through financial policy choices. The\nsequence of topics roughly parallels the life cycle of a typical corporation.   {
    "Course": "MGMT64700",
    "Title": "Financial Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. The objective of this course is to provide students with the necessary skills to value and\nhedge a wide variety of derivatives contracts used in financial markets. The main tool of analysis of the course is\nstochastic calculus set in continuous-time. Some basic knowledge of stochastic processes would be helpful, but not\nessential: we will cover what we need in class. The course covers valuation of securities using modern martingale\nmethods as well as the necessary parameter estimation and numerical methods such as Monte Carlo simulations.\nApplications will include derivatives such as options on stocks, bonds and currencies, as well as valuation of\ndefaultable securities, and modeling the term structure of interest rates and risk management with Value-at-Risk.\nPrerequisites: MGMT 61400, or similar coursework with instructor permission. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits:\n2.00 or 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MGMT64810",
    "Title": "Marketing Analysis And Planning",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The course in Market Analysis and Planning examines the issues associated with the analysis of\nmarket opportunities and the formulation of strategic marketing plans to take advantage of market\nopportunities. Specific analysis issues include the identification of customer needs, competitive advantages, and\ncompany capabilities. Results of these analyses lead to choices the firm makes with regard to its market segmentation,\ntarget market selection, and positioning. Topics introduced in conjunction with these analyses include product life\ncycle analysis, product portfolio selection, and strategic resource allocation decisions. Aspects of resource allocation\ninclude decisions regarding market research and new product development (or product repositioning). Further, the\nallocation of firm resources directed at fostering market demand is examined, including the deployment of marketing\ncommunications to potential customers and salesforce efforts to attain distribution. A long-term perspective on market\nanalysis and planning is emphasized through the utilization of the Markstrat Simulation. For this computer simulation,\nstudent teams participate in multi-period decision-making for their respective companies. Prerequisite: MGMT 62000.\nTypically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 2.00"

    "Course": "MGMT65390",
    "Title": "HR Analytics",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. This course provides an introduction to the field of HR analytics. HR Analytics is an\nadvanced set of data analysis methodologies, tools and metrics for comprehensive workforce performance\nmeasurement and improvement. The objective of HR analytics is to drive evidence-based decisions and action in the\nworkplace. In addition to your instructor, you may hear from expert practitioners and corporate leaders who have \"been\nthere and done that\" leveraging a myriad of HR analytics along the way. We will also review (and hopefully expand)\nyour understanding of handling data including conceptualizing models, identifying key metrics, collecting data,\nanalyzing data, and presenting data in ways that tell a powerful story. Throughout our course, I will infuse consulting\nconcepts, methodologies, and lessons learned that combined with your analytic skills will help you to effectively serve\nas an HR Business Partner (internal HR consultant)."

    "Course": "MGMT65500",
    "Title": "Competitive Strategy",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. Examines how firms obtain and sustain superior returns through the development and\nimplementation of a competitive strategy at the business-unit level. Focus is on strategies that develop and exploit two\nsources of superior returns: unique value-creating resources (e.g., patents, brand equity, operational capabilities), and\npowerful positions in markets and supply chains. Participants are expected to be familiar with basic competitive\nstrategy concepts and tools, such as \"five-forces analysis\", the value chain, and generic strategies. Presents a more\nanalytical perspective of strategy, drawing from game theory. Prerequisites: MGMT 65000. Typically offered Fall\nSpring Summer.Credits: 2.00 or 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MGMT65700",
    "Title": "Manufacturing Strategy And Process Innovation",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "In recent years many firms have rediscovered manufacturing and operations as a potential source of\nstrategic advantage. In general, these firms have sought to develop capabilities in operations which provide a\nsustainable advantage in the marketplace. In addition, successful firms have developed processes for understanding the\ncross-functional implications of product and process choices. In this course, we will seek to understand the\ncircumstances under which particular operating capabilities are most beneficial and how such capabilities can be\ndeveloped so that operations can be exploited for competitive advantage. Concurrent Prerequisite: MGMT 61000,\n65000, 66000. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MGMT65900",
    "Title": "Strategic Management II",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "to 4.00. Further emphasis on understanding how organizations might achieve advantage relative to\ncompetitors. Focus is on corporate strategy: the decisions of a multi-business firm. Such decisions include: What range\nof businesses is appropriate within a single firm? What mode of expansion, e.g. alliance vs. acquisition, is appropriate?\nHow should a firm's administrative systems and structure be organized across multiple businesses or markets to achieve\nmaximum value? What is needed to foster innovation in the organization? Introduces a variety of analytical\nframeworks to help students qualitatively and quantitatively appraise corporate-level strategies given a firm's unique\nresource profile and the environment in which it competes. Prerequisite: MGMT 60000, 61000, 62000 and 65000.\nTypically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 2.00 to 4.00"

  {
    "Course": "MGMT66000",
    "Title": "Introduction To Operations Management",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "to 4.00 (West Lafayette) 3.00 (Calumet, North Central). As goods and services are produced and\ndistributed, they move through a set of inter-related operations or processes in order to match supply with demand. The\ndesign of these operations for strategic advantage, investment in improving their efficiency and effectiveness, and\ncontrolling these operations to meet performance objectives is the domain of Operations Management. The primary\nobjective of the course is to provide an overview of this important functional area of business. Prerequisite: MGMT\n67000, MGMT 67100.Credits: 2.00 to 4.00"

  {
    "Course": "MGMT68200",
    "Title": "Digital Business And Information Strategies",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The Internet and other emerging technologies have enabled new ways for companies to organize\ntheir businesses. Companies are also increasingly dealing with digital information that is different in many ways from\nother goods and services. The purpose of this course is to explore how new digital business models and digital\ninformation affect company strategy, market structure, and pricing. We will use lectures, cases, class discussions,\ngames, and team projects to examine a variety of topics including pricing and competition on the Internet, cross-\nchannel competition and marketing, \"Long Tail\", pricing of digital information, bundling, versioning, network effects,\nplatform, and a variety of other topics. Fundamental economic principles will be illustrated using business case studies.\nAt times, we will also discuss emerging digital technologies, business models and industry structures. Typically offered\nSpring.Credits: 2.00"

    "Description": "to 3.00. This course will build on design thinking and game design techniques to develop process,\npolicies, and/or products that appeal to human instincts. We will cover ideas that provide insights into, for example,\nnew product development, entrepreneurship or designing HR policies. To name a few examples of projects we will\ndiscuss, SAP's points-based system to encourage carpooling that helps the company save on large gas expenses; at\nchallenge.gov, the Whitehouse encourages innovative solutions through crowdsourcing; and at companies like Google,\nand Best-Buy, employees participate in information assimilation games called prediction markets providing\ninformation to senior managers about ongoing projects. In this course, you will examine the mechanisms behind\ndesigning for human instincts and thereby developing an understanding of their effective use in the modern firm.\nGamification is one form of design for human instincts. In order for any design to be effective, it should involve clearly\ndefined strategies and wellmanaged execution. To identify effective strategies, and metrics for the application of\ntechniques to business, this course will draw upon interdisciplinary source material as well as real-world case studies. It\nwill also identify a number of significant pitfalls to techniques, as well as notable legal and ethical issues, and the\nproblems with implementing radical change in established firms. As a part of this class, you will be designing, playing,\nand evaluating various games. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 1.00 to 3.00"
  },

Through a strong emphasis on data-centric computing, and quantitative critical\nthinking, this class covers key principles and techniques of machine learning.     "CreditHours": 3.0,

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

Project work drawn from\ncurrent problems in materials processing. Offered in alternate years. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "MSE52300",
    "Title": "Physical Ceramics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Physical and chemical processes responsible for microstructure development in modern ceramic\nmaterials, and the relationship between microstructures and physical properties. The material covered is divided into\nthree parts: solid state processes, including structural defects, diffusion, sintering and grain growth, reaction rates,\nnucleation and growth, and microstructure development; mechanical and thermal behavior, including deformation,\nstrength, thermal properties, and thermal and compositional stresses; and electrical and magnetic behavior, including\nelectrical conductivity, dielectric properties, and magnetic properties.   },
  {
    "Course": "MSE52400",
    "Title": "Mechanical Behavior Of Polymers",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will focus on the mechanical properties and behaviors of polymeric materials. The\ncourse will utilize fundamental solid and fluid mechanics to understand the response of bulk polymers (solid and liquid,\nabove and below Tg). The impact of deformation rate and temperature on the mechanical response of polymers will be\ncovered in detail. The course will start with an overview of linear elastic mechanics, move to rubber elasticity, and then\nviscoelasticity (concentrating on time-temperature superposition). We will also cover fluid dynamics and the rheology\nof non-Newtonian fluids. We will conclude with a section on deformation, yield, and fracture mechanisms (focusing on\nthose phenomena that are unique to polymers such as rubber cavitation, drawing, and crazing).Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MSE52500",
    "Title": "Struct-Property Relationships Of Engineering Polymers",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Structure-property relationships developed for commodity and engineering resins. Focus on\nconnecting bonding and polymer structure (i.e., molecular weight, tacticity, crystallinity as it regards spherulites) to\nmechanical (yield phenomena and fracture) and thermomechanical behavior (viscoelasticity). Thermal characterization\ntechniques, including DSC, TGA, TMA, and DMTA. Flow of polymer melts related to common melt processing\ntechniques (i.e., extrusion and injection molding). Offered in alternate years. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "MSE53100",
    "Title": "Quantitative Analysis Of Microstructure",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A review will be presented of basic probability theory and statistical analysis, with particular\nemphasis on terms and definitions of a microstructure. The properties accessible to quantification, the basic\nstereological relationships and the mathematical foundations, and the microstructural tools needed to quantify the\nstructure will be emphasized. The last one-third of the course will cover applications of quantitative metallography to\nproblems in failure analysis, solidification, heat treatment, phase equilibria, and deformation behavior.   {
    "Course": "MSE55000",
    "Title": "Properties Of Solids",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Critical examination of fundamental concepts of physical properties of solids and the relation of\nthese properties to thermal and mechanical treatments. Approach is atomistic rather than electronic, and an emphasis is\nmade to connect the fundamental knowledge of solid state physics to actual processing of materials and to a qualitative\nunderstanding of current research in the area of materials science.   },
  {
    "Course": "MSE55500",
    "Title": "Deformation Mechanisms In Crystalline Solids",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Focuses on the mechanisms for deformation and fracture of metal, intermetallic, and ceramic\nmaterials, with particular emphasis on high temperature properties. The industrial success of superalloys, dispersion-\nstrengthened alloys, stainless steels, composites, and thermal barrier coatings will serve as the basis for exploring the\nrelationship between composition, microstructure, and component application in high temperature performance. Topics\nincluded are alloying effects on dislocation climb and glide, grain boundary and lattice diffusion, and dynamic\nrecrystallization. The interactions between environment and thermal and mechanical cycling also will be considered.\nDesign tools for prediction and evaluation of component life will be investigated in detail, including an exploration of\ndeformation mechanism maps. Offered in alternate years. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MSE55600",
    "Title": "Fracture Of Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The failure and fracture of materials under applied stress are the focal points of this course, with\nparticular emphasis on the material characteristics that influence fracture. The initial subjects covered in this course\nwill include introductions to linear elastic fracture mechanics (LEFM) and elastic plastic fracture mechanics (EPFM).\nSubsequently, the strength and toughness of metals, ceramics, and polymers will be explored with regard to processing\nproperty relationships and microstructure. Special topics will include fracture mechanism maps, Weibull statistics,\ntoughening mechanisms, and failure analysis. This course is distinct from a course on fracture mechanics in that the\nfundamental materials aspects of fracture are of paramount importance. Offered in alternate years. Typically offered\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MSE55900",
    "Title": "Phase Equilibria In Multicomponent Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A detailed examination of the thermodynamics of phase equilibria in multicomponent systems,\nexperimental methods of determining these equilibria by measurements of thermodynamic activity and graphical\nmethod of representing the equilibria. This is followed by an examination of theoretical models of the behavior of\nsolutions and an examination of the extent to which observed phenomena can be understood and predicted in terms of\nthe models. Offered in alternate years. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MSE56000",
    "Title": "The Production Of Inorganic Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Examination of the production of inorganic materials of engineering importance (metals, ceramics,\nand glasses) from ore concentrates, raw materials, and recycled materials. Individual stages in the extraction, refining,\nand syntheses processes are examined from the viewpoints of thermodynamics and kinetics, and alternative production\nroutes are compared and contrasted. Topics covered include carbothermic and metallothermic reduction of oxide\nconcentrates, smelting and conversion of sulfide mattes, electrolysis and electrowinning from aqueous solutions and\nmolten salts, distillation and vacuum refining, glass-forming, and the synthesis of carbide and nitride ceramics. Offered\nin alternate years. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MSE56200",
    "Title": "Soft Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Soft materials are an important and diverse class of materials that share the common trait of being\neasily deformable by external stresses, electric or magnetic fields or even thermal fluctuations. These materials are the\nfoundation of important technologies that are used in everyday life including ceramic and pharmaceutical processing\n(tablet formation), cosmetics (hand creams), cleaning products, foods (milk, mayonnaise) and bio-technologies (drug\ndelivery). The aim of this class is to gain a fundamental understanding of the physical and chemical underpinnings of\ncommon soft materials systems and how they are used to engineer technologically relevant materials and\nstructures.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Analyze properties of polymers and correlate them to chemical structure. Apply methods and\nmechanisms of polymer chemistry to industrial and laboratory synthesis. Examine the kinetic and design factors that\ncontrol polymer structures. Offered in alternate years. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "MSE58200",
    "Title": "Transmission Electron Microscopy Skills",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Principal components and operation of the transmission electron microscope (TEM). Limits to\nresolution; imaging and diffraction modes; and interpretation of results. Laboratory sessions emphasize the practical\noperation of the instrument and culminate in a test of student skills. This course must be completed before undertaking\nany TEM research in the School of Materials Engineering. Weeks 6 - 10. Permission of instructor required. Typically\noffered Fall Spring.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MSE58300",
    "Title": "Energy-Dispersive X-Ray Microanalysis Skills",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Theory of X-ray generation, components and operation of the energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer\n(EDS); limits to resolution; qualitative, semi-quantitative and fully quantitative analysis; and interpretation of results.\nLaboratory sessions emphasize the practical operation of the instrument and culminate in a test of student skills. Weeks\n11 - 15. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MSE58600",
    "Title": "Experimental Characterization Of Advanced Composite Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The characterization of advanced composite materials is a combined lecture/laboratory course in\nwhich polymeric composite laminates will be fabricated of carbon fiber epoxy and subjected to classical test methods\nappropriate to the determination of the anisotropic, thermoelastic properties. Properties measured will include thermal\nexpansion coefficients, anisotropic elastic constants, biaxial strength properties and interlaminar fracture strengths. The\nautoclave processing of composite laminates will be discussed and the consolidation, degree of cure and glass transition\ntemperature of the polymeric matrix will be modeled. Microscopic analysis of the composite will be carried out to\nobserve microstructure and measure composition fractions. Lectures will precede each experiment. Typically offered\nFall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {

The course will focus on the analysis and interpretation of\narchaeological artifacts and provide opportunities for hands-on learning. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Materials Engineering Fundamentals",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Fundamental relationships between the internal structure, properties and processing in all classes\nof engineering materials. Comprehensive coverage spanning physical, chemical, thermal, mechanical, electrical,\nmagnetic, and optical responses.   {
    "Course": "MSE64000",
    "Title": "Transmission Electron Microscopy And Crystal Imperfections",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Theory and application of TEM to problems in materials science and engineering. Principles of\nelectron diffraction and microscopy are reviewed with the emphasis on the relationship between real and reciprocal\nspace. Diffraction theory of imperfect crystals will be introduced. A primary part of the course will be a discussion of\nimage contrasts in terms of atomistic structures of key crystal imperfections, including dislocations and grain\nboundaries. Experimental applications and image simulations will be included to amplify theoretical concepts. Offered\nin alternate years. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "ME50000",
    "Title": "Advanced Thermodynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The empirical, physical basis of the laws of thermodynamics. Availability/exergy concepts and\napplications. Properties and relations between properties in homogeneous and heterogeneous systems. The criteria of\nequilibrium.   },
  {
    "Course": "ME50100",
    "Title": "Statistical Thermodynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The molecular interpretation of thermodynamic equilibrium. Development of the partition function.\nIntroduction to quantum mechanics and molecular spectroscopy. The Maxwell-Boltzmann formulation of statistical\nmechanics and applications to ideal gases, solids, radiation, and laser diagnostics. The Gibbs formulation of statistical\nmechanics and application to real gases. Kinetic theory and applications to transport properties and chemical kinetics.\nOffered in alternate years. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME50400",
    "Title": "Automotive Control",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Basic engine operation; lambda control, speed control, knock control, fuel injection timing control,\nignition control of SI engines; driveline modeling, automatic transmission control, clutch phasing control; wheel model,\ncomplete vehicle model; observers, friction coefficient estimators, tire contact patch force estimators; anti-lock brake\ncontrol, traction control, yaw stability control; drive-by-wire systems. The distance offering of this course originates\nfrom the IUPUI campus, is offered through streaming video via ProEd, and may be made available at the West\nLafayette campus. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME50500",
    "Title": "Intermediate Heat Transfer",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Heat and mass transfer by diffusion in one-dimensional, two-dimensional, transient, periodic, and\nphase change systems. Convective heat transfer for external and internal flows. Similarity and integral solution\nmethods. Heat, mass, and momentum analogies. Turbulence. Buoyancy-driven flows. Convection with phase change.\nRadiation exchange between surfaces and radiation transfer in absorbing-emitting media. Multimode heat transfer\nproblems.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME50600",
    "Title": "Two-Phase Flow And Heat Transfer",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Basic two-phase flow equations, homogeneous model, drift-flux model, flow regimes, pressure\ndrop in two-phase flow. Nucleation and bubble dynamics, pool boiling, subcooled boiling, forced convection boiling,\ncritical heat flux in pool boiling, critical heat flux in forced convection boiling, minimum heat flux, film boiling, post\ndryout heat transfer. Flow instabilities, choking in two-phase flow, film and dropwise condensation. Applications to\nheat exchangers. Special boiling and two-phase flow problems. Offered in alternate years.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME50700",
    "Title": "Laser Processing",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduces background knowledge in laser science and laser technology and fundamentals\ninvolved in laser processing and manufacturing. The following topics are discussed: laser fundamentals, industrial laser\nsystems and processes, and the laser-induced thermal, thermo-mechanical, and thermo-acoustic effects. The course also\ndiscusses emerging areas of laser applications, such as microscale laser processing, ultrafast laser processing, and the\nrelated energy transport analyses. Laboratory and video demonstration sessions are used to enhance the overall\nunderstanding of the course materials. Offered in alternate years.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME50800",
    "Title": "Heat Trans In Biological Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to applications of heat transfer in living systems to students who have general\ninterests in biomedical engineering. Fundamental concepts of biology and engineering involved in these applications\nare introduced. Regulation of blood flow under external thermal stimuli and its effect on heat transfer are discussed.\nClinical applications of heat transfer, including cancer therapy and gene therapy. Prerequisite: first course in fluid or\naerodynamics. Offered in alternate years. Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {

    "Title": "Gas Dynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,

Multidimensional flows including\ngeneral concepts, small perturbation theory for linearized flows and method of characteristics for nonlinear flows.\nPrerequisite: first course in fluid or aerodynamics.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ME51300",
    "Title": "Engineering Acoustics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The simple oscillator. Lumped acoustical elements. Electro-mechanical-acoustical analogies.\nWave motion in strings and membranes. Introduction to linear acoustics through derivation of the wave equation and\nsimple solutions. Plane and spherical waves. Acoustic intensity. Plane wave transmission through fluid layers and\nsimple barriers. Sound absorption. Modeling of acoustical sources: monopoles, dipoles, quadrupoles. Mechanisms of\nsound generation and directionality. Sound propagation in one-dimensional systems (e.g., ducts and mufflers).\nIntroduction to room acoustics. Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Theory of spray formation and evolution as well as treating a host of spray applications. Topics\ninclude drop size distributions, breakup of liquid sheets and ligaments, drop formation and breakup, drop motion and\nthe interaction between a spray and its surroundings, drop evaporation, nozzle internal fluid mechanics, external spray\ncharacteristics, nozzle performance, and experimental techniques relevant to these subjects. Applications include: (1)\nagricultural sprays, (2) consumer products, (3) gas turbine combustion, (4) heat transfer, (5) internal combustion\nengines, (6) paints and coatings, (7) pharmaceutical and medicinal sprays, and (8) spray drying. Offered in alternate\nyears. Offered in alternate years.Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Dynamics of multi-degrees-of-freedom mechanical systems. Holonomic and nonholonomic\nconstraints. Lagrange's equations of motion. Hamilton's principle for holonomic systems. Stability of linear systems - divergence and flutter. Applications to\ngyroscopes, satellite dynamics, etc. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

  },
  {
    "Course": "ME56400",
    "Title": "Vibrations Of Discretized Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Theory of small oscillations of discrete or discretized systems of high dimensionality. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ME58400",
    "Title": "System Identification",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Theory and application of System Identification methods. Connecting the world of mathematical\nmodels to experimental data - least squares methods and difference equation models. Background in probability and\nanalysis: algebra of random variables, law of large numbers, central limit theorem. The ARMA family of models;\nmapping physics models to generalized ARMAX forms (linear and nonlinear); mapping the parameter estimation\nproblem to the least squares problem (batch and recursive), and numerical solution techniques. Model (in)validation,\noptimal identification criteria, experiment design and data preprocessing considerations. Issues of signal to noise ratio,\npersistency of excitation, sampling frequency, data accuracy and data sizes. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {

    "Description": "A unified and exact mathematical treatment of the mechanics of solids and fluids.   },
  {

    "Title": "Advanced Engineering Acoustics",

    "Description": "An extension of ME 51300. Sound transmission between two media. Acoustic resonators and\napplication to muffler theory. Structural radiation and sound. Acoustical measurements and signal processing: sound\nintensity, surface intensity, coherence and cepstral techniques. Numerical acoustics: finite element analysis, boundary\nintegral equation analysis and statistical energy analysis. Advanced topics. Prerequisite: ME 51300. Typically offered\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME61400",
    "Title": "Computational Fluid Dynamics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Application of finite difference methods, finite element methods, and the method of characteristics\nfor the numerical solution of fluid dynamics problems. Incompressible viscous flows: vorticity transport equation,"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME61500",
    "Title": "Aeroacoustics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(AAE 61500) Quantitative measures of sound (decibel scales, spectra, energetics of acoustic\nmotions, and measurement techniques). The wave theory of sound (basic equations and properties, sound propagation\nin homogeneous and inhomogeneous media, one-, two- and three-dimensional sound fields and distributed sources).\nEffects of source movement. Aerodynamic noise generation - acoustic analogy (Lighthill's equation and Ffowcs\nWilliams-Hawkings equation). Introduction to Computational Aeroacoustics (CAA). Noise from turbulent shear flows\n(jet noise, cavity noise, and noise from flow over objects). Noise from turbomachinery, propellers, and rotors.\nPrerequisite: ME 30900 or ME 51300 or AAE 51100. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME61700",
    "Title": "Applied Thermal Physics And Molecular Spectroscopy",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The fundamentals of statistical mechanics, kinetic theory, and molecular spectroscopy will be\ntaught in order to predict and characterize the behavior of non-equilibrium gases using optical and laser diagnostics.\nThis material will be taught within the context of applications involving combustion, plasmas, propulsion, energetic\nmaterials, shock waves and laser radiation.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME62000",
    "Title": "Combustion Of Energetic Materials",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Students will learn the concepts of how to approach research in the area of Energetic Materials\n(EM) based on an understanding of the fundamental principles. Students will learn how energetic materials are\nfabricated, safety used, as well as understand life cycle issues, homogeneous & heterogenous combustion, and\nadvanced energetic material concepts. Multiphase combustion phenomena will be introduced and emphasized. They\nwill apply these concepts to a literature review and group research project, as well as that includes applying\nthermochemistry and chemical kinetic software. In addition, six hands-on labs are performed. This material will be\ncovered in the context of real-world applications, with an emphasis on energetic materials, combustion, propulsion,\nexplosives, pyrotechnics, and detonation phenomenon. Pre-requisite: ME 52500 or AAE 53900 or consent of\ninstructor.Credits: 3.00"

Offered in alternate years. Prerequisite: ME 51300, ME 56300. Typically\noffered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME66400",
    "Title": "Vibrations Of Continuous Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Theory of small oscillations of continuous systems. Love's equations for thin shells, reduction to\nspecial cases of shallow shells, plates, beams, etc. Initial stresses; influence of shear; thermal excitation. Initial value\nproblems; forced vibrations; structural damping. The dynamic Green's function, impedance concepts; variational\napproaches. Experimental procedures, scaling, composite, and stiffened shells. Prerequisite: knowledge of one degree\nof freedom system vibrations. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

  },
  {
    "Course": "ME67500",
    "Title": "Multivariable Control System Designs",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Fundamentals of the frequency response loop shaping methodology for the analysis and design of\nrobust multivariable control systems will be presented. Emphasis is on suitable extensions of the classical Bode-\nNyquist design techniques to systems with not only uncertain parameters but also multiple inputs and outputs.\nInstrument and environmental signal level constraints on the performance of control systems will be critically\nevaluated. Students are required to develop ability to handle open-ended design issues involving significant\nmultiobjective performance trade-offs. Prerequisite: ME 57500. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME67700",
    "Title": "Nonlinear Feedback Controller Design",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Controller design and analysis of nonlinear feedback systems. Topics include the design of\nlinear/nonlinear feedback controllers. Describing Function (DF) techniques for design, Popov and Generalized Circle\nCriterion for closed loop stability, functional analysis and Volterra series approaches, and introduction to existing\nnonlinear controller design tools. Offered in alternate years. Prerequisite: ME 67500. Typically offered Spring.Credits:\n3.00"
  },

Models governed by difference, ordinary, and\nparticle differential equations. Examples from mechanical, structural, chemical, and electrical systems. Models of\nchaotic behavior. Techniques for prediction of chaos. Routes to chaos. Offered in alternate years. Prerequisite: ME\n58000. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Description": "This course will introduce technology graduate students and senior undergraduates to the basic\nconcepts of optimization methods with particular emphasis on applications in product and process design.\nUnconstrained nonlinear problems will be presented and solved using steepest descent and conjugate directions.\nConstrained problems will be solved using exterior penalty functions.
