  {
    "Course": "MCMP51400",
    "Title": "Biomolecular Interactions: Theory And Practice",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "to 4.00. Theory and applications of biophysical and bioanalytical methods for the identification and\nqualification of biological and pharmaceutical samples. Methods to be discussed include chromatography,\nelectrophoresis, optical spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, electrochemical methods, radiochemical analysis,\nultracentrifugation, calorimetry and surface plasmon resonance. Physical measurements, such as binding equilibrium,\nkinetics and macromolecular structure will be discussed. While fundamentals of each technique will be discussed, a\nmajor focus will be on the application and integration of presented methods for the analysis of biological problems. The\ncourse will be organized into four general topic areas around the theme of medicinal analysis, and variable credit will\nbe available based on a student's interest in the four topic areas (i.e., 1 credit per topic area). Students should register\nfor 1 credit hour, and the variable credit option will be discussed and determined at the first class period. Permission of\ninstructor required. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 1.00 to 4.00"

  {
    "Course": "MCMP61700",
    "Title": "Molecular Targets: Neuro Function And Dysfunction",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The application of basic scientific principles from medicinal chemistry and molecular\npharmacology, and new discoveries in biology, to the development of new drugs to treat psychiatric disorders and\ndiseases of the central nervous system. Important examples of drug targets, and small molecules (either currently\napproved drugs or those under investigation) that target them, are discussed. Classes of drug target examples discussed\ninclude: G protein-coupled receptors, neurotransmitter transporter proteins, and ion channels. Processes of\nneurosecretion and neurodegenerative processes will also be discussed, as well as target validation and examples of the\nuse of genetic models to identify CNS targets. Prerequisites: MCMP 57000. Typically offered Spring. This course is\noffered in the Spring Semester of the even numbered years.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MCMP61800",
    "Title": "Molecular Targets: Cancer",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The application of basic scientific principles from medicinal chemistry and molecular\npharmacology, and new discoveries in biology, to the development of new anti-cancer drugs. Important examples of\ndrug targets and small molecules (either currently approved drugs or those under investigation) that target them, are\ndiscussed. Classes of drug targets discussed include: kinases, small monomeric G proteins, prenyltransferases,\ntranscription factors, nuclear receptors, cell cycle proteins, cytoskeletal proteins, and topoisomerases.   {
    "Course": "NRES12100",
    "Title": "Stepping Stones To Environmental Science",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course trains individuals to stop the release or potential releases of hazardous substances.\nThey have a more aggressive role than first responders at the operations level by approaching the point of the release to\nplug, patch, or otherwise stop it or manage offensive operations. This course satisfies the OSHA standards for\ncompletion of the 40-hour Hazardous Waste Operator/Emergency Response Technician certification, 29CFR1910.120.\nTopics covered include implementing an employer's emergency response plan; classification and identification of\nunknown materials using field survey instruments; functioning within the Incident Command System; specialized\nchemical protective equipment; hazard and risk assessment techniques; advanced product control operations;\ndecontamination procedures; proper termination procedures; and basic chemical and toxicological\nterminology.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "NS21300",
    "Title": "Sea Power And Maritime Affairs",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is a study of the U.S. Navy and sea power's influence on history and the political\nprocess. Students will explore the major events, attitudes, personalities, and circumstances that have imbued the U.S.\nNavy with its proud history and rich tradition. It deals with issues of national imperatives in peacetime, as well as war,\nvarying maritime philosophies that were interpreted into naval strategies/doctrines, budgetary concerns that shaped\nforce realities, and the pursuit of American diplomatic objectives. It concludes with a discussion of the Navy's strategic\nand structural changes at the end of the Cold War and its new focus, mission, and strategy in the post-September 11,\n2001 world.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "NUCL41000",
    "Title": "Introduction To Reactor Theory And Applications",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Intermediate treatment of reactor theory and its relevance to routine design engineering\ncalculations, including introduction to transport theory, criticality evaluation, multi-group theory, isotopic depletion,\nand concludes with short overview of multi-level reactor design calculations, critical experiments, and treatment of\nneutronic uncertainties.\nList of Topics: Derivation of Boltzmann transport equation, and its reduction to steady state and time dependent\ndiffusion equation. Introduction to multi-group theory, and evaluation of group parameters in both wide and narrow\nresonance approximations. Introduction to homogenization theory, and evaluation of lattice parameters. Evaluation of\ncriticality condition for bare and reflected reactor geometries. Development of discretization techniques for the time-\ndependent multi-group diffusion theory equation. Reactor kinetics, reactivity coefficients and reactivity balance\nequation. Flowchart of multi-level reactor design calculations. Introduction to critical experiments and startup reactor\nphysics test. Sources and treatment of uncertainties in reactor calculations. Typically offered Fall. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "NUCL50300",
    "Title": "Radioactive Waste Management",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Will familiarize students with the nature of the risks associated with radioactive waste and the\nhistory, regulations, and worldwide status for the safe storage of various types of radioactive waste.   {
    "Course": "NUCL51000",
    "Title": "Nuclear Reactor Theory I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Methodologies of neutron flux calculations, diffusion and slowing down theory, flux separation,\nmaterial buckling, resonance absorption, Doppler effect, 2-group and multi-group theories, and reactivity balances for\ndesign and operation. Introduction to reactor kinetics, delayed neutrons, point reactor kinetics, transient behavior, load\nchanges, reactivity feedback, and safety implications. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "NUCL51100",
    "Title": "Reactor Theory And Kinetics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Advanced methodologies for neutron flux calculation, nodal methods, introduction to transport\ntheory, transport correction, multigroup theory, and introduction to the generation of group constants. Reactor kinetics,\nperturbation theory, adjoint fluxes, reactivity calculation from perturbation theory, reactivity coefficients due to\nDoppler effect, temperature and density changes, void coefficient, and energy and power coefficients. Microkinetics,\ntheory of reactivity measurements, approximate methods: prompt jump approximation, and prompt kinetics. Transients\nwith feedback, safety implications, and spatial kinetics. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

Typically offered\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "NUCL61000",
    "Title": "Nuclear Reactor Theory II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course covers advanced reactor physics topics including the neutron transport theory, slowing\ndown and resonance escape, and generalized perturbation theory. The neutron transport theory is the fundamental\ntheory describing the neutron flux behaviors in nuclear systems. The slowing down and resonance escape calculations\nare essential for generating the multi-group cross sections required in the whole-core neutron transport calculations.\nThe generalized perturbation theory is a powerful method for determining the changes in response parameters due to\nthe variations in nuclide densities and microscopic cross sections. Prerequisites: NUCL 51000 and advanced\nengineering mathematics covering complex analysis, partial differential equations, and integral equations.. Typically\noffered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Reactor physics analysis of existing reactors and critical experiments through the use of digital\ncomputers and reactor programs. One-, two-, and three-dimensional solutions of the diffusion and transport equations.\nCalculation methods for lifetime effects on excess reactivity, power distribution, breeding ratio, and temperature, void,"
  },

    "Title": "Advanced Topics In Radiation Damage",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,

The\nrelation between these phenomena and the structure and properties of engineering materials is discussed. Coupled\nphenomena are considered in relation to materials modeling codes.   },
  {
    "Course": "NUCL64000",
    "Title": "Fast Reactor Theory",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Course is designed to teach reactor physics specific to fast spectrum reactors and the associated\ncomputational methods. Topics include breeding and actinide burning capabilities, core design implications, and\nreactivity feedback mechanisms. Computational methods will be specific to fast reactor physics analysis and include\nthe fast neutron spectrum calculation, group constant generation and reactivity feedback calculations for Doppler,\nthermal expansions, and sodium void. Prerequisites: NUCL 51100 and advanced engineering mathematics covering\ncomplex analysis, partial differential equations, and integral equations. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits:\n3.00"

  {
    "Course": "NUR50500",
    "Title": "Sociocultural Influences On Health",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "or 3.00. This course examines the influences of cultural and sub-cultural variables on health and\nhealth care delivery. Students analyze and apply appropriate theoretical perspectives and current research to design\nevidence-based strategies that ground clinical decision making in advanced practice nursing. Students use the National\nStandards on Culturally and Linguistically Appropriate Services (CLAS) as the basis for providing culturally\ncompetent care. As students apply principles of culturally competent communication they are encouraged to develop\ninsight and an attitude of resistance to stereotyping. Students gain an understanding of the context of vulnerable and\nmarginalized populations through the analysis of social, cultural, and economic influences that impact health and\nillness. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 2.00 or 3.00"

    "Course": "NUR54400",
    "Title": "Advanced Practice Psychiatric Mental Health Nursing Across The\nLifespan",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Evidence-based treatment methods including principals of psychopharmacology and\npsychotherapeutic modalities across the life span are examined, evaluated and implemented in clinical practice.\nFactors, such as culture, neurobiology, developmental level and gender that impact disease expression, therapeutic\napproaches and treatment response are explored. Mental health assessment including standardized psychiatric\nassessment tools, including Mental Status Exam, Mood Disorder Questionnaire, Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9),\nColumbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS), DSM V and ICD is presented. In addition, developmental and\nfunctional level, and cultural influences are included. Substance use assessment skills and substance use interventions\nwill be examined including how substance use impacts psychiatric symptom expression and response to treatment.\nLegal and ethical implications of care will be discussed.   },
  {
    "Course": "NUR64100",
    "Title": "Principles Of Epidemiology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will provide the student with an introduction to epidemiology - the study of the\ndistribution and determinants of health status. This course focuses on application of epidemiologic descriptive and\nanalytic study as it relates to the distribution and determinants of health status. Topics will include the scope and\nhistory of epidemiology, basic quantitative methods and measures used in the field, and an introduction to the design\nand implementation of epidemiological studies. The course will also include the examination of cases from infectious\ndisease, various forms of applied epidemiology (e.g., clinical and field epidemiology), surveillance/screening tests,\ntypes of epidemiological studies, concepts of disease transmission, and causality. Prerequisites: At least one\nundergraduate or graduate level statistics course. Permission of department required. Typically offered\nSummer.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "NUR64200",
    "Title": "Systems Approaches In Healthcare",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Students are introduced to the fundamentals of systems engineering tools and approaches through\nhands on problem solving exercises. Systems Engineering tools/methods are applied to a clinical problem. Upon\ncompletion of this course, the participants will have had exposure to system engineering tools and approaches such as\nprocess mapping, bottle-neck analysis, queuing, lean engineering, simulation, optimization, dealing with uncertainty,\nwhat-if analysis, quality control and performance monitoring techniques. Typically offered Summer.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "NUR69020",
    "Title": "Leadership Seminar",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "The nurse as leader is deconstructed and reconstructed within the realms of scientific knowledge,\ntheory, education, and healthcare delivery. Nurse leaders as members of collaborative teams and the influence of\nnursing intelligence on research teams are examined. Historical and societal influences affecting nurse leaders are\nexamined, including media portrayals of nursing, transformational leadership, critical theory and feminist theory.\nModels of leadership are explored within the context of scientific work; the student is challenged to evaluate\nthemselves as present and future leaders and members of nursing's academe. Admission to the Nursing PhD program or\ninstructor permission. This is one of the first courses taken by PhD students and may be open to graduate students\noutside the School of Nursing with permission from the instructor.     "Course": "NUR69050",
    "Title": "Implementing Theory In Healthcare Research",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Historical and contemporary social, ethical, educational, scientific, and professional influences on\nthe development of theoretical knowledge in nursing and health research are analyzed. Various methods of theory\ndevelopment are reviewed. Selected biological/physiological, behavioral, and health service theories that form the basis\nof nursing science are critically evaluated. Skills needed for theory analysis and theory development are emphasized.\nThe role of theoretical knowledge to innovation in nursing science and healthcare is presented. Scientific bridges\nbetween theoretical frameworks and research methods are appraised. Selected nursing and healthcare scientists\ncommunicate the theoretical aspects of their programs of research with an emphasis on collaboration between\ndisciplines.     "Course": "NUR69100",
    "Title": "Health Care Research Methods",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course advances knowledge and skill in quantitative research methods for health program\nevaluation, population health, healthcare quality improvement, and other healthcare research applications. Topics\ninclude design of experimental, quasi-experimental, and observational studies; primary data collection through surveys\nand other techniques; use of clinical, administrative, and other secondary data sources; and data analysis strategies\nappropriate to each design and type of data.   {
    "Course": "NUR69200",
    "Title": "Applied Statistics In Healthcare Research",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course advances knowledge and skills in statistical approaches for analyzing complex\nhealthcare data. It focuses on statistical analysis in contexts such as evidence-based practice, quality improvement,\nevaluation, and behavioral and population health. Topics include probability and descriptive statistics, nonparametric\nstatistics, risk and odds ratios, sensitivity and specificity, logistic and multinomial regression, multiple linear\nregression, general linear models, survival and time-to-event analysis, and mixed effect modeling. The course will\nprovide hands-on experience in statistical analysis of healthcare data. Prerequisites: Introductory course in statistics or\nbiostatistics at the advanced undergraduate or graduate level.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "NUTR52900",
    "Title": "Basic Bone Biology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to present the fundamentals of bone biology. The course objectives are\ndesigned to provide learners with a solid framework for understanding mechanisms, diseases, and treatments associated\nwith the musculoskeletal system as they advance in their education and training.\n\u2022 Approximately 45 hours of lecture will help the learner achieve the objectives outlined. Lectures will be\ngiven to present information and tie into information learners have acquired or will acquire in other courses\n(e.g. biomechanics, physiology, molecular biology, etc.) to assist them in combining all of their courses and\nresearch experiences together into one interdisciplinary learning experience.\n\u2022 Directors will attend and supervise the scheduled lecture sessions if they are not providing the lecture\ncontent, and they will be available during these times to answer questions. However, it is expected that\nstudents take additional time outside of scheduled class time to further learning.\n\u2022 Materials for the learners will be posted on the course's website. These materials will include:\n\u2022 Lecture notes and PowerPoints: Each lecturer will post his/her lecture notes and associated PowerPoint slides\nprior to the lecture.\n\u2022 Additional information: As the course progresses, instructors may come across additional information that\nthey may find useful for student learning of the material. These materials will be posted for students to utilize\nas they see fit."

    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The topics in this course provide a firm conceptual foundation for graduate students interested in\nissues related to obesity.     "Course": "NUTR62600",
    "Title": "Advanced Presentation Skills",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course will teach graduate students how to synthesize information from multiple scientific\nstudies and then communicate that information effectively to others in the form of a 40 minute long scientific seminar.\nThe course is designed to provide students with clear guidelines for effective long-form oral communication of\nscientific information and then give students an opportunity to put those guidelines into practice. Prerequisites:\nGraduate standing past the first year. NUTR 69400 or equivalent course (determined by instructor review). For PhD\nstudents; INP Scientific Writing Course NUTR 62700. For MS students; a statement from the research mentor that the\nstudent has a clear thesis topic, that the student has completed the majority of work on the thesis, and that the student\nhas conducted background reading on the thesis topic. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "NUTR62700",
    "Title": "Scientific Writing In Nutrition Science",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "The goal of this course is to develop and practice skills for clear scientific writing. The course is\ndesigned to introduce and practice the building blocks of scientific writing, including word choice, sentence structure\nand paragraph structure.   {
    "Course": "OBHR64700",
    "Title": "Teams, Technology And Human Capital",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Human capital-people and their collective knowledge, skills and abilities-is the lifeblood of\norganizations. Today's managers must be equipped to leverage technology effectively, which requires an understanding\nof how technology alters the social dynamics of work. Drawing on an interdisciplinary, socio-technical framework, this\ncourse develops an understanding of the interplay between information and communication technologies and human\ncapital, and applies this knowledge to timely work topics, including change management, knowledge management,\nvirtual and alternative work structures, ethics and fairness, distance leadership and control, security, privacy, and trust.\nPrerequisite: Master's student standing and Management majors only. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "OBHR65000",
    "Title": "International Human Resource Management",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Explores the international dimensions of human resource management. Focuses on the human\nresource policies and practices that are adhered to in various regions of the world. The process of expatriating and\nrepatriating managers to and from the U.S. is examined. International issues faced by a manager working for a\nmultinational organization in the U.S. are studied. Prerequisite: MGMT 65310 or OBHR 63300. Typically offered Fall\nSpring.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "OBHR65200",
    "Title": "Organizational Development And Consulting",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Organizational development (OD) refers to the application of behavioral sciences knowledge and\ntechniques to improve organizational effectiveness (e.g., productivity, quality, service, employee satisfaction, etc.). The\ncourse will describe techniques for diagnosing organizations and interventions for improving organizations. Specific\ninterventions will be examined in detail including structural interventions (e.g., organizational design, job design),\ninterpersonal process interventions (e.g., process consultation, team building), and human resource interventions (e.g.,\nperformance management, career development). The course will attempt to both build knowledge and provide practice\nin the various techniques. The course will not duplicate material in other current course offerings by this professor, and\nit will not require prior courses in human resources. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 2.00"
  },

    "Course": "OLS45400",

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

    "Course": "PHRM46800",
    "Title": "Clinical Integration And Application",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This is an elective class which gives participants more experience working up patient cases with\nmultiple complications and an opportunity to make recommendations to a team.     "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the basic principles of pathophysiology, pharmacodynamics, toxicology and\nmedicinal chemistry necessary to understand the therapeutic use and adverse actions of drugs.   },
  {
    "Course": "PHRM82800",
    "Title": "Dosage Forms I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The purpose of Dosage Forms I is to provide a foundation in the basic concepts of pharmaceutics\nthat are the foundation of drug delivery. The course begins by presenting the molecular basis for aqueous and lipid\nsolubility of drugs, pharmacokinetic principles that are related to dosage forms, mechanisms by which excipients or\nmanufacturing processes affect bioavailability, and chemical kinetics applied to the shelf-life of dosage forms. The\npharmaceutics principles are then applied to successively more complex liquid dosage forms: solution, emulsion, and\nsuspension. The excipients that are required to prepare the dosage forms: buffers, preservatives, emulsifiers, suspending\nagents, wetting agents, etc. and the method of preparing each dosage form in both a compounding and manufacturing\nsetting are covered. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHRM82900",
    "Title": "Dosage Forms II",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "Education in the use of dosage forms to deliver drugs. Collaboration with peers and other members\nof the health care team regarding the proper use of the various dosage forms so that the desired therapeutic objective is\nachieved. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 2.00"
  },

    "Course": "PHRM83100",
    "Title": "Health Care Systems",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course is envisioned as a primarily didactic course whose main purpose is to provide students\nwith an introduction to the structures and functions of the United States Health Care System.   },
  {
    "Course": "PHRM83200",
    "Title": "Principles Of Diagnosis Labs And Monitoring",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course will serve as an introduction to the role of diagnostics in the clinical continuum of\npatient care. Since most therapeutic decisions are based in part on information obtained through utilization of\ndiagnostic testing, it is important for pharmacists to have an understanding of these tests as the pertain to diagnosis. As\nthey progress in their training, students will be required to evaluate and interpret diagnostic tests to help monitor and\nfine tune drug therapy. This course will provide an introduction to diagnostic testing as a whole, with an introduction to\ndifferential diagnosis and the selection of diagnostic tests. The students will also have the opportunity to learn about\ndifferent types of testing (lab, imaging, etc.) and how to critically judge information provided by various tests. Finally,\nthe students will be introduced to several common laboratory tests that have wide application in the diagnosis and\ntreatment of many different disease states. This course will provide a background introduction to these tests, allowing\nthe students to gain understanding of how the test is performed, how the results are interpreted and how to identify\npotential problems with the laboratory data, allowing a strong foundation as they move into subsequent integrated\npharmacotherapeutic (IP) modules. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHRM83300",
    "Title": "Introduction To Case Studies",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course will focus on medical terminology, discovery of different sections of a patient chart,\nexploration of the components of a SOAP note and other documentation types, orientation to the teaching electronic\nmedical record (tEMR), and reinforcement of the Pharmacists' Patient Care Process (PPCP) with a focus on what is\nunique or different in the care provided by a pharmacist. A primarily online method for content delivery will be\nutilized. Multiple in person case-based sessions will be incorporated throughout the semester. Material covered is\nmeant to supplement and augment that gained in PHRM 82600, PHRM 82500, and the PPL sequence. Typically\noffered Spring.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHRM83400",
    "Title": "Pharmaceutical Calculations",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Mastery of pharmaceutical calculation skills is vital and PHRM 83400 prepares students to apply\ncalculation problem solving skills to clinical practice. PHRM 83400 prepares students to perform pharmaceutical\ncalculations necessary for prescription/drug order preparation, compounding dosage forms, and medication dosage\ncalculations based on patient specific factors. Pharmacists must perform error-free pharmaceutical calculations. Correct\ncalculations contribute as much to pharmaceutical care as the newest methods/guidelines for diagnosis, treatment, and\nprevention. The development of problem solving skills with pharmaceutical calculations is an important component of\nthis course. In addition, practice and repetition of problems is necessary to develop confidence as well as accuracy.\nAppropriate documentation of work/set up and numerical answers (including units) is required. Approaches to\nminimize errors and maximize accuracy with pharmaceutical calculations are emphasized. Typically offered\nFall.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHRM83500",
    "Title": "Principles Of Pharmacokinetics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces the theory and concepts of pharmacokinetics and biopharmaceutics. It\nprovides the student with a foundation for more advanced therapeutic concepts in subsequent courses. The learner will\ndevelop expertise in quantifying drug absorption, distribution and elimination from concentration vs. time data or\nurinary drug excretion vs. time data to estimate primary pharmacokinetic parameters. Use of these parameters is\nrequired to design and modify individual drug-dosing regimens. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "PHRM86700",
    "Title": "Introduction To The Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "The Introduction to Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience (APPE) course was designed to\nprovide students with the tools needed to be successful clerkship students. Students will participate in a variety of\nactivities, including case studies, group work, evaluations and assessment, review of therapeutic topics, and\nstudent/preceptor panel interactions. Activities will be supplemented by didactic lecturing for each topic. The activities\nand lecture topics were selected based on feedback from previous clerkship students, preceptors, and faculty, and are\nintended to de-mystify the clerkship experience. This course prepares students to enter the clerkship year with the\nability to successfully submit required clerkship forms, evaluate preceptors and peers, avoid common clerkship student\nmistakes, document clinical interventions, review medical charts, and prepare for therapeutic and pharmacokinetic\nresponsibilities.   {
    "Course": "PHPR48000",
    "Title": "Self-Care Pharmacy Practice I",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course is specifically designed to provide students with guided experience in the application of\nknowledge acquired during previous professional course work to the solution of simulated problems which occur in\nself-care pharmacy practice. Specifically, the course is designed to introduce students to the appropriate selection and\nuse of nonprescription medications and devices for the treatment of minor health complaints by patients. A principle\ntheme throughout the course is that the solution of all self-care problems (i.e., regardless of the context in which they\noccur) involves the application of the same basic problem solving process. Course activities, readings and homework\nassignments will provide students with illustration of how the problem solving process can be applied to specific self-\ncare situations that arise in practice. Active learning methods will be employed to involve students directly in the actual\napplication of this process to simulated practice problems. Topics: Colds, Coughs, Allergies. Typically offered\nFall.Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "PHIL11005",
    "Title": "I Play, Therefore I Am: Introduction To Philosophy Through Video\nGames\nThis course uses video games to demonstrate many of the fundamental problems of philosophy. To better understand\nthe philosophical problems presented in text, students will watch online walkthroughs and live demonstrations of video\ngames in class. Students will also engage with these problems through active learning by occasionally playing video\ngames.Credits: 3.00\nPHIL 11100 - Introduction To Ethics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A study of the nature of moral value and obligation. Topics such as the following will be\nconsidered: different conceptions of the good life and standards of right conduct; the relation of nonmoral and moral\ngoodness; determinism, free will, and the problem of moral responsibility; the political and social dimensions of ethics;\nthe principles and methods of moral judgment. Readings will be drawn both from contemporary sources and from the\nworks of such philosophers as Plato, Aristotle, Aquinas, Butler, Hume, Kant, and J. S. Mill. Typically offered Summer\nFall Spring.   {
    "Course": "PHIL11500",
    "Title": "Philosophy: What Are You Going To Do With That?",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed for all philosophy majors, but is open to anyone interested in\nminor/majoring in philosophy. The format for this course is based on three components: reading and reflection, along\nwith in-class discussion; in-class guest speakers who will address various topics in philosophy as a field, and/or\nprofessionalization (both within and outside of academia); and short written exercises, often done in class, which are\ndesigned to build up to the final project. Most classes will begin with a guest speaker giving a brief introduction to a\nparticular area or topic within philosophy. Students will have a short reading assigned for each class period that will be\ndiscussed with the instructor following the guest's presentation. The course readings will be, as best as possible, related\nto the area/topic introduced by the guest. Certain classes will be dedicated solely to career/professionalization interests\nand will feature guests with expertise in these areas. The professionalization experts will help students develop their"

    "Description": "The course encourages critical reflection on traditional and contemporary views about God and\nother religious ideas.   {
    "Course": "PHIL20700",
    "Title": "Ethics For Technology, Engineering, And Design",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is designed to increase your understanding of professional and ethical responsibilities in\nnational, international, and cross-cultural environments, helping you to anticipate, understand, and navigate issues that\nwill likely arise in your working life as an engineer or designer. The focus of the course is on developing the ability to\napply a general ethical framework to new and unique situations, including those arising from the global cultural context\nof modern engineering. The course covers how this ethical framework should be constituted, and provides practice in\napplying this a framework to specific, concrete cases. Together, these components work toward your development as a\nbetter engineer and a more responsible global citizen. The readings, case studies, and exercises are geared towards the\ndevelopment of a well-researched original case study that you will present to the class, which is informed by your past\nexperiences and future aspirations related to engineering. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHIL20800",
    "Title": "Ethics Of Data Science",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "As applications of data science permeate more aspects of our lives, new and important ethical\nissues are arising. However, especially because we are entering uncharted territory, reasoning clearly about the ethical\nimplications of data science isn't easy. This course provides students with the tools for doing so, including a conceptual\nframework for ethical reasoning in professional settings, as well as a procedure for case-study analysis that allows\nstudents to practice employing this conceptual framework. Together, these components help prepare students to be\nethical professionals and responsible global citizens.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "PHIL31000",
    "Title": "Classical Chinese Philosophy",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course, we will survey the classic works of classical Chinese philosophy (c. 600-200 BCE).\nWe will focus on seven major philosophers (and their followers): Kongzi (Confucius), Mozi, Mengzi (Mencius),\nZhuangzi, Laozi, Xunzi, and Han Feizi. We will use their work to consider topics such as: the nature and value of\nmorality, the proper role of ritual in human life, whether human nature is good or bad, how one becomes a moral\nperson, the proper role and function of government, and more. In addition to introducing the competing traditions of\nConfucianism, Mohism, Daoism, and Legalism, the course will help students to develop basic philosophical skills as\nthey develop and defend their own views on these topics. No knowledge of Chinese is expected. Typically offered Fall\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Moral Psychology And Climate Change",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course investigates the ethical challenges posed by climate change in conjunction with the\ndeep cognitive and motivational factors that shape our individual and collective responses to it. Current research on\nhuman moral psychology is examined, drawing on work from a range of disciplines. Ethical theories concerning the\nunique moral challenges posed by a threat that spans national borders and human generations are considered. Strategies\nfor addressing climate change that try to avoid our common cognitive foibles, and to leverage what we know about\nhuman moral capacities for collective action, are examined.   {
    "Course": "PHIL56100",
    "Title": "Reading Philosophy: Skills And Strategies",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Repeatable twice for a maximum of 9 credits.\nAcademic philosophy demands both the ability to read large amounts of texts fluently, carefully, and closely.\nFurthermore, the abstract nature of philosophical discourse places a large cognitive demand upon readers. This course\nprepares non-native English speakers philosophy students for these intensive reading demands. The course has three\nmajor learning areas: the language skills that students need to read fluently (i.e., the efficient processing of language for\ngeneral comprehension of meaning); reading strategies that students can use to improve comprehension and learning;\nand communication about readings, as the close reading of texts is essential to communicating one's ideas both orally\nand in writing.\nStudents are also supported in their regular philosophy courses. This course is linked to one or more 500+ level\nphilosophy seminars that students in this course are enrolled in. Reading materials, writing activities, and projects for\nthe course are designed to complement tasks and projects required in the linked philosophy seminar.\nPermission of department required. Typically offered Fall and Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHIL56200",
    "Title": "Reading To Argue",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Repeatable twice for a maximum of 9 credits.\nClosely and critically reading philosophical arguments is the first step to composing your own arguments in\nphilosophy. In addition, developing these skills will help you to orally discuss philosophical ideas, both in classroom\ndiscussions as well as when giving presentations. This class aims to prepare students for these tasks by developing the\nskills of close and critical reading in philosophical discourse. All the while, students will continue improving their\nreading, writing, and speaking skills in the English language through specifically designed language learning\ncomponents for non-native English speakers.\nStudents are also supported in their regular philosophy courses. This course is linked to one or more 500+ level\nphilosophy seminars that students in this course are enrolled in. Reading materials, writing activities, and projects for\nthe course are designed to complement tasks and projects required in the linked philosophy seminar.\nPermission of department required. Typically offered Fall and Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Description": "This course is a co-requisite, language-focused class linked to a philosophy seminar. Walk-along\ncourses provide opportunities to shift focus from content to language form and use. Activities and projects for the"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHIL57100",
    "Title": "Writing To Learn",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Repeatable twice for a maximum of 9 credits.\nWriting on a higher academic level can be especially challenging for non-native English-writers. Thus, this course aims\nto develop students' graduate-level skillsets in philosophical practices in an English language environment to help them\ngain confidence and become productive members of the philosophical community. Students will learn writing\nprocesses that will aid their ability to effectively compose in English, including developing a thesis statement,\noutlining, drafting, formatting, and editing. As all four chief skillsets in second-language proficiency development work\nin tandem and enhance each other, the course will rely on writing, reading, speaking, listening, and presenting work for\nlearning and further developing these advanced language skills.\nStudents are also supported in their regular philosophy courses. This course is linked to one or more 500+ level\nphilosophy seminars that students in this course are enrolled in. Reading materials, writing activities, and projects for\nthe course are designed to complement tasks and projects required in the linked philosophy seminar.\nPermission of department required. Typically offered Fall and Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHIL57200",
    "Title": "Writing To Argue",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Repeatable twice for a maximum of 9 credits.\nWriting is a primary mode of communication in philosophy. This course aims to prepare students for the writing\ndemands of philosophy by having students develop their ability to analyze, interpret, and critique philosophical\narguments through written works and, in the process, construct their own philosophical arguments. Students will also\nlearn writing processes that will aid their ability to effectively and clearly compose philosophical arguments, including\noutlining, drafting, and editing. Finally, the class will also pay attention to genre and rhetorical features of\nphilosophical discourse, such as how philosophers enact criticism and write introductions to research papers. All the\nwhile, students will continue improving their writing and speaking skills in the English language through specifically\ndesigned language learning components for non-native English speakers. Students can use their course paper as a draft\nof a writing sample for PhD programs.\nStudents are also supported in their regular philosophy courses. This course is linked to one or more 500+ level\nphilosophy seminars that students in this course are enrolled in. Reading materials, writing activities, and projects for\nthe course are designed to complement tasks and projects required in the linked philosophy seminar.\nTypically offered Fall and Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Modern Mechanics",
    "CreditHours": 4.0,

    "Course": "PHYS21500",
    "Title": "Physics For Elementary Education",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The curriculum draws heavily on Project 2061 Benchmarks and NRC Science Education Standards\nfor content and nature of science materials and focuses on middle school learning goals (especially those with strands at\nelementary level). Each learning goal was expanded to finer-grained target ideas creating more steps to make concepts\nmore understandable and explicit. Activities were designed to enable students to develop deep conceptual\nunderstanding of each target area and the structure and sequence were guided by research on student learning. In this\nclass social interactions are used to clarify ideas and to encourage peer teaching. The students' understandings are based\non prior knowledge. The class is based on a constructivist framework where new understandings are scaffolded from\npartial to incomplete understandings, and those are refined over time. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "PHYS23000",
    "Title": "Physical Science For Elementary Education",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The course is aimed at facilitating future elementary teachers to learn physical science that will\nprepare them to teach these concepts to future elementary students grades K-6. The course will be focused on learning\nphysical science by doing science i.e. developing understanding by collaborative activities and discussion in the\nlaboratory and lecture and communicating your ideas to others. The course will have one 50-minute lecture and two\n110-minute laboratory meetings each week.\nThe course content is consistent with the CAEP (Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation) K-6\nElementary Teacher Preparation Standards (Standard 2: Understanding and Applying Content and Curricular\nKnowledge for Teaching in Physical Science and Engineering Design) and the NGSS (Next Generation Science\nStandards) Disciplinary Core Ideas (DCIs) for the Physical Sciences (Physical Sciences PS1, PS2, PS3, and PS4) as\nwell as many of the Science and Engineering Practices (SEPs).\nThe course will be divided into four units: 1) Matter and Interactions, 2) Motion and Stability, 3) Energy, and 4) Waves\nand their applications. All of these units will be delivered through the paradigm of solving engineering design\nproblems. Engineering design involves many different practices: problem definition, model development and use,\ninvestigation, analysis and interpretation of data, application of mathematics and computational thinking, and\ndetermination of solutions. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHYS23300",
    "Title": "Physics For Life Sciences I",
    "CreditHours": 4.0,
    "Description": "Physics For Life Sciences I builds upon prerequisite knowledge in college level biology, chemistry,\nand mathematics to present introductory physics that will be useful for applying physical principles, insights, and\nproblem solving approaches for students with life science majors. Content will feature the Newtonian framework with\nemphasis on friction, drag and viscosity, random motion and diffusion, fluid flow, the Coulomb force, molecular forces\nand bonding, momentum, conservation of energy, entropy, and the first and second laws of thermodynamics.     "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is intended for first-year graduate students in the Department of Physics. It provides an\nintensive problem solving environment encompassing a broad survey of major topics in classical mechanics,\nelectromagnetism, and thermal physics.   },
  {
    "Course": "PHYS52600",
    "Title": "Physics Of Quantum Computing And Quantum Information",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An introduction to the physics of quantum information science. Starting with the concepts of\nquantum superposition, it defines and describes qubits (quantum bits) and their manipulation by quantum logic gates.\nThe topics of quantum entanglement and the EPR paradox are introduced, and their importance for quantum\nteleportation, communication, and quantum cryptography are covered. Quantum computing is described in terms of\nquantum circuits of logic gates, and also in terms of quantum algorithms, such as Deutche's algorithm, the quantum\nFourier transform, Shor's prime factoring algorithm, and Grover's search algorithm. The final topic is quantum\ndecoherence and the limits it places on practical implementations of quantum computing. Typically offered Fall\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course brings students up to the current status of research in elementary particle physics. The\nfocus of the course is the construction of the Standard Model with emphasis on the electroweak theory. The seminal\nexperiments that confirmed the predictions of the Standard Model is presented. The solar neutrino problem, the search\nfor nonzero neutrino masses, and the efforts to construct a theory which unifies all interactions, including gravity, is\ndiscussed.     "Title": "Pedagogical Methods For Physics Graduate Students",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course prepares physics graduate students for classroom and laboratory teaching assignments.\nThrough 100 minutes per week of lectures and hands-on recitations, it provides an intensive survey of basic\npedagogical methods, both theoretically and in practice. Students will learn and practice teaching techniques via\nvarious forms and microteaching, reading, and class discussion. A broad range of results from physics education\nresearch will be studied in detail.   {
    "Course": "PHYS65800",
    "Title": "Theoretical Techniques Of Elementary Particle Physics I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Theory and phenomenology of the standard model of elementary particle interactions. Electro-\nweak model of Glashow, Salam, and Weinberg: spontaneous symmetry breaking, mass generation, Cabibbo-\nKobayashi-Maskawa mixing in charged weak current, path integral quantization, R3 gauge Feynman fules,\nrenormalization. Parton model. Neutral current phenomenology. Comparison to high energy high precision electron-\npositron annihilation and deep inelastic scattering experiments: weak mixing angle, heavy top quark constraints.\nPrerequisite: PHYS 66200, PHYS 66300. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits:\n3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHYS65900",
    "Title": "Theoretical Techniques Of Elementary Particle Physics II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Theory and phenomenology of the standard model of elementary particle interactions. Quantum\nChromodynamics (QCD) theory of strong interactions: asymptotic freedom, perturbative QCD applied to high energy\nelectron-positron annihilation and deep inelastic phenomena using operator product expansion, renormalization group,\nextended parton model, and Altarelli-Parisi equation. SU(3)xSU(3) current algebra and effective Lagrangians, chiral\nperturbation theory and chiral anomalies. Weak decay of heavy quarks: Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa mixing matrix,\nCP violation. Neutrino physics. Electroweak symmetry breaking and Higgs physics. Other topics of current research\ninterests in and beyond the standard model. Prerequisite: PHYS 65800. Permission of instructor required. Typically\noffered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHYS66000",
    "Title": "Quantum Mechanics I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Origins of the quantum theory, the uncertainty and complementarity principles. The Schrodinger\nequation and its solutions for simple physical systems. Mathematical formulation of the quantum theory. Applications:\nsimple harmonic oscillator, theory of angular momentum, the hydrogen atom. Time-independent and time-dependent\nperturbation theory. The Pauli exclusion principle. Spin of the electron. Elementary theory of scattering. Prerequisite:\nPHYS 53000, PHYS 55000, PHYS 60000, PHYS 61000, Corequisite: PHYS 60100. Typically offered Fall\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHYS66100",
    "Title": "Quantum Mechanics II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Symmetry and conservation laws. The Klein-Gordon and Dirac equations. Interaction of radiation\nwith matter. Applications of quantum mechanics to atomic structure. Scattering theory. Prerequisite: PHYS 60100,\nPHYS 63000, PHYS 66000. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHYS66200",
    "Title": "Quantum Field Theory I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduction to relativistic quantum field theory. Representations of the Lorentz and Poincare\ngroups. Noether's theorem: symmetries and conservation laws. Canonical quantization of free Klein-Gordon, Dirac,\nMaxwell fields. Interacting field theory: Lehmann-Kallen representations. LSZ reduction formula. Schwinger action\nprinciple. Quantum Electrodynamics (QED): Gell-Mann Low expansion, Wick's theorem, Feynman rules for Green\nfunctions and S-matrix elements. Scattering processes in QED: cross sections in low orders of perturbation theory.\nPrerequisite: PHYS 66100. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PHYS66300",
    "Title": "Quantum Field Theory II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Concepts and techniques of relativistic quantum field theory. Quantum Electrodynamics: radiative\ncorrections, renormalization program, infrared divergences, external field problem. Feynman path integral quantization.\nGlobal symmetries and Ward identities. Quantum effective action: effective potential, loop expansion. Non-Abelian\ngauge theories: quantization via Faddeev-Popov prescription, Feynman rules, BRS invariance. Quantum\nChromodynamics. Callen-Symanzik equation and renormalization group. Prerequisite: PHYS 66200. Permission of\ninstructor required. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Title": "Spies And Lies: Studies In Intelligence And National Security",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course examines the role that the collection, analysis, and dissemination of intelligence plays\nin US foreign policy and national security. We will unpack the missions and methods of the US Intelligence\nCommunity. Who does what? What are the different challenges for those engaged in the different aspects of\nintelligence? Why is the intelligence community configured like it is? We will also spend time with more contemporary\ntopics in intelligence. What role does intelligence play meeting future national security and foreign policy challenges?\nWhat is the role of intelligence in modern warfare, including cyber-warfare? What role does intelligence play in a\nliberal democracy? What should intelligence oversight look like? Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "POL32600",
    "Title": "Black Political Participation In America",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "An examination of African American political participation in the United States. Analyzes political\nculture and socialization, with a focus on the interaction between African Americans and actors, institutions, processes,\nand policies of the American system of politics and governance. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "POL33500",
    "Title": "China And The Challenges Of Globalization",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Globalization is a very popular topic, resulting in a lot of loose and poorly thought-through talk and\nwriting around the subject. The view taken in this course is that to understand current processes of globalization we\nneed to examine it in less broad and amorphous ways by focusing on its specific manifestations. Thus, this course\nfocuses on how China has managed the challenges of globalization. China is a particularly useful case study because it\nfailed the challenges of globalization in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. For an ancient civilization such as China,\nthis failure had tremendous impact on its national pride. The Chinese refer to this historical juncture as the \"century of\nshame.\" Towards the end of the 20th century and the onset of the 21st, China faced again the challenges of\nglobalization and has arisen to the tasks in a spectacular fashion, transforming a largely rural and agriculture economy\ninto the world's second largest economic power. This amazing transformation is leading some to proclaim that the 21st\ncentury will belong to China! Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {

    "Description": "This course exposes students to the politics of international human rights through reading, lectures,\nfilm, discussion, and student research.   {
    "Course": "POL45000",
    "Title": "Game Theory And Strategy In International Relations",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course introduces students to the basics of game theory and its applications in international\nrelations. The course will cover foundational concepts in game theory, including strategic rationality, best responses,\nnormal and strategic form games, backward induction, and games of incomplete information. Students will complete\nproblem sets to demonstrate mastery of these subjects. We will also apply these basic game theoretic tools to important\nproblems in international relations to better understand the dynamics of bargaining, coercion, reassurance, cooperation,\nand other key concepts.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Title": "Nuclear Strategy And Proliferation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "\"Nuclear Strategy and Proliferation\" is designed to teach students about 1) the conceptual elements\nand operational requirements of nuclear deterrence and 2) the historical dynamics of nuclear proliferation and\nnonproliferation.     "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Extends the work of POL 51600 (Group Politics) to the empirical study of primary groups, cliques,\nsocial groups, voluntary associations, experimental and occupational groups (insofar as they have political impacts) and\nof political clubs and associations, paraparties, and inchoate political movements and parties.   {
    "Course": "PSY37600",
    "Title": "Attention And Cognitive Control",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This upper-level undergraduate course provides an overview of research and theory related to\nattention and cognitive control. The first half of the course focuses on selective attention to locations, objects, and\nfeatures, as well as the role of attention in memory and skilled performance. The second half focuses on divided\nattention and cognitive control in multitasking situations, as well as aspects of adaptive, hierarchical, and inhibitory\ncontrol. The goal of the course is to provide you with an understanding of major theoretical views, key experimental\nfindings, and common research procedures related to attention and cognitive control. Typically offered Spring.Credits:\n3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PSY38000",
    "Title": "Behavior Change Methods",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Application of behavioral learning principles to problems in living. Self-paced learning format\ncovers design and evaluation of behavior modification programs, with practical and ethical issues.     "Course": "PSY40100",
    "Title": "Language And The Brain",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(SLHS 40100) This course is an overview of the neutral systems that underlie the core components\nof language, including speech perception and production, reading and writing, morphology, syntax, semantics, and\ndiscourse. During the past few decades, there has been an unprecedented increase in studies on these topics, due in\nlarge part to the widespread use of highly sensitive brain mapping techniques that enable researchers to identify\nrelationships between particular brain areas and particular language functions. The findings that have been emerged\nfrom this recent explosion of research are exciting and important for several reasons. They provide fresh insights into\nthe nature of the uniquely human capacity for language, and they have significant implications for understanding and\ntreating language disorders that result from brain injury.   {
    "Course": "PSY51500",
    "Title": "Neuroscience Of Consciousness",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "How does your brain generate your uniquely subjective experience of the world? Is it possible to\nidentify distinct neurophysiological markers of your awareness of a particular sight, sound, taste, or touch? What is the\ncortical basis of your sense of being a self with a first-person point of view that is spatiotemporally grounded in a\nbody? How does consciousness relate to attention and working memory? Does consciousness have an adaptive\nfunction? Might a person in a coma or a vegetative state still have some form of awareness? Could a computer or a\nrobot ever have what we would consider to be genuine experiences? During the past few decades, these and other\nquestions about the nature of consciousness have been the focus of increasing empirical and theoretical research in\nneuroscience and other disciplines. The main purpose of the course is to introduce students to this exciting field of\ninquiry by exposing them to a variety of representative books and articles in the literature. The \"backbone\" of the\ncourse will be Stanislas Dehaene's Consciousness and the brain: Deciphering how the brain codes our thoughts (2014).\nAs we go through the course, we will use each successive chapter in this book as the starting point for a deeper and\nwider exploration of the given topic(s), bringing into our discussion relevant experimental findings and philosophical\nperspectives from other investigators. Requirements: Students will take turns guiding discussions and will also write 1-\n2 page \"response papers\" to the weekly readings. Permission of department required. Typically offered Fall\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"

  },
  {
    "Course": "PSY62101",
    "Title": "Genes, Brain And Behavior",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course examines how genes regulate development and function of the brain to ultimately\ninfluence behavior. Genetics has come to be an important aspect of research in almost every field of Neuroscience and\nPsychology ranging from neural development to cognitive function and dysfunction. However, many students have not\nhad the opportunity to explore this in their studies to date. Therefore, the goal of this course is to provide students with\nthe background needed to understand and think critically about the genetic components of Neuroscience and behavioral\nresearch. Numerous questions will be explored mainly through discussion of research papers. Lectures by the professor\nwill fill in background knowledge needed to understand the readings. The questions explored will include: What are\nchromosomes and genes? What do they do? How do they do it? How do genes control development of the brain? How\nare single genes manipulated in animals to study their effects on behavior? How can genes associated with normal or\nabnormal behavior be identified? What has been learned from gene-behavior studies in animals? in humans? What do\nthese studies tell us about the nature-nurture controversy? In addition to exploring these more traditional aspects of\nbehavioral genetics we will address the 3 most exciting recent developments. These include the use of transgenic\nprimate models, selective remote control of specific neural circuits using optogenetics and chemogenetics, and\nepigenetics, which helps explain how environmental factors and behavior itself can change gene activity and how these\nchanges may be transmitted from one generation to the next. Many behaviors could be used to explore the principles\nthese questions address. The readings will be selected from papers that focus on learning & memory and mental illness.\nHowever, if students are interested in other behaviors, papers that involve those behaviors and serve our purposes can"
  },
  {
    "Course": "PSY62400",
    "Title": "Human Learning And Memory",

    "Description": "All important aspects of visual perception are covered: neurophysiology and neuroanatomy,\npsychophysics, color, perceptual organization, size, shape, depth, motion, and binocular disparity.     "Course": "PSY62901",
    "Title": "fMRI Design And Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Introduces students to the design of fMRI experiments and fMRI data analysis. Covered topics\ninclude an introduction to MR physics, block designs, rapid-event related designs, data preprocessing, and standard\nanalyses using the general linear model. Advanced analysis techniques such as functional connectivity and multivariate\npattern analysis and common pitfalls in design and analysis will also be covered. Prerequisites: Required: Basic\nknowledge of inferential statistics. Recommended: Familiarity with the general linear mode (GLM) and signal\nprocessing. Permission of department required. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

  {
    "Course": "PUBH51100",
    "Title": "Foundations Of Global Health",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Global disparities in the health and well-being of diverse populations, across and within borders,\nhas never been greater. Profound and rapid changes in demographics, from population growth to urbanization, along\nwith unprecedented shifts in patterns of disease and risks, are coupled with game-changing advances in knowledge,\ntechnology, and innovation. This course will introduce students to current challenges and efforts at solutions in global\nhealth, with a focus on low- and middle-income countries. It will provide an interdisciplinary overview of topics that\ninclude measures of health and disease, communicable diseases such as HIV/AIDS and malaria, non-communicable\ndiseases such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease, women's health, maternal and child health, food systems and\nnutrition, health systems, and health care delivery. In addition to lectures, the course will include interactive discussions\nof case studies and specific country examples, aimed at immersing students in the debates and challenges facing global\nhealth leaders and decision makers.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Statistical Methods For Public Health Evaluation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an overview of the statistical methods required to evaluate the effectiveness\nof public health intervention or prevention programs and policies. You will collaborate with those students to conduct an evaluation, develop a report with your findings, and\npresent your findings.\nThe course is intended for graduate students in public health; however, it may be of interest to students in social work,\nnursing, education, criminal justice, psychology, and other related fields.   {
    "Course": "PUBH69900",
    "Title": "Research PHD Thesis\nResearch PHD Thesis\nPurdue Systems Collaboratory\nSYS 30000 - It's A Complex World - Addressing Global Challenges",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The main goal of this course is to address grand challenges that are of global concern - such as\nenvironmental sustainability and energy use, natural and human disasters, and political and economic development -\nusing the ideas and tools of complex adaptive systems. The course exploits the broad expertise of the four faculty\nmembers by treating these challenges from diverse disciplinary perspectives, from the biological and physical sciences,\nto the social sciences, to engineering. By way of a set of case studies, students will analyze the features of these\nchallenges which make them complex, and seek to explain and find solutions to the problems that arise in each case.\nTheir treatment of the cases will be informed by published research and computer simulation. Students will actively\nparticipate in discussions regarding these global challenges, and contribute to the progress of the class using oral and\nwritten presentations. The course will culminate with a final project completed by teams composed of students from\ndifferent disciplines. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "SYS35000",
    "Title": "Systems Methods",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Engineers, social scientists, and managers frequently bring people and technology together to\naddress complex problematic situations in an equitable way that benefits people and the environment. Multiple systems\ntheories and methods have been developed to address these situations, and typical courses in systems focus on a\nrelatively small portion of the rich assortment of available approaches to addressing systems problems. This course\nintroduces students to multiple systems theories and methods via readings, class discussion, reflective writing\nassignments, and selected case studies. The course will emphasize critical thinking about how the theories and methods\nrelate to each other and how they might be applied individually and in combination to address complex problematic\nsituations.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "SOC31000",
    "Title": "Race And Ethnicity",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is a sociological examination and analysis of the presence and significance of race and\nethnicity in our society. The purpose of this course is to provide a foundation and critical framework for assessing the\norigins and manifestations of race and ethnicity. Race and ethnicity have historically been one basis for differentiation\nand stratification in the United States and other societies, and this persists today. In this course, we will examine the\nemergence of race and ethnicity as concepts, and how they shape our everyday lives. We will be guided by the\nfollowing questions: Why do we study race and ethnicity? How and why are they relevant in our society? How do we\nexperience race and ethnicity, and how has this changed over time? Topics include multiculturalism and diversity;\nmedia representations; racism and discrimination; colorism; racial hierarchies; immigration; and different domains of\nracial inequality.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "SOC33900",
    "Title": "Sociology Of Global Development\nAnalysis of the causes and consequences of global development. Topics include: globalization; colonialism and\ndecolonization; food insecurity and dependency; industrialization; poverty and inequality; migration; debt and trade;\nwomen's empowerment; environmentalism; global health; rights and social change; and sustainable development.\nThis course will introduce you to the study of global development and globalization. The primary questions we will\naddress are: What is development? What is globalization and what is its relationship with development? How have the\nprocesses of global development produced inequalities among nations, regions, races, genders, and classes? Is there a\n\"developing\" world and a \"developed\" world? If so, what are their differences and how do they relate with each other?\nHow have some developing countries become more developed than others? What roles do corporations, the state, and\ncivil society organizations play in the processes of global development? How is global development interrelated with\nthe physical environment, inequalities of consumption, and the environmental crisis? How do people resist the\ninequalities and perceived injustices of global development through global social movements? How are we\ninterconnected economically, politically, culturally, socially, and ecologically with people all over the world? What are\nthe possible futures of development? To address these issues, our focus will be on the developing world, our scope will\nbe global and long-term, our methodology will be historical-comparative, and our perspective will be social-scientific\nand critical.Credits: 3.00\nSOC 34000 - General Social Psychology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Social influences on the individual and processes of social interaction. Individual attitudes and\nbehavior as related to socialization, social norms, social roles, communication and propaganda, and other social\ninfluences. Among the interaction processes considered are interpersonal attraction, influence, leadership, cooperation,\nand conflict. Not open to students with credit in PSY 24000. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "SPAN32300",
    "Title": "Humanities-Informed Engineering Projects",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "to 3.00. The main goal of this course is to encourage students to think like global engineers by\nfocusing curricular activities on engineering case studies from a humanistic-engineering perspective. The case studies\nexamined in the course may include past, present, and hypothetical engineering successes and failures; analyses will\nrequire engineering skills combined with understanding of cultural perspectives of local communities and cultural\ncontext (i.e., sociological, anthropological, and historical information and analyses that contribute to cultural\nunderstanding). This humanities-infused approach will encourage students to develop a new mindset-a way of seeing\ncurrent and hypothetical engineering plans, projects, and impacts through local communities' pasts and presents, unique\nvalues, perspectives, and daily ways of life. Taught in Spanish."
  },

    "Description": "to 3.00. The local context of the students in this class (i.e., internship abroad) allows students to gain knowledge and\npractice with a humanistic-engineering framework situated in a particular community and professional setting. There\nare two, multistep main projects in this course: 1) Case study project and 2) Spanish language use and development\nproject.   {
    "Course": "SLHS40100",
    "Title": "Language And The Brain",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(PSY 40100) This course is an overview of the neutral systems that underlie the core components\nof language, including speech perception and production, reading and writing, morphology, syntax, semantics, and\ndiscourse. During the past few decades, there has been an unprecedented increase in studies on these topics, due in\nlarge part to the widespread use of highly sensitive brain mapping techniques that enable researchers to identify\nrelationships between particular brain areas and particular language functions. The findings that have been emerged\nfrom this recent explosion of research are exciting and important for several reasons. They provide fresh insights into\nthe nature of the uniquely human capacity for language, and they have significant implications for understanding and\ntreating language disorders that result from brain injury. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(SLHS 40300) This course aims to introduce students to the current, research-based understanding\nof how different aspects of language (such as word perception, language acquisition, or speech production) are\nrepresented in the mind.   {
    "Course": "SLHS56501",
    "Title": "Vestibular Assessment And Rehabilitation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will review anatomy and physiology of the vestibular system. Diagnostic assessment,\ninterpretation and proper recommendation techniques will be discussed. Current research addressing dizziness and\nbalance issues will be reviewed as well as case history discussions to help prepare students to see these patients in a\nclinic setting. The clinical practice of audiology encompasses the assessment and habilitation/rehabilitation vestibular\nand balance disorders arising from a wide variety of medical and environmental etiologies. It is essential that\naudiologists have a firm understanding of the most common causes and medical treatments of vestibular disorders for\nall age groups. Additionally, vestibular assessment and treatment options are expanding rapidly in the past 5-10 years.\nStudent clinicians need exposure to this area of care so that they may grow as research and technology change.\nAudiologists practice in a medical setting and thus must be comfortable with the medical approaches and terminology\nused by otolaryngologists, otologists, neuro-otologists, pediatricians, physical therapists and other allied health\nprofessions.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "SLHS57401",
    "Title": "Hearing Aids II",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "The focus of this course is on the evolving technology in hearing aids with an emphasis on the\ninformation students will need to make efficacious clinical decisions not only for the hearing aids of today but also for\nthe hearing aids of tomorrow. For each of the hearing aid features that are discussed, we review (1) the need or\npotential benefit to the patient, (2) the engineering behind the feature, (3) research supporting its efficacy and\neffectiveness, (4) its limitations, and (5) how to conduct routine clinical measurements to document its functioning.\nTypically offered Fall.\nCredits: 2.00"

    "Course": "SFS31100",
    "Title": "Aquaponics",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "There has been significant renewed interest in the investigation of integrated fish-food plant\nsystems. Such systems have a long and rich history, particularly in Asia, and our impending food crisis has kindled an\ninterest in developing aquaponic systems in western countries. Many growers are turning to controlled environment and\nhydroponic production methods to produce high-value crops in tight quarters. High input costs can, however, be a\nlimitation. High value food plants and fish can be a natural marriage. The waste disposal problem of the fish can\nbecome the nutrient supply to the plants. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "SFS31200",
    "Title": "Urban Agriculture",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Urban agriculture has the potential to address a range of social, economic and environmental issues\nincluding food insecurity, energy conservation, and human health and well-being. During this 5-week course, students\nwill learn about the forces driving urban agriculture as well as the political and biophysical factors constraining it by\nreading articles, reviewing case studies, and visiting urban farms, vertical farm factories, food pantries, and local food\nadvocacy groups.   {
    "Course": "STAT47301",
    "Title": "Introduction To Arbitrage-Free Pricing Of Financial Derivatives",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course exposes students to a number of financial economics concepts related to arbitrage-free\noption pricing in the binomial market model and the Black-Scholes model. Specific models include: (1) Options and\nparity relationship between options (2) Option Pricing under the Binomial model (3) Option Pricing under the Black-\nScholes model (4) Option hedging and the market maker 's overnight profit (5) Black Scholes theory with Brownian\nmotion and Ito calculus (6) Risk-neutral option pricing and Monte Carlo valuation (7) Stochastic interest rates and\nStochastic Volatility. This course provides the background for Couse MFE of the Society of Actuaries and Course 3F\nof the Casualty Actuarial Society. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
