  {
    "Course": "STAT52600",
    "Title": "Advanced Statistical Methodology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "As a sequel to STAT 52500 , this course introduces some statistical modeling tools that are\ndeveloped for situations where least squares regression and standard ANOVA techniques may not naturally apply. One\ncoverage centers around two lines of models that are closely related, the generalized linear models (GLM) for\nregression (and ANOVA) with non Gaussian responses, and survival models for the analysis of lifetime data. Among\nissues to be discussed are the estimation of the models, the testing of hypotheses, and the checking of model adequacy.\nData examples will be used throughout the course to illustrate the methodologies and the related software tools in R.\nTypically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "STAT52700",
    "Title": "Introduction To Computing For Statistics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides a thorough introduction to the R programming language, and its use for\nstatistical computing and data science. The course will first look at the fundamentals of R, including different data-\nstructures, control-flow, and the basic vocabulary. An emphasis will be placed on learning idiomatic and efficient R,\ncovering ideas such as recycling, vectorization and functional programming. The course will then look at principles and\ntools for tasks like organizing data ('tidy data'), manipulating data ('data carpentry'), querying data (through topics like\nregular expressions) as well as visualizing data (including interactive visualizations). The material and the homework\nwill encourage development of modular reusable code and reproducible research through ideas such as object-oriented\nprogramming and dynamic documents in R Markdown. The last part of the course will study statistical procedures such\nas least-squares regression, LASSO, Monte Carlo sampling and Markov chain Monte Carlo. Besides exams and\nhomeworks, the course will involve a final project that students can collaborate together on.\nCredits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "STAT65600",
    "Title": "Bayesian Data Analysis",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Bayesian data analysis refers to practical inferential methods that use probability models for both\nobservable and unobservable quantities. The flexibility and generality of these methods allow them to address complex\nreal-life problems that are not amenable to other techniques. This course will provide a pragmatic introduction to\nBayesian data analysis and its powerful applications. Topics include: the fundamentals of Bayesian inference for single\nand multiparameter models, regression, hierarchical models, model checking, approximation of a posterior distribution\nby iterative and non-iterative sampling methods, and Bayesian nonparametrics. Specific topics and the course outline\nare subject to change as the semester progresses. All topics will be motivated by problems from the physical, life,\nsocial, and management sciences. Conceptual understanding and inference via computer simulation will be emphasized\nthroughout the course. Permission of department required.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "STAT66700",
    "Title": "Measure-Theoretic Statistics: Decision Theoretic And Classical",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Decision theoretic approach to statistical problems, complete class theorems, Bayes and minimax\nprocedures, sequential decision problems, sufficiency, comparison of experiments, invariance; most stringent, similar,\nunbiased, likelihood ratio tests; efficiency, Cramer-Rao inequality, estimation analogues of good tests; confidence sets.\nPrerequisite: MA 57100, STAT 52800, STAT 53900, STAT 57600. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "TECH22000",
    "Title": "Designing Technology For People",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Innovating in our complex world requires understanding people and the issues and challenges they\nface. This unique course brings together perspectives from technology and anthropology to address this by exploring\nethnographic studies of people and technology interactions. Through this process, students will practice the problem\nscoping skills necessary to identify and define problems and begin to generate appropriate design solutions. In addition,\nstudents will learn how to observe and talk with people about technology and discuss a range of ways people\nuse technology. Accordingly, the course will focus on human-centered design and how to empathize will people during\nthe design process. This will allow students to learn how to identify opportunities for innovation that emerge when\ndesigners carefully observe and listen to humans using technology and/or experiencing problems with current\ntechnology. Note: This class engages the material in both the classroom and innovation labs.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Foundations Of Innovation Studies",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Foundations Of Innovation Studies has been designed to provide a broad spectrum introduction to\nthe field of innovation studies.   {
    "Course": "TLI52100",
    "Title": "Drug Development",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "A review of drug discovery and drug development, with emphasis on the regulatory aspects of\nthese activities. Animal preclinical research and human clinical research are discussed in detail. In addition, the process\nfor the assembly of an IND and NDA is discussed along with the Phases (I,II,III) of human clinical trials. The CMC\n(chemistry manufacturing and control) aspects of drug development are presented along with ICH documents and\nmanufacturing process analytical technologies. The course concludes with a brief review of international regulatory\nissues and patents. Typically offered Summer Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

  {
    "Course": "TLI52600",
    "Title": "Digital Innovation And Transformation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Rapidly evolving digital technologies are fueling a stream of innovation opportunities. To remain\nrelevant, incumbent firms need to innovate and transform their business models. Digital strategies and innovation,\nhowever, oftentimes conflict with traditional managerial thinking. For example, rapidly falling coordination costs and\nthe rising relevance of data make diversification patterns profitable that contradict today's dominant view that focused\nproduct-market positioning is best. This course explores the different effects the digital revolution has on the\nfoundations of competitive advantage and thereby prepares its students to design, apply, and implement strategies and\nsystems for digital innovation. Permission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "TLI54000",
    "Title": "Smart Manufacturing Enterprise: Organizational Behavior And\nLeadership In The Digital Enterprise",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Smart manufacturing is about increasing efficiency and eliminating pain points in your system. It's\ncharacterized by a highly connected, knowledge-enabled industrial enterprise where all organizations and operating\nsystems are linked, leading to enhanced productivity, sustainability, and economic performance. Implementing smart\nmanufacturing techniques requires an effective understanding of organizational behavior and leadership skills required\nfor the new digital enterprise. This knowledge of individuals' perceptions, attitudes, and behavior enables leaders to\nchoose appropriate leadership styles and managerial practices to increase organizational effectiveness and positive\nhuman outcomes. This course will provide an overview of organizational behavior and leadership concepts important\nfor implementing change within a smart manufacturing enterprise. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "TLI62500",
    "Title": "Research In Open Innovation I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This is a research-oriented course designed for graduate students who aim to develop and\nimplement a scientific research project in the field of open innovation. They will critically discuss and evaluate\nscientific writings relevant to the new research area of open innovation from the fields and disciplines of innovation\nstudies, information systems, and other social sciences. Through synthesis of theories and frameworks used in\nacademic articles, the students will develop a theoretically and practically motivated research question. They will also\nimplement a pilot study to examine their hypotheses. The Research Center for Open Digital Innovation (RCODI) in the\nDiscovery Park at Purdue will offer opportunities to plan and implement individual questions, if students have not\nidentified their own data source. In addition, the students will participate in an action-oriented research project in open\ninnovation performed by the class as a group project to gain experience in experimental innovation research and\npractice. Prerequisites: Basic statistics (at least STAT 30100 or equivalent, STAT 50100 or higher is recommended);\nfoundational knowledge in scientific research (TECH 64600 or SOC 58000 or equivalent). Permission of instructor\nrequired. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "TLI66200",
    "Title": "Philosophy Of Technology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The term technology has multiple meaning and applications so vast that one clear and all-\nencompassing definition of the term has become unattainable. However, to build an epistemology of technology, we\nmust explore ways to define technology so to provide a foundation for a philosophy of technology.   {
    "Course": "TDM11100",
    "Title": "Corporate Partners I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Students in The Data Mine Corporate Partners Learning Community will work in groups with\nCorporate Partner mentors on a variety of projects. They will analyze real data related to questions that the Corporate\nPartner proposes. Most projects will last for a full academic year (late August through late April), with multiple reports\nand presentations given more frequently. The mentor is expected to meet with the students weekly by Microsoft Teams,\nor (more rarely) in person. Students are expected to actively participate in these meetings and in all individual and\ngroup work. The goal of the course is to help students build impactful industry related skills in data science,\nvisualization, and data engineering. The Data Mine staff also has data scientists who can assist students with technical\nquestions focused on the skills being built and the research conducted. Students can work on real-world industry facing\nissues that have a high value add for the corporate partner.Credits: 3.00"

  },
  {
    "Course": "TDM30100",
    "Title": "The Data Mine Seminar V",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "The Data Mine is a supportive environment for students in any major from any background who\nwant to learn some data science skills. Students will gain hands-on experience with computational tools for\nrepresenting, extracting, manipulating, interpreting, transforming, and visualizing data, especially big data sets, and in\neffectively communicating insights about data. Topics include: the R environment, Python, visualizing data, UNIX,\nbash, regular expressions, SQL, XML and scraping data from the internet, as well as selected advanced topics, as time\npermits.Credits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "TDM31100",
    "Title": "Corporate Partners V",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Students in The Data Mine Corporate Partners Learning Community will work in groups with\nCorporate Partner mentors on a variety of projects. They will analyze real data related to questions that the Corporate\nPartner proposes. Most projects will last for a full academic year (late August through late April), with multiple reports\nand presentations given more frequently. The mentor is expected to meet with the students weekly by Microsoft Teams,\nor (more rarely) in person. Students are expected to actively participate in these meetings and in all individual and\ngroup work. The goal of the course is to help students build impactful industry related skills in data science,\nvisualization, and data engineering. The Data Mine staff also has data scientists who can assist students with technical\nquestions focused on the skills being built and the research conducted. Students can work on real-world industry facing\nissues that have a high value add for the corporate partner.Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "VCS80130",
    "Title": "Introduction To Population Medicine And Veterinary Ethics",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course will introduce first year veterinary students to the fundamental principles of population\nmedicine. This will include concepts behind population versus individual animal medicine, population animal\nindustries and their management practices, population animal diseases, outbreak investigation, regulatory medicine, and\ninteractions between wild and domestic animals. Following an introduction to population medicine, students will shift\nto a discussion of veterinary ethics and its application to various animal industries. Students will explore basic concepts\nin animal use ethics and welfare, ethical and moral reasoning, and critical thinking and problem solving in population\nmedicine. Typically offered Fall Summer.Credits: 2.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "VCS80140",
    "Title": "Fundamental Principles Of Comparative Nutrition",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course will cover fundamental aspects of comparative nutrition building on knowledge from\nveterinary comparative anatomy and physiology courses. Multiple species will be discussed to provide the student a\nbroad-based foundational knowledge in key nutritional concepts, including feeds and feeding assessment and the\nanimal's physiologic state/lifestage. The student will learn how physiologic status will impacts energy needs and\nnutritional adequacy, on an individual and/or group basis. The student will also develop skills in forage identification,\npet food assessment, and when the individual/group is at risk of nutrient deficiency. Typically offered Spring\nSummer.Credits: 2.00"

  {
    "Course": "VCS81410",
    "Title": "Comparative Theriogenology",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course develops a broad clinical knowledge of common reproductive management strategies\nand clinical conditions associated with reproduction in the major domestic species. It provides information and\nstrategies for the conduct of breeding soundness examinations and infertility work-ups in the male; estrous cycle\ncharacteristics, diagnostics and control in females; breeding management strategies, pregnancy diagnosis, and\nmanagement of gestation; investigation and control strategies for pregnancy loss; management of parturition and\ntreatment of dystocia; normal post-partum changes and diseases of the peri-partum period and the pathophysiology and\ntreatment of uterine infections. Material will be presented in both comparative and species-specific manner. Students\nshould review reproductive anatomy and physiology notes in preparation for this course.     "Title": "Diagnostic Imaging",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course covers basic mechanisms of image generation and interpretation. Focuses\non the diagnosis and treatment of diseases commonly encountered in small animal practice. Typically offered Spring\nSummer.Credits: 1.50"

    "Course": "VCS88602",
    "Title": "Clinical Veterinary Services At Centaur Equine Specialty Hospital",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this 3-week rotation students will assist the staff with diagnosis and treatment of sports-related\nconditions including lameness diagnosis and treatment, evaluation and treatment of upper respiratory diseases, and\ndiagnosis and treatment of a variety of surgical conditions such as lacerations and traumatic injuries to the\nmusculoskeletal system.   {
    "Course": "VCS89200",
    "Title": "Veterinary Forensic Medicine",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "The definition of forensic medicine is a science that deals with the relation and application of\nmedical facts to legal problems. The primary role of a forensic specialist is to provide law enforcement officials,\njudges, and jury members with the information necessary to make decisions (decision to prosecute, render a verdict,\netc.) regarding a case. This elective course is designed to expose students to the many situations where veterinary\nmedicine and the law intersect. Offered SpringCredits: 1.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "VCS89300",
    "Title": "Shelter Animal Medicine",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "The Shelter Animal medicine course will be offered to second and third year veterinary students.\nThe course will cover topics essential to understanding the complexity of population medicine in a shelter environment\nand related welfare issues. Topics to be covered include animal shelter models (no-kill/adoption guarantee, tradition,\netc.), population medicine and disease control as it relates to the environment and the animals, critical care in a shelter\nenvironment, foster care, neonatal care of shelter animals, population statistics, animal behavior and relinquishment\nissues, abuse and cruelty, legal and ethical issues, euthanasia, and developing and implementing animal disaster plans.\nTypically offered Spring Summer.Credits: 1.00"

  {
    "Course": "VM20100",
    "Title": "Introduction To Veterinary Technology",
    "CreditHours": 1.5,
    "Description": "A didactic course which presents the basic skills that will be used in all nursing courses and in the\noverall curriculum. The course will provide an introduction to the various opportunities within the veterinary healthcare\nprofession as well as a general introduction to the attributes and traits of veterinary medical professionals. In addition,\nthe course introduces medical math and terminology used in veterinary medicine. Students will complete exercises\nutilizing math concepts used for dosage calculations, conversions, proper notation, dispensing medications, fluid\ntherapy calculations, and percent solutions. Students will use medical terminology including prefixes, roots, and\nsuffixes of medical terms to complete exercises. This knowledge will be utilized in didactic courses and labs as well as\nin clinical rotations. Students will learn normal temperature, pulse and respiration values for various species. There will\nbe both in-class and self-study components. This course combines content previously presented in VM 14000 and VM\n25100. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 1.50"
  },

    "Description": "to 3.00. This practicum will provide international students with hands-on experience working in a\nmodern veterinary practice or other veterinary medical setting.   {
    "Course": "VM82000",
    "Title": "Applications And Integrations I",
    "CreditHours": 2.0,
    "Description": "This course uses a small group tutorial, problem-oriented approach to understanding how basic\nscience concepts are integrated into clinical aspects of veterinary medicine. Students are expected to identify learning\nissues, resolve identified gaps in their knowledge base, integrate information across disciplines, and practice/develop\nproblem-solving skills using simulated case materials. Evaluation of students will be based upon, but not limited to,\ntutorial group evaluation, peer evaluation, self-evaluation, and comprehensive content and process examinations.\nIntroductory session on hematology, clinical chemistry and radiography will be included to facilitate student\ninterpretation of testing used in the cases.Credits: 2.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 2.0,

Students are expected to identify learning issues, resolve\nidentified gaps in their knowledge base, integrate information across disciplines, and practice/develop problem-solving\nskills using simulated case materials and research problems at a higher level of performance than in VM 82000, VM\n83000, and VM 84000.     "Course": "VM86000",
    "Title": "Early Origins Of Veterinary Medicine Seminar",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Students will study the very early origins of man's fascination with animals from the Paleolithic\nera, and the roots of veterinary medicine in Mesopotamia, Ancient Egypt, and East and South Asia. Particular attention\nwill be paid to works of art that help demonstrate man's fascination with animals and their well-being. This course is\nappropriate for students with no previous study of history or art history. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "VM86500",
    "Title": "History Of Veterinary Medicine From Marshals, Horse Doctors, Cow\nLeeches, The First Schools Of VM",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "The students will study the history of marshals, horse doctors, cow leeches, and authors, an\nemphasis on the launching of European veterinary education with a rationale for a veterinary profession, and the history\nof the first official schools of veterinary medicine in France (Lyon and Alfort), concluding with the history of the\nincreasing demand for veterinary schools. Particular attention will be paid to works that help demonstrate man's\nfascination with animals and their well-being. This course is appropriate for students with no previous study of history"
  },
  {
    "Course": "VM86600",
    "Title": "Pathogenic Bacteria, Viruses, Mayhew, Darwin, And Mendel",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Students will study the golden age of pathogenic bacteriology from the 1860s to the end of the\nnineteenth century; the discovery of viruses; the development of immunological products; intractable vector-borne\nhemoprotozoal parasitic diseases; horse-doctoring in the nineteenth century; care of animals used in transport, war and\nsport; and will conclude with Darwin's natural selection and Mendel's fractional inheritance. Particular attention will be\npaid to works that help demonstrate man's fascination with animals and their well-being. This course is appropriate for\nstudents with no previous study of history or art history. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 1.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "Students will study early veterinary contributions to biomedical science; how livestock production\nwas enhanced by veterinary specialists; companion animal medicine; bioethics, animal experimentation, and sentience;\novercoming the exclusion of women, and the evolving spectrum of opportunity in veterinary careers. This course is\nappropriate for students with no previous study of history or art history. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 1.00"

    "Course": "VM87000",
    "Title": "History Of Veterinary Medicine From The Ancient Greeks Through The\nRenaissance Seminar",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "The students will study the contributions of the ancient Greeks and Romans to the development of\nanimal doctors. The veterinary highpoint during the Byzantine Empire and Arabian medical and veterinary progress\nwill also be studied. Animals in the Dark Ages, equine and canine medicine in Medieval Europe, and the Italian roots\nof the Renaissance in medical sciences will be studied. Particular attention will be paid to works of art that help\ndemonstrate man's fascination with animals and their well-being. This course is appropriate for students with no\nprevious study of history or art history. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 1.00"

    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "to 3.00. This course allows veterinary students to participate in a unique faculty-led veterinary\nlearning experience in an international location. Credit will be assigned on the basis of 1 credit for each 45-50 hours of\nstudent effort up to a maximum of 3 credits. In most instances, one week of experience will equal one credit. Each\nveterinary learning experience will be designed by the faculty leader to accomplish specific learning goals in the\nfocuses area of study.     "Title": "Clinical Rotation In Small Animal Medicine In Switzerland",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is a 3-credit clinical rotation. A faculty member will lead this elective 3-week clinical\nrotation in Switzerland. The Purdue faculty member leading the rotation each year will spend one week at\neach rotation site.   {
    "Course": "WGSS43000",
    "Title": "Women In African History",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "(HIST 43000 [Inactive]) African women's history is rich and deeply layered. In this course, we will\nexamine the social, political, economic, religious, and cultural experiences of women living in Africa. Although we\nlook at women in the pre-colonial and slave trade eras, the focus will be on women during the nineteenth and twentieth\ncenturies. Much of our reading and discussion will consider not only women, but also gender as we think about\nwomen's interactions with men and children. This course is concerned with the historical forces shaping African\nwomen's lives, as well as with ways in which women have been active agents in the making of their own histories.\nStudents can expect to engage with a number of different types of texts (e.g. firms, novels, scholarly analyses, and\nprimary sources.) Typically offered Fall, Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Title": "Feminist Perspectives On Film And Cinema And Visual Culture",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course, students investigate the gendered and intersectional meanings ascribed to or\ngenerated by popular cinematic and other mass-distributed visual texts, with particular attention to the way that visual\nmedia have impacted women's participation in public culture over the last century and a half. This course is highly\nconceptual, asking students to learn to recognize power relations hiding within visual entertainments and embedded\nwithin the experience of everyday life. with the goal of deepening their understanding and appreciation of the\nexperience of spectatorship and visuality as a central element of modern American and contemporary global mass\nculture.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "VIP17911",
    "Title": "First Year Participation In Vertically Integrated Projects (VIP) I",
    "CreditHours": 1.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an opportunity for undergraduate students to engage in authentic and\nextended research and design projects related to active research areas of Purdue faculty members and national,\ninternational, and industry-sponsored design challenges. Students will work on interdisciplinary and vertically-\nintegrated teams (first-year through seniors) with faculty and graduate student mentors to address these real-world\nresearch and design challenges. Students will participate in weekly lectures and professional development activities\nthat include topics related to design, research, documentation and technical writing, communication, leadership and\nteamwork, ethics, project management, intellectual property, information literacy, and introduction to a broad range of\napplicable research topics, technologies and development tools. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 1.00"

  {
    "Course": "ANTH41700",
    "Title": "The State Of The World: Social Theory And Human Crisis In The\nTwenty-First Century",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course we will examine a series of urgent issues facing the global community through\nreading ethnography and studying social theory. For each issue, we will read recent ethnographic research that\nilluminates the issue as well as social theories that connect the issue to long-standing zones of theorizing among social\nscientists. Through careful reading and discussion, students will learn about the urgent issues that will shape their\nprofessional and personal lives, become familiar with theoretical approaches that illuminate these issues, and engage in\ndiscussion and debate about these issues in a diverse classroom. The following issues is a sample of the types of global\nissues that the course will cover: the environment (i.e., global warming, environmental critiques of capitalism, the\nstruggle for indigenous rights to land, the energy economy), global struggles for rights (for indigenous peoples, women,\nthe LGBTQ community, the global underclass, stateless peoples), the state system (to include an examination of the\nnature of the state, authoritarian and leaderless states, democracy in crisis, the warlord state), technological change\n(social media, AI, cyberwarfare), and violence (weak states, the global arms trade, the nuclear threat). Theoretical\nperspectives to be covered include historical materialism, world systems theory, gender studies, subaltern studies,\npostcolonialism, poststructuralism, and others. Credits: 3.00"
  },

  {
    "Course": "BIOL51501",
    "Title": "Non-Mendelian Genetics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course students will explore topics and papers on genetic and environmental sources of\nvariation in inherited disorders. This includes but is not limited to epistatic and other pathway influences, complex\n(multigenic) diseases, quantitative traits, genetic modifiers, environmental risk factors, gene x environment\ninteractions. Students will look at primary research that identifies examples of these factors, both in human disease and\nin animal models of disease. They will also complete a miniature proposal, in which they will identify a human disease\nor disease model that is subject to phenotypic variation. They will propose an experiment to either characterize the\nimpact of a modifying factor on that disease, or a way to screen for/identify modifying factors. We will have in-class\ntime to work on this project during the Journal Club/Workshop portion of the course. Permission of instructor\nrequired. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "BIOL57501",
    "Title": "Systematic Biology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Systematic biology is the study of how life is classified in order to best study and understand\nbiodiversity. This course is both a historical course and a research methods course. The history of classification systems\n(such as how Linnaean ranks came to be, and the weakness of using these ranks) will be discussed, leading into how\nmodern phylogenetic methods were developed that have given rise to reliable methods to test hypotheses of\nevolutionary relationships. The course will go into detail for modern systematic methods, and will incorporate short\nexercises in how to use these methods - including model-based methods of studying genomic data - to reconstruct\nevolutionary relationships. Students complete several systematic research projects, including one they design and\nimplement. Credits: 3.0"
  },

  {
    "Course": "BIOL59001",
    "Title": "Mammalogy",
    "CreditHours": 4.0,
    "Description": "This course will cover mammalian evolutionary history from the first basal synapsids over 300\nmillion years ago, when the mammalian lineage spilt from the reptile lineage. The series of transformations that\noccurred leading to modern living mammals will be studied by examining the fossil record. Living mammalian\nbiodiversity will be explored at the family level. For all extant groups the course will examine evolutionary history, life\nhistory traits, and ecological aspects - including conservation issues. Current 'hot button' issues regarding conservation\nwill be highlighted, such as the plight of the white rhino and cases were mammals are invasive species. Anatomy of\nmammals will be examined in lab, with dissections and study of osteological specimens. Credits: 4.00"
  },

    "Title": "Probability, Statistics, And Applications In Biomedical Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Probability theory and statistical methods are developed for life science applications.   },
  {
    "Course": "BME33100",
    "Title": "Biosignals And Systems",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course applies mathematical analysis tools to biological signals and systems. Frequency\nanalysis, Fourier and Laplace transforms, and state equations are used to represent and analyze continuous and discrete-\ntime biosignals. Classic feedback analysis tools are applied to biological systems that rely on negative feedback for\ncontrol and homeostasis. Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Title": "Biofluid Mechanics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course explores fluid mechanics in the context of the human circulatory system.   },
  {
    "Course": "BME52600",
    "Title": "Cardiac Electrophysiology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will introduce the basic principles of cardiac-generated bioelectricity as measured at\ncellular, extracellular and body surfaces. The generation, detection and classification of abnormal cardiac rhythms will\nbe emphasized. Clinical and engineering principles of relevant electro-therapies will also be studied including cardiac\npacemakers, defibrillators and ablation therapies involving cardiac mapping and a variety of ablative energy sources.\nModern signal processing methods as applied to electrocardiography will also be presented. Permission of department\nrequired.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "BME54500",
    "Title": "Orthopaedic Tissue Mechanics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Orthopaedic tissues, such as bone, cartilage, tendon and ligament, serve functions that are largely\nmechanical in nature and that are critical for our health. This course is structured around classical topics in mechanics\nof materials and their applications in biomechanics and musculoskeletal tissues. Primary emphasis will be on the\nmechanical behavior of tissues, including elastic and failure properties as well as more advanced topics such as\nanisotropy, nonlinearity, viscoelasticity, poroelasticity, damage, and fatigue. Importantly, the theories used to describe\nthese mechanical properties were originally developed for advanced engineering materials such as fiber composites,\npolymers, elastomers, hydrogels, etc. Thus, while the theories will be presented in the context of biological materials,\npotential applications are much broader. Tissue microstructure and its importance to the material properties will be\ncovered. Mechanics of whole bones and implants (composite and asymmetric beam theories) and the mechanical\nfunction of native and artificial joints (contact mechanics, lubrication and wear) may also be discussed, time permitting.\nSome homework assignments will emphasize the use of experimental data to develop and test theoretical models via\nnonlinear curve fitting and optimization using Matlab. Students will receive an introduction to tissue mechanics\nliterature to better understand how the concepts presented in class are used in the research setting. Credits: 3.00"
  },

Students will build data-driven and location-aware applications and be\nintroduced to a variety of object-oriented software design patterns common to mobile application development. A\nvariety of data storage and remote data source-driven applications will be introduced. Apple student developer accounts\nare provided. Beginning programming experience is required. Development computers are available through the\nStudent Technology Centers. Access to a personal Macintosh computer is encouraged, but not required. Credits: 3.00"

Students will take a hands-on approach\nusing publicly available data sources to build their own BI platform to gain better insight into the various phases and\ncomplexities involved in analytic systems.   {
    "Course": "CS52520",
    "Title": "Software Design I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This is a first course in Software Design, which is an internship-training course that the PNW\nComputer Science faculty conducts in cooperation with a local software industry partner, with students working on\nsoftware development projects for the partner. Over the past few years the project has been run in conjunction with the\nValparaiso, Indiana based software development company, BEULAHWORKS, LLC.\nThis course introduces various topics related to software design including Object-Oriented Analysis & Design, Object-\nOriented Design Principles, UML Diagrams, Architecture Design & Patterns and other topics.\nIn addition, students will participate in developing software for software industry use. In particular, students will work\nin small teams to design and implement new features for a commercial software project. By the end of the course,\nstudents should gain practical experience with enterprise software design and implementation. The first half of the\nsemester will be devoted to lectures regarding software design (assignments related to the lectures will also be given\nduring this time). For the second half, students will be working on the project.\nThe students who get a B or better grade will be able to take the second course of the sequence, Software Design II.\nPermission of instructor required. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "CS52530",

  {
    "Course": "CS58300",
    "Title": "Big Data Analytics in Cloud Computing",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course brings together the principles of large-scale distributed computing and the state of the\nart for Big Data Analytics in the Cloud. This course will first overview Cloud computing which is a service model for\nlarge-scale distributed computing, and the representative platform, Hadoop. Then, the course will introduce\nMapReduce which is a scalable programming model for processing Big Data on a cluster and have in-depth analysis of\nvarious algorithmic design patterns, and go on to explore Big Data Analytics applications on Hadoop MapReduce and\nSpark. Afterwards, the course will introduce NoSQL systems for Big Data storage. This course will also show how to\ndeal with services from public cloud infrastructures. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "EDPS38000",
    "Title": "Special Education Law For Teachers",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "The purpose of this course is to provide pre-service teachers with a general understanding of the\neducational entitlement and civil rights of children with disabilities. Laws ensuring the provision of special education to\nstudents with disabilities are based on constitutional principles, written and enacted by legislatures and administrative\nagencies, and interpreted by the courts. It is through the interaction of these various components of the legal system,\nlegislative and judicial, that the field of special education has evolved. The knowledge and skills gained in this course\nshape the advocacy and ethical dispositions of the teacher. Permission of Department required. Typically offered Fall\nSpring.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ENGL51402",
    "Title": "Using Poems To Beat Death (Finding Poetry To Live)",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will provide an exploration and examination into poetics and its relationship with\nperformance. It's said that public speaking is the number one fear, even before death. With that in mind, students will\nlearn to use their voice and represent their voice through performance/oral renditions of their individual work, and work\nthat they choose to use that speaks to them. Students will view, read, analyze, and discuss, as well as explore the\nstructural, figurative, and literary devices of poetic language, while at the same time redefining the common rules of\nverse as a foundation for performance. We will investigate and reinforce the \"everyday\" poetry happening around us,\nwhich goes unnoticed. We will study some traditional poetic forms and contemporary works, which will often be\nperformed, produce pieces which integrate more than one artistic discipline, and develop a critical\nvocabulary. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,

Students will read a lot of twentieth-century\nAmerican poetry, learn how to analyze and discuss it, and consider it in light of form, technique, theme, and cultural\nconsiderations.   {
    "Course": "HIST33301",
    "Title": "Eugenics As Racism/Bigotry\nCredit hours: 3.00. History of the eugenics movement, including its impact on the United States and the Western\nWorld, its role in fostering racism and bigotry, and its influence in forming racial policies like those of Nazi Germany.\nTypically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00\nHIST 33604 - France In World War I And World War II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This class considers the history of French society, culture, and politics through participation in the\nFirst and Second World Wars. While WWI and WWII affected millions of people around the globe, France held a\nunique position in that in addition to the fighting, French civilians lived under harsh occupation in both world\nwars. This course explores the French experiences during the two world wars, considering the war experience from\ndiverse perspectives, including those of soldiers, civilians, men, women, collaborators, resisters, and France's imperial\nsubjects. While the class is centered on the two world wars, it is not a military history course; rather, the course\nfocuses on society and culture and how the war experiences shaped France, the French Empire, and its people. Along\nwith the war experience, students will consider the shifting view of war as it was being anticipated, fought, and\nremembered.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "MA57700",
    "Title": "Computational Mathematics I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This is a graduate-level course in computational mathematics, which is the study of algorithms and\nmethods for computing numerical answers to science and engineering problems. The purpose of this course is to\nintroduce students to the techniques and concepts of modern numerical analysis. In this course, students study\nalgorithms and numerical methods for a variety of basic problems, studying their reliability, efficiency, and computer\nimplementation. This course is designed for graduate students and select advanced undergraduate students in\nmathematics, computer science, engineering, and sciences. Topics include floating point arithmetic, numerical\nsolutions of equations and systems, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, polynomial and spline interpolation and\napproximation, and curve fitting. Each numerical method discussed in class is demonstrated through the use of\nMATLAB, which is user friendly and presents advantages such as: powerful matrix structure, versatile two- and three-\ndimensional graphing facilities, and a vast number of built-in functions. Typically offered Fall Spring.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "ME50201",
    "Title": "Single Phase Convective Heat Transfer",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course will cover fundamentals of single-phase convective heat transfer by focusing on\nmethods in determining convective heat transfer rates in various flow conditions most of which will be combined with\ncalculations for the other modes of heat transfer to predict the overall heat transfer. The topics will include external\nlaminar flows, laminar flow in ducts, external and internal turbulent flows, natural convection, combined convection,\nand convective heat transfer in porous media flow.   },
  {
    "Course": "ME50801",
    "Title": "Orthopaedic Tissue Mechanics",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Orthopaedic tissues, such as bone, cartilage, tendon and ligament, serve functions that are largely\nmechanical in nature and that are critical for our health. This course is structured around classical topics in mechanics\nof materials and their applications in biomechanics and musculoskeletal tissues. Primary emphasis will be on the\nmechanical behavior of tissues, including elastic and failure properties as well as more advanced topics such as\nanisotropy, nonlinearity, viscoelasticity, poroelasticity, damage and fatigue. Importantly, the theories used to describe\nthese mechanical properties were originally developed for advanced engineering materials such as fiber composites,\npolymers, elastomers, hydrogels, etc. Thus, while the theories will be presented in the context of biological materials,\npotential applications are much broader. Tissue microstructure and its importance to the material properties will be\ncovered. Mechanics of whole bones and implants (composite and asymmetric beam theories) and the mechanical\nfunction of native and artificial joints (contact mechanics, lubrication and wear) may also be discussed, time permitting.\nSome homework assignments will emphasize the use of experimental data to develop and test theoretical models via\nnonlinear curve fitting and optimization using Matlab. Students will receive an introduction to tissue mechanics\nliterature to better understand how the concepts presented in class are used in the research setting.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "Course": "ME50810",
    "Title": "Introduction To Two Phase Flow And Heat Transfer",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course is intended for graduate engineer or scientist who is interested in multiphase\nflow and heat transfer area (where several different phases of fluids co-exist, e.g. water boiling, combustion\nand the operation of the power plant). Thermo-fluid transport phenomena in multiphase system will be\ndiscussed as well as the methodology and techniques to formulate and solve problems associated with the\nphenomena. Permission of instructor required.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "ME53503",
    "Title": "Model-Based Systems Engineering",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course focuses MBSE or Model-Based Systems Engineering (i.e. the model-based version of\nSystems Engineering) with an emphasis on its intelligent implementation using SysML graphical language for systems\nrepresentation. The other two pillars for implementing MBSE are also covered: a methodology (OOSEM) and a tool\n(Cameo Systems Modeler). The coursework incorporates theoretical concepts learned in earlier systems engineering\nclasses and is structured around the Object Modeling Group's SysML which is used in modeling systems. SysML's\napplication to real-life projects and businesses to define, track and visualize various aspects of a system is investigated.\nCase studies from a variety of disciplines -- including engineering and healthcare - are used as teaching tools. Typically\noffered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "ME53504",
    "Title": "Systems Driven Product Development",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Integrated Model-Based Systems Driven Product (and Process) Development, or SDPD (Systems\nDriven Product Development) is a methodology and framework for integrating system behavioral modeling with\ndownstream design and manufacturing practices to plan multi-domain, complex, systems. SDPD is an implementation\nof MBE (Model-based Engineering) which integrates MBSE (Model-based Systems Engineering) and PLM (Product\nLifecycle Management) to create the \"Digital Twin\" of a product/process and support the digital transformation\nresulting in the digital enterprise of Industry 4.0 (4th Industrial Revolution). The course covers key concepts and\ndefinitions pertaining to SDPD including MBSE (Model-based Systems Engineering), PLM, Digital Manufacturing,\nDigital Twin, Digital Thread, Industry 4.0, Interoperability, Traceability, Validation/Verification, Optimization, and\nPredictive Analytics. State-of-the-art engineering software tools are taught and used by students to design, optimize and\nverify multi-domain complex products (or systems) following the SDPD methodology. The graduate level project\nconsists of a comprehensive implementation of SDPD methodology in real-life/industry relevant design and\noptimization of complex (multi-domain) systems. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00"
  },

This management area, which federates activities as diverse as production, transportation, inventory,\nwarehousing, purchasing, material handling, sales, and customer service, represents a synthesis of methods and\ntechniques coming from traditional business areas of finance, accounting, management, and marketing, as well as\nbusiness decision-making tools offered by operations research, statistics, and economics.   {
    "Course": "MUSC40501",
    "Title": "Music History I",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course offers a broad introduction to the history of music from Greek and Roman antiquity\nuntil circa 1600. In addition to developing skills pertinent to matters of style, genre, function, and form, students will\nengage with the social, cultural and philosophical contexts of musicking from a global perspective. Historical\napproaches to music pedagogy; connections between music and the body; developments in musical notation and music\npublishing; the evolving relationship between music and text; and the relationship between musical transmission and\nhuman migration will be emphasized in this course. Above all, this course aims to foster and develop listening skills\nessential to thinking, speaking, and writing critical and intelligently about all musical traditions, and to combine these\nskills with historical and cultural knowledge of diverse musical traditions. Typically offered Spring.Credits: 3.00"
  },
  {
    "Course": "MUSC40502",
    "Title": "Music History II",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course offers a broad introduction to the history of music from circa 1600 until circa 1900. In\naddition to developing skills pertinent to matters of style, genre, function, and form, students will engage with the\nsocial, cultural, and philosophical contexts of musicking from a global perspective. The intersections of science and the\ndevelopment of instrumental technology; connections between music and the body; a critical exploration of the\nhistoriography of women and musicking; and the relationship between popular song, nationalism, race (and slavery),\nand colonialism will be emphasized in this course. Above all, this course aims to foster and develop listening skills\nessential to thinking, speaking, and writing critically and intelligently about all musical traditions, and to combine these\nskills with historical and cultural knowledge of diverse musical traditions. Typically offered Fall.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "NUR62601",
    "Title": "Applied Biostatistics For Outcome Evaluation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course, students will learn to interpret biostatistics commonly used in nursing and\nhealth services research. This course covers important concepts and techniques for understanding and\ninterpreting statistical results and evaluating health outcomes. The focus of this course will be when to use a\ngiven method and how to interpret the results, not the actual computation or computer programming to obtain\nresults from raw data. This course will involve minimal calculation and offer no formal training in any statistical\nsoftware. Students will examine, translate and critically analyze biostatistics through the fundamental concepts\nof:\n\u2022 study design,\n\u2022 descriptive statistics,\n\u2022 hypothesis testing,\n\u2022 confidence intervals,\n\u2022 odds ratios,\n\u2022 relative risks,\n\u2022 multiple linear, logistic and proportional hazards regression,\n\u2022 power analysis, and\n\u2022 survival analysis.\nCredits: 3.00"

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this internship course, students will have the opportunity to develop an understanding of the\napplication of clinical psychology in the real world.     "Course": "PSY43100",
    "Title": "Advanced Psychobiology",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this course, students will learn about different stages of brain maturation: prenatal brain\ndevelopment, child and adolescent brain development, and the aging brain. Emphasis will be placed on how certain\nbrain regions grow or degenerate at different stages of life and how that relates to observed changes in behavior. Topics\nmay include: disorders of brain development, how experience guides brain development, adolescent susceptibility to\npsychological disorders, and age-related cognitive decline. Hands-on experience will be gained through exercises in\nbrain anatomy. In addition, students will design an empirical project in the area of developmental\nneuroscience.Credits: 3.00"
  },

    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "In this internship course, students will have the opportunity to develop an understanding of the\napplication of clinical psychology in the real world. Interns will engage in a high level of hands-on activities, including\ndirect educational outreach on campus, disseminating information on mental health and suicide prevention, providing\nresources, and shadowing licensed clinicians through the mental health screening and assessment process. Interns will\nconduct mental health self-screenings while learning to differentiate the different screening and assessment tools, how\nthey are administered and how and when referrals for intervention are made. Sudents will develop an individual capstone project related to mental health education and/or prevention. Both\nPSY 37700 and PSY 47700 cannot apply to major.Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "SOC25000",
    "Title": "Personal Life, Intimacy, And The Risk Society",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "This course provides an overview of the nature of the day-to-day life of individuals in\ncontemporary Western societies. It deals with questions such as: How do individuals navigate through the complex\nrealities of late modernity? How manufactured risks and heighted uncertainty affect our life course and the choices we\nmake in our daily lives? How do we shape our lives amid the continuous erosion of traditional institutions such as\nreligion, family, class, and work? How do new lifestyles impact physical and phycological well-being? Indicative\ntopics are the new family structures and marriage patterns, issues of adolescence and new media, problems of identity\nand the shaping of the body, the rise of social networks and new types of romantic relationships, childlessness, post-\ndivorce families and the new experiences of work. Throughout the course various theoretical approaches to\ncontemporary society will be considered: U. Beck's concepts of individualization and risk, Bauman's concept of liquid\nmodernity, and Giddens' theses on the juggernaut, late modernity, and self-identity.Credits: 3.00"

    "Course": "SPAN31800",
    "Title": "Introduction To Spanish Translation",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Those who speak two or more languages often find themselves in situations in which\nthey are asked to translate (in written form) or interpret (orally) from one language to the other. These tasks\ninvolve different skills than those practiced in most language development classes. This course introduces\nstudents to the history, theory, methods, techniques, and problems involved in translating from English to\nSpanish and/or Spanish to English. Students will also gain practice in the translation of simple documents\n(i.e.: newspaper articles, magazine articles, tourist brochures, etc.). This course is designed to prepare\nstudents for further studies in translation, including professional trainings and/or certification\nprograms. Credits: 3.00"

  {
    "Course": "SWRK37100",
    "Title": "Grief And Loss\nCredit hours: 3.00. Grief and Loss is designed to help students develop a deeper understanding of the processes of\ndying, death, and bereavement. Emphasis is on increasing awareness of the individual, societal, legal, ethical, cultural,\ntheoretical, and historical factors that influence attitudes and behaviors surrounding death. Focus is on the development\nof competence informed by knowledge, values, skills, and cognitive and affective processes. This competence is\nspecific to the provision of supportive and referral/case management services to individuals, families, and communities\nexperiencing loss. Typically offered Fall Spring Summer.Credits: 3.00\nSWRK 37400 - Trauma And Crisis Intervention",
    "CreditHours": 3.0,
    "Description": "Trauma and Crisis Intervention combines two important components of working with vulnerable\npopulations in crisis. First, trauma-informed care aims to prepare students through research and best practice standards\nwhen working with individuals, families, groups, organizations, and communities. Standards for competent practice in\nresponse to trauma are an ethical obligation of the profession, because the likelihood of encountering survivors of\ntrauma in every practice setting is very high. Additionally, trauma-informed care recognizes the importance for\nstudents to understand the impact of the work on self, colleagues, the organization, and the system. Understanding the\nimpact of secondary traumatic stress, vicarious traumatization, vicarious resilience, and posttraumatic growth is critical\nto professional growth and development. Second, Non-violent Crisis Intervention training is a safe, nonharmful\nbehavior management system designed to help human service professionals provide the best possible care for\nvulnerable people involved in crisis situations. This training will result in the possibility of students becoming certified\nin Non-violent Crisis Intervention. Credits: 3.00"
  },
